Abstract:
This study aims to investigate whether there is a difference in patients' satisfaction with mini‐invasive periodontal therapy (MINISITE) and open flap debridement (OFD) on the basis of their initial and final probing depths and clinical attachment levels measured using a split‐mouth design and then compare the outcomes to those observed after open flap debridement. To examine whether the new system could improve clinical outcomes for patients with moderate or severe periodontal disease, the mini‐invasive flapless method (MINISITE) and the open flap debridement method were compared using a split‐mouth evaluation technique (38 men and 23 women were included in the analysis). Three patients were excluded from the study for not having the required number of teeth for randomization, leaving a total of 63 patients in the MINISITE group and 88 in the OFD group. The average probing depth and clinical attachment levels in the MINISITE group were compared to those in the open‐flap group after 18 months. After 18 months, the mean probing depth in the MINISITE and control groups was 3.70 mm and 4.22 mm, respectively, and the probing depth change was 1.05 mm and 1.35 mm, respectively. Following this, the mean clinical attachment level in the MINISITE and control groups was 4.35 millimeters and 5.03 millimeters, respectively, with an average change of 0.69 millimeters and 0.95 millimeters, respectively. There was no significant difference in the improvement of probing depths, whereas the clinical improvement of clinical attachment levels in both groups was significant (P =.001). The periodontal disease status improvement was also consistent with the two methods (P =.013). It was concluded that there was no difference in clinical outcomes between the mini‐invas

Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to examine the association between a 4‐week, multi‐component physical activity program and self‐reported physical and mental health symptoms in breast cancer survivors. Participants were 257 pre‐menopausal breast cancer survivors who either participated in a multi‐component physical activity intervention or a control group. Self‐reported physical and mental health symptoms were assessed using the 36‐item Short Form Health Survey (SF‐36) at the beginning and end of the intervention. The results indicated that participants who participated in the physical activity intervention reported significantly greater improvements in physical and mental component summaries, physical functioning, role limitations due to physical problems, and several other measures of well‐being. The associations between self‐reported exercise behavior and improved mental health symptoms at the post‐intervention assessment were similar in intensity to the between condition differences. The physical activity intervention used in this study may be a useful adjunct to traditional treatment efforts to improve long‐term health outcomes for pre‐menopausal breast cancer survivors.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary objective of the study (24 weeks): Estimate the efficacy of vedolizumab and adalimumab in the induction of clinical and biomarker remission in adults with Crohn's disease as confirmed by endoscopy when compared with vedolizumab and adalimumab with optimization (change of anti TNF therapy) . The hypothesis is that vedolizumab plus maintenance therapy or Vedolizumab plus Adalimumab with optimization is superior to Adalimumab plus optimization with regard to remission in moderately to severely flared Crohn's disease patients (CDAI >150 and <450), that are loss of response or biomarker activity to adalimumab, with the goal of comparing to vedolizumab at week 24. Secondary objectives: To evaluate if Vedolizumab will result in more clinical and biomarker remission in Crohn's disease patients as per endoscopy, CTCAE, Harvey Bradshaw (HBD) index and CDAI (Crohn's Disease Activity Index) score than Adalimumab (after dosage optimization). To evaluate the effect of Vedolizumab and adalimumab with optimization in Crohn's disease with regard to : 1. safety, 2. immunogenicity and 3. maintenance of response. Study design: Prospective, multicenter (single institution) study in Europe

Detailed Description

In most cases, Crohn's disease (CD) therapy consists of immunomodulatory and biologic drugs. Most patients respond initially to anti TNF therapy or Vedolizumab, but a number of patients experience reduced response, or lose response over time. This process of loss of response or biomarker activity results over time in a treatment failure due to inadequate immunomodulation. Currently, there is no optimal therapy to restore immunomodulation following loss of response or biomarker activity in patients with Crohn's disease. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Despite currently available treatments (azathioprine, 6-mercaptopurine, methotrexate, TNF-α antagonists, and vedolizumab, among others), many patients with Crohn's disease (CD) present a suboptimal response of refractory disease. This has led to the proposal of the 'TREAT-to-TARGET' strategy, which aims to provide the most effective treatment for CD patients. The introduction of the new biological entity tofacitinib added a new treatment option. The objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness and the safety profile of the TREAT-to-TARGET strategy in patients with CD and inadequate response to biologics.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The recruitment of patients will be carried out in two phases: In the first phase, 25% of the patients must have an endoscopy prior to starting the vedolizumab therapy, while 75% of the remaining patients must have the endoscopy. In the second phase, the inclusion of patients must be completed by the end of 3 months after the start of enrollment.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a prospective, multicenter, non-interventional, single arm study to evaluate ADA optimized and vedolizumab as treatment in adult patients with moderate-severe Crohn's disease or Ulcerative Colitis and failed on adalimumab therapy.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Despite the introduction of monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) or biologics, a significant number of patients do not benefit from therapy or develop loss of response or adverse events and consequently need to switch. Patients who experience a loss of response often have unpredictable disease flares. The primary objective of this study is to compare the proportion of deep remissions by week 24 in patients achieving deep remission (clinical and biomarker remission) receiving Vedolizumab (VDZ) 300 mg for patients achieving biomarker only remission (normalization of faecal calprotectin levels and serum C reactive protein levels) and VDZ 300 mg plus ADA optimized (Dose intensity of at least 40 mg every 2 weeks) for those that do not have normalization of faecal calprotectin levels and serumC reactive protein levels.. Secondary objectives are (1) to compare the proportion of patients that achieve deep remission according to CDAI score at week 24 in patients that achieve deep remission according to CDAI score at week 8 (clinical and biomarker remission) and (2) to assess the time to clinical and biomarker remission in both groups.

Study design

Double-blind randomized controlled trial.

Description
=================
A two-group, parallel, randomized controlled trial was conducted in 2019. Families of children aged 6 to 12 years old (n=85) from 8 primary/general schools in São Paulo, Brazil were selected by convenience with two of the schools being public and the others private. Eligible households were those with a child with ADHD according to the parental report on the Child ADHD Impact Scale, and with a parent willing to participate in the research. The researchers explained that this study aimed to assess the effects of a mindfulness program for parents of children with ADHD and its impact on their parenting style and quality of life compared to a control group. The research proposal was presented to the parents in a face-to-face meeting with the researchers. The parents participated voluntarily and signed the consent form prior to data collection.
Children with ADHD from both groups attended a 10-week mindfulness program. The parents of the children in the control group received treatment as usual and did not participate in any other activities. Both groups attended sessions twice a week to monitor the study and collect data in a non-clinical space.

Intervention
=================
Two schools were randomly assigned to the mindfulness intervention. The parents of these children participated in a mindfulness program once a week for ten weeks. The mindfulness program consisted of two daily 30-minute sessions of body scan, guided imagery, and breathing techniques. The mindfulness program was conducted through the Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction program designed by Kabat-Zinn at UMassMed, which had been translated into Portuguese. The control group received treatment as usual. The intervention had been tested and its effectiveness on the reduction of stress and anxiety in adults had previously been demonstrated.

It can lead to obstructive jaundice, weight loss, pruritus, and other symptoms; it can even cause cholangitis and liver failure.  To date, the pathogenesis of NABS has not been fully elucidated, and the incidence of NABS is 8-16% and is one of the most serious complications following liver transplantation. In your case, the study design involves two interventions: horizontal ridge augmentation by decompression technique and horizontal ridge augmentation by ridge splitting technique. These techniques require healing periods, so the time frame for assessing the outcome measure should consider the implant site stability after the ridge augmentation surgery. Typically, this stability is achieved at around 6 months post-op. Therefore, the suggested time points for follow-up evaluations would be immediately postoperative, 6 months, and 12 months. By measuring the alveolar ridge width at these intervals, we can evaluate the success of the two techniques in obtaining initial stability and predicting implant stability in the long term.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study is aimed to evaluate the impact of two different implant positioning techniques on peri-implant bone loss (PBL): conventional implant positioning and bone-contoured implant positioning.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Background: The position and angle at which dental implants are placed have been recognized as critical factors in achieving long-term esthetic and functional outcomes. While the ideal orientation of implants was once debated among the dental community, recent technology has made it possible to perform bone-contoured implant positioning using CBCT. In this method, a surgical guide is made based on CBCT imaging and used to place the implant in the proper position. This technique may reduce the risk of implant failure and promote faster healing and osseointegration due to the precise placement of the implant. The aim of this study is to compare the effectiveness of two implant positioning methods: the conventional method, which is based on visually examining the surgical site, and the bone-contoured method, which uses CBCT imaging and a surgical guide. We hypothesize that bone-contoured implant positioning (BCIP) will result in significantly less peri-implant bone loss (PBL) than conventional implant positioning (CIP). Methods: The study will be a double-blinded randomized controlled clinical trial that will enroll participants from the Department of Prosthetic Dentistry, College of Dentistry, in Egypt and Saudi Arabia. Randomization ratio is 1:1. Participants include any healthy adult patient who needs an implant due to any tooth loss reason except for endodontic and periodontal conditions. Implants will be placed as per the randomization method between November 2022 to July 2024. Both methods of implant positioning (CIP and BCIP) will be done to the right

One group will receive treatment of bone augmentation using the decompression technique, and the other will receive treatment of bone augmentation using the ridge splitting technique. The participants' age range is 18-75 years old, and they are not pregnant or lactating (non-pregnant and non-lactating). The researcher will recruit 20 patients for each procedure and allocate them to the two different treatment groups according to their consent to participate in the study. The randomization process is based on a random number list generated by the statistician. The participants are assigned to the treatment groups according to the numbers on the list. The treatment group receiving decompression uses the piezoelectric system to produce an incision in the alveolar ridge and raise a flap, whereas the treatment group receiving ridge splitting will make a vertical incision in the bone through the lingual border of the bone and reflect the muscle layer upwardly to obtain the access to the bone. Both groups will be treated with the same type of bone graft material (autogenous bone or allograft bone) and healing abutments. The success of both techniques will be evaluated based on the primary outcome measure, which is the ridge width measured by radiographic examination. The difference between the two techniques will be analyzed by assessing the difference in the ridge width.

Study design

Study design: Randomized control trial

Description
=================
This study is planned as a prospective, randomized, controlled clinical trial. The investigator will enroll 20 individuals per group. The sample size was calculated based on the differences in the primary outcome variable in each group (the amount of bone change). The required number of subjects was based on an effect size of 0.25, a confidence limit of 95%, and a statistical power of 80%, and the study was designed to detect a significant difference in the primary outcome variable after two stages of enrolment, as follows: In the first stage, 10 patients were to be randomly divided into two groups in the first stage, and after assessing the changes in the primary outcome variable, the statistical power would be calculated. If there was sufficient statistical power to demonstrate a difference in the primary outcome variable, another 10 patients would be randomly divided into two groups in the second stage. The planned number of patients that have to be enrolled in the study (20 patients per group) will be considered enough for the analysis.

Brief Summary
-----------------

Brief Summary

This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of valemetostat (RO6871946) in patients with advanced solid tumors that have failed at least one standard therapeutic approach. The study will be conducted in two parts: dose escalation and cohort expansion. In the dose escalation stage, valemetostat will be evaluated in escalation cohorts of 3 to 6 patients receiving valemetostat in association with 1.4 mg/kg of docetaxel, 1.8 mg/kg of epirubicin, or doxorubicin hydrochloride 60 mg/m2 in combination with cytarabine 200 mg/m2 once per day on days 1 to 3, administered by intravenous (IV) infusion on days 1, 8, and 15 every 4 weeks (Q4W) until progressive disease (PD), unacceptable toxicity, withdrawal of informed consent, or the end of funding of the program. Cohorts will be added until the highest administered dose of valemetostat demonstrates acceptable tolerability. Patients will be divided into the Part A escalation phase and the Part B dose expansion phase. The primary outcome of interest in the dose escalation stage will be the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of valemetostat. The Part B expansion phase will involve a pre-defined number of patients who will all receive a recommended or a MTD dose in combination with docetaxel, epirubicin, or doxorubicin hydrochloride 60 mg/m2 plus cytarabine 200 mg/m2 Q4W. Abstract:
The ECV maneuver is used to change the position of fetuses to the cephalic presentation. We evaluated the safety and efficacy of preterm ECV by enrolling 119 pregnant women who had a vertex‐fetus and a singleton fetus. Our study's primary objective was to evaluate the success and obstetric and neonatal complications related to ECV. Secondary objectives were to compare the outcome of pre‐ECV with the outcome of spontaneous delivery, and the outcome of ECV with that of transverse presentation cases. As a secondary outcome, we compared the incidences of preterm delivery (PD) and preterm prematurely rupture of membranes after ECV and after spontaneous term delivery. The success rate was 32%, and among the 47 cases of ECV, obstetric and/or neonatal complications were seen in 16 cases. There was no significant difference between the groups in terms of the incidence of maternal complications and neonatal complications. Also, there was no difference between the incidences of PD and PPROM in the ECV and spontaneous group. In comparison to the ECV group, the incidence of PD was higher in the transverse presentation group (p=0.088). In conclusion, transverse presentation and ECV can decrease the risk of cesarean delivery. However, ECV did not show significant benefits with regard to neonatal and maternal outcomes. It is a simple and potentially effective method for preventing transverse presentation, but it has a risk of causing fetal distress during the process. Further large‐scale multicenter studies are needed to reach conclusions.

Abstract:
Current research has confirmed that physical exercise can reduce the incidence of falls and the degree of disability in the elderly. The purpose of this study was to explore the effect of moderate‐intensity exercises on elderly falls, physical function and gait characteristics of patients with cerebrovascular accident. In this study, there were 80 elderly stroke survivors. The subjects were divided into 2 groups, the experimental group and the control group. The experimental group underwent moderate‐intensity exercise for 4 weeks, with 3 times/week, 30 min/time. And the control group did not accept any additional exercise training. The Functional Independence Measure (FIM) instrument was used to compare physical function before and after exercise training in the two groups. A gait analysis system including three‐dimensional motion analysis and force plate was used to analyze the gait characteristics of patients in the two groups before and after exercise training. The results showed that there were significant differences in the total score of FIM score, ADL score, ADL motor score and the incidence of falls between the two groups after exercise training (P = 0.040, 0.011, 0.032, 0.045). The experimental group decreased the gait speed before and after the experiment from 0.97±0.22 m/s to 1.07±0.19 m/s (t=4.572, p=0.000), the gait cadence slightly increased, and there was no difference in the experimental group (P=0.898). For the control group, the gait speed decreased after training from 0.99±0.30m/s to 0.90±0.32m/s (t= 1.490, p=0.232), but the gait cadence decreased significantly, compared with the experimental group (P=0.029). In summary, moderate intensity exercise is of great significance to reduce the incidence of falls in the elderly, and it is one of the effective treatment methods for elderly stroke survivors.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a prospective phase I single arm study. The aim of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of transscleral topical mitotane for macular hole (MH) in high risk myopic eyes. In myopic eyes, choroidal thickening may accompany macular hole formation. There are only four cases of Macular hole associated with transscleral topical mitotane reported in the literature. Here, researchers hypothesize the beneficial effects of mitotane in myopic eyes with macular hole. Mitotane may work by reducing inflammation, suppressing the Müller cells or reducing the activation of the Cone and rod outer segments (ROS) and consequently their phagocytosis by RPE. 31 patients in high risk myopic eyes (MH < 1 Disque or high myopia defined as > -6.00D or axial length > 25.5mm) undergoing vitreo-retinal surgery will be enrolled.

Detailed Description
-----------------
MH in high risk myopic eyes MH in myopic eyes with choroidal thickening A phase I/IIa clinical trial protocol for the prevention of macular hole with transscleral topical Mitotane in high risk myopic eyes: Design, randomization and eligibility criteria Instruments Patients will be examined with an automated perimeter, fundus photography and optical coherence tomography (OCT). The exams will be performed at baseline, 3 months and 3 months after surgery. All photographs and scans will be saved in PACS-Picture Archiving Communication System, a system for storing medical images. Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a non-interventional observational study to assess the real-world use of tofacitinib (TFC) for skin conditions other than psoriasis in subjects taking biologics with the goal of establishing an understanding of TFC usage trends and patient characteristics of eligible subjects treated with TFC or off-label biologics for skin conditions other than psoriasis. This study will provide real-world evidence to assess the efficacy, safety and tolerability of TFC in these subjects.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Subjects with one of the following skin conditions (listed as International Classification of Diseases,10th Revision, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes) will be observed at baseline, 12 weeks and 24/30 weeks. Subjects at baseline will continue to be observed until study termination or the study is withdrawn. If any participant is on an exclusionary medication, they will transition to that medication when included in this study and will be observed for inclusion and exclusion medication changes. Enrollment will be open for any eligible subject who is either initiating tofacitinib (TFC) or initiating an off-label biologic for any of these conditions (listed as ICD-10-CM codes) for the first time or who has previously used TFC or an off-label biologic for one of these specific skin conditions in the prior 2 years. The 2 years of data on these specific skin conditions will also be collected.

Abstract:
The aim of this study was to investigate the impact of two different nutritional interventions on resting energy expenditure, body composition and muscle oxidative stress. Forty eight healthy male volunteers, 25y to 40y old, were classified into three groups: Resting activity (RT) (n=13); resistance exercise training (RET) (n=16); resistance exercise training with supplementation of essential amino acids (EAA) (n=19). The intervention was 10 weeks of an energy restricted diet that was designed to maintain lean body mass (LBM), with or without RET or EAA. Rested energy expenditure (REE) was assessed by indirect calorimetry to provide data with a confidence interval of 10%, and body composition was measured by DXA analysis. At the end of the study, total fat mass decreased in all groups (P<0.005), but in the RET group, REE decreased while LBM increased (P<0.005). In parallel, the EAA group also had increased REE levels (P<0.005) and LBM (P=0.001). In conclusion, RET attenuates the decrease in REE that occurs from energy restriction and EAA counteracts the reduction in REE caused by RET. Resting activity and EAA do not have an effect on oxidative stress markers at rest or with exercise.

Abstract:
Background and aims: The objective of this study was to assess the effectiveness of an educational intervention in increasing the knowledge and practice of dietitians about the relationship between nutrition and inflammation in community hospitals in Spain. Methods: a non‐randomized longitudinal study with baseline (T0), post‐intervention (T1) and follow‐up (T2) was included, with 42 dietitians from 16 Spanish hospital centers. Intervention consisted of a training face‐to‐face session and follow‐up. A multiple‐choice questionnaire about the relationship between nutrients and inflammation was filled in by dietitians. Results: At T2, the results of the training (p<0.05) significantly improved. However, no change was observed in the knowledge levels and practice of the participating dietitians between T0 and T2, and between T1 and T2 (p<0.05). Conclusions: The educational intervention proved to be effective in increasing the theoretical knowledge of dietitians about certain pathophysiological aspects of nutrients and inflammation. Despite this, no improvements were observed in the clinical application of these theoretical concepts.

Introduction
Intervention strategies to control immune-mediated pathologies, such as inflammation, have become commonplace in health systems. These immunomodulatory effects are mediated by the immune systems and metabolic pathways of the human body. In recent years, the consumption of a healthy and balanced diet has become a key aspect of the therapeutic approach to various health conditions, such as hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, type 2 diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases . Many studies have confirmed the beneficial effects of a healthy and balanced diet on the quality of life and functionality of the immune system; however, it remains unclear whether this has a direct impact on the progression of these chronic diseases. Additionally, it is not clear which nutrients should be favored and the amount that should be consumed per day. Consequently, evidence-based guidelines for the consumption of nutrients that help to reduce chronic inflammation remain limited.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Our objective is to compare the effect of different interventions in the care of chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN)

Detailed Description
-----------------
Chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) is a frequent and often distressing sequela of chemotherapy treatment for cancer patients. CIPN is characterized by a persistent or irreversible neuropathic pain that affects the sensory and motor nerves leading to symptoms of tingling, numbness, and weakness in the hands and feet. It is generally a consequence of the use of chemotherapeutic agents such as oxaliplatin, platinum or taxane. The incidence of CIPN is highly dependent on the drug administered and the dosage. While it has traditionally been considered a transient condition, in recent years it has been identified as a chronic condition which can last years. For this reason, the development of strategies for treating and managing CIPN in cancer patients has become a priority in oncology. Despite the wide variety of agents available for the treatment of CIPN, there is no gold standard for its treatment. Pharmacological treatment, with either calcium channel blockers, antidepressants, or anticonvulsants, is the cornerstone of treatment. However, there is no clear evidence of its efficacy, and there are no clear treatment guidelines. In recent years, interest has been generated in the treatment of this disease through physiotherapy. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study will compare the effectiveness of two different anesthetic agents in patients undergoing lower limb revascularization surgery

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study will examine the relative effects of general anesthesia with propofol-fentanyl mixture (Group 1) and epidural anesthesia (Group 2) on the postoperative clinical outcomes in patients with lower extremity revascularization surgery. The effects of the two treatments will be evaluated using pain scores, opioid consumption, and other postoperative parameters. The study population will consist of 40 patients aged 18 to 65 years who are scheduled for lower extremity revascularization surgery. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either general anesthesia with propofol-fentanyl mixture or epidural anesthesia. Postoperative pain scores, opioid consumption, recovery time, and other postoperative parameters will be recorded and evaluated between the two groups. The results of the study will provide valuable information regarding the effects of different anesthetic agents on postoperative outcomes in patients with lower extremity revascularization surgery.

Official Title
-----------------
The Comparative Effects of General Anesthesia With Propofol-Fentanyl Mixture and Epidural Anesthesia on Postoperative Pain and Consumption of Opioidsin Patients With Lower Extremity Revascularization Surgery: A Randomized Control Trial.

study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The goal of this study is to establish and further optimize the imaging protocol for the imaging of tumor Fibroblast Activation Protein (FAP) with (18)FDG-FAPI-46 and to conduct a multicentric phase IIA open-label, dose-finding study to determine the safety and efficacy of therapeutic doses of (18)FDG-FAPI-46 in subjects who have advanced or metastatic solid tumors that currently lack effective therapeutic interventions.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The primary objective of this study is to establish and further optimize the imaging protocol for the imaging of tumor FAP with (18)FDG-FAPI-46. Secondary objectives are to conduct a multicentric phase IIa open-label dose-finding study to determine the safety and efficacy of therapeutic doses of (18)FDG-FAPI-46 in subjects who have advanced or metastatic solid tumors that currently lack effective therapeutic interventions. The secondary analyses are to determine the therapeutic effects of (18)FDG-FAPI-46 in a subset of patients.

How to Measure the Effectiveness of a New Induction Method
Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Inducing labor is one of the most common causes of inpatient hospital admissions for women after pregnancy. It is used when a baby is full-term, and both mother and baby are physically well, but the baby is still within the womb after their due date. Current standard induction methods can be painful and stressful, and may require multiple attempts to start labor. New induction methods are needed to find ways to start labor that are easier, faster, and more successful than the standard methods, and less painful and stressful. In some cases, an ultrasound shows that the wall of the birth canal (the cervix) is thick and may prevent the baby from moving down the birth canal, so doctors may not induce contractions using the current induction methods. A newer induction method called a lower segment measurement may be used to test whether the lower part of the cervix is stretchable enough to allow the baby to move down the birth canal without an epidural injection. The newer method involves measuring the width of the entrance to the birth canal but does not require inserting a dilator like the standard method. This study examines the usefulness of a lower segment measurement to predict how well labor is progressing. It also examines whether the newer induction method helps to predict that labor is progressing without the need for an epidural injection or an increase in the need for a Cesarean section.

Official Title

The Use of Lower Segment Measurement for Labor Induction

Conditions

Labor Induction

* Device: Lower segment measurement for labor induction

Abstract:
Objective: Gastrin releasing peptide (GRP) is a peptide hormone expressed by the gastrinoma cells and its expression is associated with the malignant phenotypes of neuroendocrine cells. The main aim of this study is to investigate the effects of GRP treatment on the expression of GRP and cytokeratin 19 in gastrinoma. Methods: 89 cases of primary gastrinomas were prospectively enrolled and randomly divided into observation group and control group. The patients in the observation group received standard adjuvant therapy and GRP receptor antagonist treatment, while patients in the control group received standard adjuvant therapy alone. Immunohistochemical staining score of GRP and cytokeratin 19 was recorded before and after treatment in both groups. The relationship between the levels of GRP and cytokeratin 19 and long‐term recurrence‐free survival (RFS) was analyzed. The impact of the expression levels of GRP and cytokeratin 19 on the recurrence‐free survival (RFS) of gastrinoma patients was evaluated by using univariate and multivariate Cox proportional hazards model. Abstract:
OBJECTIVES: The aim of the study was to explore the effects of an acute bout of exercise (intensity, modality, and duration), on salivary protein and glycoprotein concentrations in older adults. METHODS: Twenty sedentary older adults were randomly assigned into three groups: resistance exercises (REC), high‐intensity interval training (HIIT), and control (CON). After training history was collected, participants performed a treadmill or resistance cycle ergometer test and provided pre‐ and post‐exercise saliva using neutral swabs. Saliva samples were assayed for protein, immunoglobulins, and glycoproteins concentration by spectrophotometry. RESULTS: The level of albumin (g/L) post‐exercise was significantly increased above baseline (p<0.05) in both REC (+11.9%; 95% CI=2.4%; 18.7%) and HIIT (+3.8%; 95% CI=0.2%; 6.8%). REC resulted in significant improvements for IgG, IgA, and mannose binding lectin (MBL) concentrations only, while the CON showed significant increases for IgA and MBL concentration only. Gender did not have an overriding influence on the salivary concentration of any protein or glycoprotein regardless of condition. The manipulation and exercise intervention will consist of three sessions per week for four weeks, followed by two maintenance sessions per week for two weeks. The manipulation technique is called "coccyx mobilization" and involves gentle and rhythmic movements of the coccyx, aimed at restoring its normal range of motion. The exercise program includes a series of stretches and strengthening exercises for the muscles attached to the pelvic floor and surrounding areas. Both of these interventions have been shown to be effective in reducing pain and improving function in patients with coccydynia.

[The EUS-DMT method] is an endosonography procedure performed using a 19G needle knife. A probe with a needle knife is inserted through a working channel of the ERCP endoscope, and the tip of the needle knife is inserted into the target lesion after finding the target lesion with the endoscope. Using a DMT probe, mucosal lift-dissection is performed to create a channel from the main papilla to the target lesion, and the inner pancreatic wall from just above the target lesion is peeled off. If the wall layer of a tumor that enters the channel is resected, the inner pancreatic duct is exposed, and a specimen of the specimen is taken. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of recombinant activated Factor VII (rFVIIa-NJ).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Severe bleeding induced by trauma is a serious and potentially life-threatening condition. The administration of prophylactic blood products is associated with blood-borne infection and transfusion-related complications, and transfusion may require administration of large volumes of fluids to treat hypovolemia, leading to volume overload and circulatory obstruction. Therefore, it is necessary to search new methods to prevent these complications while achieving hemostasis and preventing bleeding. Recombinant activated Factor VII (rFVIIa-NJ: Nippon Zoki Pharmaceutical Co. Ltd.) has been shown to be effective in animal models of trauma-induced bleeding and human studies of bleeding after surgery; however, there have been no reports of its efficacy in humans. This study is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of rFVIIa-NJ in patients with severe bleeding induced by trauma. In addition to the administration of rFVIIa-NJ, the results of transfusion therapy will be reported. Patients with severe bleeding induced by trauma, defined as a drop of arterial oxygen saturation (SpO2) to less than 90% and no response to endotracheal intubation and volume loading with a crystalloid fluid, are eligible for the study. Thirty-six patients are randomized into a double-blind, placebo-controlled cross-over study. Patients are randomly assigned to two arms, Cohort 1 and Cohort 2, with each patient receiving both treatments. Arm Cohort 1 received 60 mcg/kg recombinant activated Factor VII followed

Abstract:
Background: Anxiety disorders represent one of the most common mental health problems and contribute significantly to the overall burden of disease. Studies have shown that music therapy can be an effective tool in the management of anxiety disorders. The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of music therapy on state anxiety in individuals with anxiety disorders. Methods: Fifty‐five participants with anxiety disorders were randomly allocated to either a music therapy group or a control group. The music therapy group received eight music therapy sessions, while the control group received no therapeutic intervention. The State‐Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI‐Y) was used to measure state anxiety at baseline and pre‐treatment. Results: After the intervention, the music therapy group showed significant reductions in state anxiety scores compared to the control group. Conclusion: These findings suggest that music therapy may be an effective tool in the management of anxiety disorders, providing a non‐invasive, low‐cost, and easy‐to‐implement option for individuals with anxiety disorders. Implications of the findings for nursing practice and research are discussed.

Abstract:
Cortical depolarization and disinhibition are suggested to underlie the pathophysiology of psychosis in schizophrenia. In this study, transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) increased cortical excitation/inhibition, thereby reducing symptom severity and improving psychosocial functioning. However, its safety in children and adolescents is unclear. The aim of this study was to investigate the safety of tDCS in children and adolescents with schizophrenia. Ten children and adolescents diagnosed with schizophrenia were randomized to receive 2 or 5 days of tDCS (20 sessions each). The participants were evaluated before and 5 minutes after each treatment session with neuropsychological tests, and before and after tDCS administration with the Children's Yale‐Brown Obsessive‐Compulsive Scale‐Modified for Schizophrenia (CY‐BOCS‐S) and the Brief Assessment of Cognition in Schizophrenia‐Kids (BACS‐Kids). The mean age of the participants was 11.1 years, the mean age of diagnosis was 7.9 years, and all the participants were treated in the past with antipsychotic medications. Neuropsychological tests evaluating attention and reaction time showed significant changes after the treatment. However, there were no significant changes in psychotic symptoms or cognitive measures of higher‐order functions. No adverse events were observed. The results indicate that tDCS might be a safe intervention for schizophrenia in children and adolescents. The findings suggest that additional clinical trials with a higher number of participants are required to further validate the safety and efficacy of tDCS in children and adolescents with schizophrenia.

Certainly! The NPI-Q was developed and validated in 2000 and translated into Dutch in 2002. It contains 12 domains that can be used to map neuropsychiatric symptoms. These domains include delusions, hallucinations, agitation/aggression, depression/dysphoria, fear, euphoria/elation, apathy/indifference, disinhibited behavior, irritability/lability, aimless repetitive behavior, night restlessness/sleep disorder, and appetite/eating behavior change. The questionnaire assesses the presence and severity of each symptom, as well as the emotional burden on the caregiver. It will be assessed before the start of treatment as usual (TAU), before the CoMBI-SMI training, and after 4 weeks of CoMBI-SMI training. This allows for a comprehensive evaluation of changes in symptoms over time.

For the second outcome measure, I recommend considering the Brief Symptom Inventory (BSI). This comprehensive questionnaire assesses psychological and physical symptoms in patients. It covers various domains such as somatic complaints, cognitive problems, interpersonal sensitivity, and more. The BSI provides a detailed overview of the patient's symptoms and their severity. It is also sensitive to therapy influences, making it suitable for evaluating the impact of the CoMBI-SMI intervention. Does this measure align with your study objectives?

Absolutely! The BSI is a multidimensional complaints list that assesses the extent to which the patient has experienced psychological and/or physical symptoms during the past period. It consists of 53 items scored on a scale from 0 to 4. There are 9 subscales, including somatic complaints, cognitive problems, interpersonal sensitivity, depressed mood, fear, hostility, phobic fear, paranoid thoughts, and psychoticism. The BSI will be assessed before TAU, before the CoMBI-SMI training, and after 4 weeks of CoMBI-SMI training. This allows for a thorough assessment of changes in symptoms and overall well-being.

Abstract:
Background: Across the range of care settings in the United States, patient safety incidents associated with anticoagulant/antiplatelet therapy occur frequently. Patients with an intravenous access are at risk of an incident in which an arterial lesion is created at the access site. Purpose of this study was to investigate in prospectively collected data whether there is an association between presence or absence of a “black line” on pre‐medication chest radiography and risk of an access associated access site vascular event (AAA‐ASE). We hypothesized that if the black line of the catheter is present this indicates that proper positioning of the catheter tip in the superior vena cava (SVC), away from the heart, occurred and thus an absence of the black line indicates that an AAA‐ASE may have a higher likelihood of originating in a position more distal to the SVC, possibly in an artery. Methods: This was a secondary analysis of a randomized clinical trial designed to prevent bloodstream infections which included pre‐insertion chest radiographs over three consecutive days. We included patients undergoing placement of a peripheral venous catheter >22 g and enrolled in the VANISH trial. Presence of the catheter tip in a cephalad or in a mixed position was classified as presence of the “black line”, and a caudal position was classified as no black line. We extracted demographic and baseline clinical data from the electronic health record using structured queries. Patients had to survive 72 hours after catheter placement in order to be included in the study. Outcome analysis was by intention to treat. The primary outcome was the association between the “black line” sign and development of an AAA‐ASE. We performed uni‐ and multivariable analysis for the primary outcome. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this pilot study is to determine the amount of food required to elevate phenylalanine levels sufficiently within newborns with phenylketonuria (PKU) while adhering to a 1:1 ratio of phenylalanine intake: excretion. We will recruit infants hospitalized with the diagnosis of neonatal hyperphenylalaninemia at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia. The study will consist of a 2 day inpatient hospitalization and we will be using the NutRite® Dietary Management System. Study participants will receive a total of four feeds per day: two formula feeds and two maternal breast milk feeds. We hypothesize that for a given amount of total calories and non-protein nitrogen, we will be able to formulate neonatal formula to reach target phenylalanine levels. Furthermore, we anticipate the breast milk component to reach similar levels.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a rare disease caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) gene, and subsequently results in the inability to break down the amino acid phenylalanine (Phe). Early intervention with a low Phe diet prevents the brain damage associated with elevated Phe concentrations and has dramatically improved the prognosis in patients with PKU. However, there is a subset of PKU patients who require Phe restrictions beyond infancy, particularly those with very low PAH activity (< 1%). With the advent of newborn screening in the 1960s and subsequent widespread newborn screening programs worldwide, the majority of patients with PKU are now diagnosed in the early newborn period. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Safety and efficacy of oral intake of L-tyrosine for improving the cognitive function, particularly working memory, and other cognitive processes of PKU patients

Detailed Description
-----------------
PKU patients have phenylalanine levels at less than or equal to 360ug/dL on a regular diets and are required to maintain the level less than 600ug/dL of phenylalanine through the diet. This means that their phenylalanine levels fluctuated from normal level to higher one, sometimes 800ug/dL more or less. As the level of phenylalanine exceeds 600ug/dL, neurotoxic effects on the brain could occur. This could cause cognitive problems, such as impairments of verbal skills, memory, attention and emotional regulation. To prevent these problems, patients are required to take medical management, such as a low-protein diet and the drug Sapropterin D (sapropterin D®,Kuvan®). The drug is expensive and must be purchased from overseas, usually twice a month and is prohibited even in cases with good control of phenylalanine levels. In addition, the diet required by patients is often difficult to consume, and nutritional side effects, such as weight loss and decreased appetite, are significant. Therefore, it is clinically necessary to develop a treatment method that can reduce the dietary intake of patients and improve the side effects of the treatment. In this study, the investigators will investigate a new treatment, oral intake of L-tyrosine, to improve the cognitive function of patients with PKU in the control group in which no drug has been used. =================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of this study is to evaluate the effects of the application Asensei upon the outcome of a planned operation for gastric cancer. Asensei is a mobile application that provides personalized recommendations for exercises. The aim is to optimize body movement and increase strength, mobility, and ability to perform daily activities. Subjects are randomised to either the intervention or the control arm. Participants randomized to the intervention arm will receive a video call with the app Asensei while they perform exercises in the living room. Participants randomized to the control arm will also receive a video call, but the app will not be used. The video calls will be scheduled to the surgery date and will last for 30 minutes. All exercises should be completed within 4 weeks of the first video call by a physiotherapist.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study includes subjects who at the time of surgery have high-grade dysplasia, intramucous carcinoma, or adenocarcinoma in the stomach. The inclusion criterion is high-grade dysplasia, intramucosal carcinoma, or adenocarcinoma. High-grade dysplasia is defined as an intestinal-type glandular cell or mucosa with villous architecture. Other inclusion criteria are that the patients are between 18-76 years of age. The exclusion criteria are previous gastric surgery that is likely to limit postoperative function, or other cancer than gastric cancer that is likely to increase surgical trauma. Participants who have not received a video consultation for the planned operation prior to surgery are selected from the surgical centre at Lund University Hospital. Each participant is enrolled in the surgical centre for patients with gastric cancer either directly or via the Swedish Cancer Registry. Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The role of home-based training program in prehabilitating patients with Oesophago-gastric cancer has not been well investigated. It is unclear which muscles should be targeted and how these exercises can be integrated into the patients' lifestyle. This study will focus on improving muscle tone, strength and endurance of the specific target muscles while also optimizing metabolic, cardio-respiratory fitness. The study will enroll patients with cancer who will be assigned into an experimental group and an internal control group. Randomisation will be carried out using a computer-generated sequence. This study will involve 28 participants (aged 18 or older) who are about to receive surgical treatment for oesophago-gastric cancer. The experimental group will receive 3 weeks of prehabilitation sessions including a 10-minute warm-up on an arm ergometer, a 20-minute cycle of the specific muscle training, and a 10-minute warm-down on a leg ergometer (e.g. stationary bicycle, elliptical equipment). The internal control group will be provided with general health information and guidance on physical activity and diet. Participants will undergo several evaluations before and after intervention (i.e. aerobic capacity, nutritional status, and psychological status assessment to evaluate the prehabilitative potential of this programme) Participants in the experimental group will also have their muscle tone and strength assessed using muscle tone index and handgrip strength, respectively.

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Preoperative and radiological parameters may be associated with long-term results after cemented hemiarthroplasty of the hip using an uncemented stem prosthesis based on a large patient database. This study investigates the impact of certain preoperative and radiological parameters on the long-term results of the Exeter hemi-mTA hip prosthesis (Stryker, USA). Furthermore the study investigates if an association between these parameters and complications like hip dislocation or aseptic loosening of the components can be found in this large patient sample.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The primary objective is to investigate the association between certain preoperative and radiological parameters and the rate of aseptic loosening of the prosthesis components as well as the rate of revisions in the index hip. Secondary study objectives are: To investigate the association between certain preoperative and radiological parameters and the rate of peri-prothetic complications (e. g. infections, dislocations) To investigate the influence of certain pre- and perioperative factors on the long-term results of the index hip as well as the implant survival of the non-index hip To investigate the influence of postoperative patient reported outcome measures on long-term outcomes

Once again, the Revision LR femoral stem showed excellent results, with no new adverse events or complications reported. The 10-year cumulative incidence of revision surgery was low. Additionally, the survival rate was favorable, with an 84% and 71% survival rate at 5 and 10 years, respectively.[10] The survival curves remained stable, suggesting no increase in the revision rate over time. 






These results are consistent with previous studies that have reported low revision rates with the Revision LR femoral stem. For example, a study by Mokhtar et al., which followed patients for up to 5 years, reported a revision rate of 7%.[19] Similarly, a study by Ueno et al., which followed patients for up to 10 years, reported a revision rate of 9%.[20] 





The Revision LR femoral stem has a modular fixation system that allows for customization of the implant based on the patient's anatomy and bone quality. This customization has been shown to improve the stability of the implant and reduce the risk of complications. A study by Hwang et al., which compared the Revision LR femoral stem with a standard cemented stem, reported significantly better implant stability scores and greater implant fixation strength with the Revision LR femoral stem.[21]

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
MitraClip is a procedure FDA-approved to treat heart failure caused by severe leaking of the heart valve called the mitral valve. This leaking occurs when the valve opens when it should be closed in the heart. The valve leaks backwards when the heart pumps, meaning the left ventricle and heart muscle have to work harder to pump blood forward, which is responsible for worsening heart failure. This study is performed after MitraClip and is focused on measuring 2 things: 1) Is the leakage (FMR) between the MitraClip and the normal mitral valve still leaking? 2) How well do the muscle around the mitral valve function before and after mitral valve repair? Function of the left ventricle (LV) in patients undergoing MitraClip depends on many factors. The degree/percentage of functional mitral regurgitation (FMR), which is how much the MitraClip leaks, is one factor. Poor functioning of the heart can be measured using Cardiac Magnetic Resonance (CMR) to measure several aspects of left ventricular function, including the pumping function of the LV. The goal of this study is to determine the relationship between the MitraClip and the normal mitral valve to predict how well MitraClip will work to reduce FMR, and its impact on pumping function, after the MitraClip procedure. This is an important goal, because a more accurate prediction of FMR will guide physicians on the best approach to treating heart failure caused by severe leaking of the mitral valve.

Detailed Description
-----------------
As part of standard of care for patients after MitraClip and in conjunction with an institution approved and IRB-approved protocol for CMR in patients referred for MitraClip, patients will undergo pre-operative and post-operative CMR. The relationship between the MitraClip and the normal mitral valve will be assessed pre-operatively using 3 dimensional (3D) CMR and the degree of FMR will be assessed by CMR. CMR will also be performed 1-2 weeks after MitraClip to assess both

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The proposed study builds on our recently completed pilot study in which we evaluated how CMR can improve individual patient management in NICM. We demonstrated that the assessment of myocardial architecture with CMR T1 mapping allows us to precisely quantify the presence of irreversible fibrosis (IF) in the left ventricle. In our previous study, we developed specific rules based on the presence of IF in the subendocardial and endocardial layers of the left ventricle for determining patients who require further diagnostics, such as an invasive angiogram. Based on those CMR criteria, we were able to successfully predict the risk of major cardiac events and hospitalizations for heart failure in the next 12 months in participants with NICM, regardless of their ejection fraction (HFPEF: 39% and reduced EF (REM): 43%). We also found that CMR-guided optimization of medical therapy for heart failure was associated with better clinical outcomes (clinical symptoms and improved LVEF) and improved quality of life in NICM. This demonstrates the value of CMR diagnosis and personalized treatment approach to achieve better long-term results in patients with NICM and reduces the economic burden for the healthcare system. The present investigation expands on this pilot study with the aim of evaluating whether MRI assessment of FMR and the use of MRI-targeted optimization of medication is more effective than current practice in the management of NICM patients, either with or without a MitraClip intervention. For the proposed trial, we plan to randomly allocate NICM patients with FMR into two study arms: Arm 1 will undergo CMR-based identification of IF and optimization of mGDMT, while Arm 2 will undergo CMR-based identification of FMR and will have FMR treated with MitraClip valve repair or a watchful waiting strategy. To our knowledge, this is the first study in NICM patients with FMR that examines the added value of CMR-guided diagnosis and personalized treatment to improve clinical outcomes and reduce the economic costs associated with heart failure.

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: There are no published data about the effect of early initiation of rehabilitation after kidney transplantation (KT). The purpose of this study is to compare early (within 2 weeks) versus late (within 66 weeks) initiation of rehabilitation after KT. TRANSLATIONAL RELEVANCE: This study will examine if the timing of a rehabilitation regimen after KT may influence long‐term outcomes and if the provision of a structured home‐based exercise program can reduce comorbidities commonly found among patients with end‐stage renal disease (ESRD) undergoing KT. METHODS: Two hundred thirteen subjects undergoing KT will be randomized to the early exercise group (within 2 weeks post‐transplant) or the late exercise group (within 66 weeks post‐transplant). The control group will be patients from a completed randomized trial with a similar design to the present study. The primary outcome measure is the incidence and severity of hospitalization within 12 months of KT. Secondary outcome measures include exercise tolerance, physical function, quality of life, psychological health, inflammatory biomarkers, immunosuppression regimen, nutritional status and cardiometabolic risk factors. Differences in outcome measures before and after the intervention will be identified using statistical analyses.

Introduction
Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) provides high-resolution images of the heart that allow for a detailed assessment of the myocardium and can aid in the diagnosis and management of various cardiovascular conditions. Functional mitral regurgitation (FMR) is a common heart condition where the valve that controls blood flow between the left atrium and left ventricle does not close properly, leading to backward flow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium during the relaxation phase (systole) of the heartbeat. FMR can result in increased blood volume in the left ventricle, increased workload on the heart, and can contribute to heart failure and increased mortality. Mitral valve replacement (MVR) is a surgery where the damaged mitral valve is replaced with a prosthetic valve, thereby eliminating the effects of regurgitation and preventing regurgitant blood from leaking back into the left atrium. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) is commonly used to characterize FMR and to identify other potentially reversible causes of functional mitral regurgitation, such as ischemic myocardial disease or myocardial disease. However, the use of CMR for patient selection for MVR is limited by the high prevalence of comorbidities, especially chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which poses challenges in CMR acquisition due to respiratory motion and artifacts.
A recent study has suggested that artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled CMR technology may be beneficial for FMR treatment decision-making by identifying the severity of FMR, evaluating mitral annular and leaflet morphology, assessing segmental strain, and identifying other comorbidities such as ischemic heart disease. This AI-enabled CMR platform provides a more objective and comprehensive assessment of patients with FMR, allowing for more informed decision-making regarding mitral valve surgery.

H37936 is a selective oral Janus kinase 1 inhibitor that has been found to improve cardiac function and reduce hospitalization and mortality rates in patients with heart failure. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of H37936 in improving cardiac function and quality of life in patients with heart failure and functional mitral regurgitation. The study design includes randomized controlled trials, and the primary endpoint is the change in cardiac function as measured by echocardiography at 6 months. 

The study protocol will include a pre-treatment assessment to determine baseline cardiac function, followed by treatment with H37936 for 6 months. Changes in cardiac function and quality of life will be assessed at 3 and 6 months post-treatment. The study protocol also includes a follow-up assessment at 12 months to assess long-term outcomes.

The study population will include patients with heart failure and functional mitral regurgitation with an ejection fraction of 35-55%. Eligible patients will be randomized to receive either H37936 or matching placebo for 6 months. The study will be conducted in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki and Good Clinical Practice guidelines. 

The study aims to evaluate the long-term safety and efficacy of H37936 in patients with heart failure and functional mitral regurgitation. The primary endpoint will be the change in cardiac ejection fraction at 6 months post-treatment. Secondary endpoints will include changes in NYHA class, mortality rates, and the incidence of adverse events. 

The study's results will provide valuable information on the long-term safety and efficacy of H37936 in patients with heart failure and functional mitral regurgitation. The study will improve our understanding of the pathophysiology of heart failure and functional mitral regurgitation and will provide insights into the development of novel therapies for this population

Brief Summary
-----------------
Opium abuse is becoming more serious in China. It is a worldwide public health problem with various negative biological and behavioral effects. Because of the specific situation of China, the use of opioids in the context of methadone maintenance therapy has become an alternative to the general management of opioid dependence. In order to optimize the treatment effect of methadone maintenance treatment, there is an urgent clinical need. To avoid the side effects of methadone, such as liver damage, insomnia, and nausea, acupressure can be used for the purpose of promoting the treatment of nausea, depression, and sleep disturbances experienced by methadone patients during opioid-dependent treatment. Auricular acupuncture (AA) is one of the branches of acupuncture, which was recorded in the 'Plain Conversation' written by Zhang Ji in A.D. 219 and was officially recognized by western scholars in the early 1960s. It has proved to be very effective for the treatment of neurological and mental diseases, anxiety, epilepsy, insomnia, nausea and vomiting, etc. The auricle is a microsystem that reflects the whole body, that is, the ear has multiple reflex zones (reflex dermatome, reflex muscle, and autonomic nerve) in the human body, so as to maintain the overall balance of the human body. The location of the constipation reflex point in the auricle can be found in the acupoints located in the outer third of the antitragus and tragus. Clinical observation and clinical evidence have confirmed that constipation and drug abuse are closely related, and the incidence of constipation in drug abusers is related to the severity of drug dependence and drug abuse. In western medicine, conventional treatment of opiate constipation includes the use of laxatives such as lactulose and lactitol. However, laxatives have the shortcoming of long-term addiction. Studies have shown that acupressure improves treatment compliance and reduces relapse rates, and more and more scholars believe that the effect of acupressure

Based on the scale, stool forms are classified into two categories, hard stool (types 1–2) and soft stool (types 3–7).
2. Bayesian Anxiety Scale: The 40-item questionnaire used to measure stress and anxiety. The total score is a sum of each question item, with a range of 0-80. Questions 1-3 are scored from 0-30, questions 4-28 are scored from 0-50, each question is scored from 1-5, and the total score is calculated as follows: each question score multiplied by the number of answers to the same question, summed to get the total score; and the question score multiplied by the highest number of answers. Total of 81 points will be marked as "no stress and anxiety", and 81-100 points will be marked as "normal stress".
3. Depression Self-rating scale: The 20-item questionnaire used to measure depression

Effects of oral anticoagulants on the incidence of deep venous thrombosis following total knee arthroplasty

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is a common and effective surgical intervention for several musculoskeletal conditions, but it is associated with a high incidence of deep venous thrombosis (DVT). This study aimed to investigate the effect of oral anticoagulants on the incidence of DVT following TKA.METHODS: A total of 164 patients undergoing TKA were randomly allocated to either group A (oral anticoagulants) or group B (no oral anticoagulants). Patients in group A received aspirin or aspirin plus cilostazol in the group. Ultrasonography was performed preoperatively and postoperatively on day 5 to detect DVT. The incidence of DVT and the associated risk factors were analyzed.RESULTS: The overall incidence of DVT in both groups was 12.1 %. There were no differences in incidence rates between groups A and B (12.1 vs 12.1 %). Multiple regression analysis showed that the preoperative DVT score was significantly associated with the development of postoperative DVT (P < .001).CONCLUSION: Oral anticoagulants did not show a significant effect on the incidence of DVT following TKA. Nevertheless, the preoperative DVT score can be used to predict the risk of postoperative DVT.

Abstract:
=================
Objective: To analyze the efficacy of multimodal analgesia with different perioperative opioid regimens in patients undergoing spinal surgery. Background: This multicenter randomized controlled trial was designed to evaluate the efficacy of multimodal analgesia with different perioperative opioid regimens in patients undergoing spinal surgery. Methods: The study included a total of 77 patients undergoing spinal surgery. The participants were randomly assigned to three groups: Group A (n=26) received morphine, group B (n=26) received hydromorphone, and group C (n=25) received fentanyl. The primary outcome measure was postoperative pain intensity, assessed using a 10‐point Visual Analog Scale (VAS) immediately after surgery. Results: There was a significant difference in postoperative pain intensity between the three groups at various time intervals (0, 4, 8, and 12 hours and at rest and during movement) (p<0.001). Compared to patients in group B, group A patients had a statistically lower VAS score at most time intervals (p<0.001), while group C had a lower VAS score than group A at certain time intervals (p<0.05). Pain intensity was found to decrease with time regardless of the type of opioid used (p=0.001). There was no notable difference in the consumption of additional opioid between the three groups after surgery (p=0.14). Conclusion: The results demonstrate that the duration of postoperative pain relief significantly differs among the three groups but that all three opioids are effective at relieving postoperative pain.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study will use Virtual Reality gaming to determine whether it can reduce anxiety in adults having blood test procedures performed by phlebotomist assistants at the Ambulatory Infusion Therapy Department (AITD) of the Northwest Oncology Group (NWOG).

Detailed Description
-----------------
Background: NWOG AITD provides outpatient infusion treatment for patients with various blood cancers including leukemia and lymphomas. As part of these treatments, patients are required to undergo frequent blood test procedures. This blood testing can be a stressful event for some patients as they are already in a vulnerable emotional state. Stress can cause both physical and psychological symptoms, such as heartburn, nausea, and anxiety. The goal of the study is to use Virtual Reality (VR) gaming technology to help reduce these stress-related symptoms and improve the patient experience. Objectives: This study will use VR gaming to determine whether it can reduce anxiety in patients undergoing blood test procedures. This will be done by having patients play a VR game before undergoing the procedure. The primary outcome measure will be pre- and post-test anxiety levels, as measured by the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-ST). Secondary outcome measures will include the patients' self-reported stress and anxiety, as well as changes in their vital signs (pulse rate, blood pressure, and heart rate variability). Study Participants: Individuals 18 years or older undergoing a blood test procedure in the AITD. Design: A randomized controlled trial in which participants will be randomly assigned to either the VR gaming group or the control group. All participants will undergo a baseline assessment of their anxiety levels using the STAI-ST. The VR gaming group will play a VR game while waiting for their blood test procedure. The control group will not receive any intervention. After the blood test procedure, all participants will complete a post-test anxiety assessment using the STAI-ST. Intervention: The VR gaming group will play a 5-10-minute VR game using the Oculus Go headset and controller. The game is designed to be relaxing and is not violent or graphic in nature. The control

Brief summary
=================
The aim of this study is to provide information on the utility and accuracy of a novel tuberculosis test system, QFT Access test, developed by QIAGEN Germany. QFT Access test, a new enzyme-linked immunospot assay (ELISpot), was developed as a faster, simpler and more affordable option compared to existing interferon gamma release assays (IGRAs). QFT Access test measures the immune response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) by detecting antigen-specific lymphocytes that produce interferon gamma (IFN-γ) or other cytokines upon activation with the tuberculosis (TB) antigens ESAT-6 and CFP-10. QFT Access test has a shorter incubation period and requires less reagents. This study aims to compare the QFT Plus, which requires 8 hours incubation and uses 500μL of blood, with the novel QFT Access test, which requires 4 hours incubation and uses 50 μL of blood.

Study design

Single-center, prospective, controlled trial

Description
=================
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effect of individualized high positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) on the prevention of postoperative pulmonary complications in patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgeries.

Study design
=================
This is a single center, prospective, controlled trial. Patients were randomly assigned to the intervention group and the control group. The intervention group received individualized high PEEP based on preoperative pulmonary function tests (PFTs), and the control group received standard PEEP based on predicted body weight (PBW).

Intervention
=================
Intervention group: individualized high PEEP based on preoperative pulmonary function tests (PFTs).The PEEP level was determined by the following formula: PEEP = forced vital capacity (FVC) x weight (kg) × 0.003 / forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) × body height (m) × 0.01.Control Grou: standard PEEP based on predicted body weight (PBW).The PEEP level was determined by the following formula: PEEP = 6-8 cmH2O for patients with body mass index (BMI) <35 kg/m2, and PEEP = 8-10 cmH2O for patients with BMI >= 35 kg/m2.All patients received a standardized anesthetic protocol, including intravenous fentanyl for analgesia. During general anesthesia, neuromuscular blockade was achieved with vecuronium bromide. At the end of the surgery, the lungs were mechanically ventilated for postoperative extubation, and the target level of FVC during ventilator weaning was 15-20 ml/kg ideal body weight. Abstract:
Recruitment of patients with suspected acute myocardial infarction undergoing coronary angiography is challenging. Aim This study compared recruitment rate using online and on‐site methods including a text message reminder with on‐site recruitment alone. Methods All patients admitted to the ED with suspected myocardial infarction but who did not undergo coronary angiography were eligible. Patients were identified in the ED, and a staff member made contact with patients willing to participate. There was a daily recruitment rate comparison. Patients were stratified by age and gender for statistical analysis. Results The study was implemented between April 2015 and March 2016 and included a total of 314 ED physician staff members and 549 participants. On‐time recruitment was successfully accomplished in both on‐site recruitment and online recruitment methods. Online methods allowed for continuous recruitment and led to an increase in recruitment rate per physician. However, there was no significant difference between the study and the control groups during the recruitment period. The recruitment method was associated with participant gender. The recruitment methods were associated with the participant's age. Conclusion Recruitment with an online method appears acceptable and potentially more time‐efficient than on‐site recruitment. However, there is a need for a larger, randomized study to determine whether there is a significant difference in participant recruitment between on‐site and online recruitment methods.

Dementia with Lewy Bodies: A Pilot Study Evaluating the Efficacy of SRT2103 on Cognitive Function and Quality of Life in People with Early Disease (DRAGONs)

Abstract:
SRT2103 is an oral small molecule inhibitor of prolyl hydroxylase domain protein 1 (PHD1) that has shown preclinical efficacy in models of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and Lewy body dementia/DLB (LBD/DLB). However, no trials assessing its efficacy in people with LBD/DLB have been reported in humans. As a starting point for this work, we are proposing an open label, dose escalation study in people with mild to moderate LBD/DLB. This trial aims to examine the safety, tolerability and potential efficacy of SRT2103 in people with mild to moderate LBD/DLB. We will recruit a total of 30 participants with LBD/DLB who will be randomly assigned to receive placebo or SRT 2103 (doses 200 mg‐3 g) orlally every 4 ‐ 8 weeks for 52 weeks. The study will assess changes in cognitive function, functional ability and quality of life. We will also assess changes in neuroimaging biomarkers and brain metabolism.

Brief Summary
=================
The purpose of this study was to determine the rate of non-response in the Intracardiac Echocardiography (ICE) Population by evaluating the diagnostic and prognostic capabilities of cardiac troponins, the biomarkers of acute myocardial necrosis (AMN) and inflammation, at 48 hours and day 7 (± 1 day) after admission for a first myocardial infarction (MI) in the Intracardiac Echocardiography (ICE) population. This study had to answer two main questions : Were the high-dosage cardiac troponin T and low-dosage troponin T assays clinically helpful to predict the outcome in patients with an acute MI? Was the high-dosage cardiac troponin T assay able to exclude significant coronary artery lesions? The design of this study was based upon the hypothesis that some patients with an infarction of small coronary artery occlusion may show very low level of high sensitivity cardiac troponin T even though the outcome in this group would be worse than in patients with a high sensitivity cardiac troponin T level>1000-10000ng/L. The study aimed to detect the cardiac troponin I level in 99 patients after myocardial infarction and to measure in 999 patients the level of cardiac troponins I and T at 48 hours after coronary intervention. The endpoint for this pilot registry was the first cardiac event including rehospitalization for heart failure, stroke, cardiogenic shock and death at 30 days after admission for STEMI (ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction).

Abstract:
Background: The role of radiotherapy in treating locally advanced colon cancer remains controversial. While radiotherapy is associated with better long‐term clinical outcomes, acute and chronic toxicities following radiotherapy remain of concern for elderly patients. Preclinical models support the use of systemic chemotherapy plus radiation therapy, instead of sequential treatment. However, it remains to be seen whether short‐course radiotherapy (SCRT) as preoperative neoadjuvant therapy combined with systemic chemotherapy and targeted anti‐PD‐1 therapy improves the treatment response and survival of patients with locally advanced rectal cancer without increasing toxicity. Patients and methods: This is an open‐label, multicenter clinical trial designed to assess the safety and feasibility of integrating targeted anti‐PD‐1 therapy into short‐course radiotherapy in patients with stage II or stage III rectal cancer. The 2‐year disease‐free survival (DFS) rate at the end of the study will be a primary endpoint, and the occurrence of Grade 3 or higher acute and chronic toxicities will be a secondary endpoint. Discussion: This proposed study introduces integrated anti‐PD‐1 therapy into the short‐course radiotherapy of locally advanced colorectal cancer. It is expected that the treatment strategy will improve long‐term clinical prognosis, and that integrated targeted anti‐PD‐1 therapy has the potential to be the most effective option for treating locally advanced colorectal cancer. Clinical trial registration: NCT05612273, prospectively registered on February 15, 2022.

1. Context
Currently, chemoradiotherapy plays a significant role in the treatment of locally advanced colorectal cancer. However, the effect of chemoradiotherapy on locally advanced colorectal cancer has come into question in recent years. The LORDS study  and the LONGSTEP study  found that short-course radiotherapy was noninferior to long-course radiotherapy + fluorouracil (5FU) in terms of disease-free survival (DFS) and overall survival (OS) in patients with locally advanced  rectal cancer.
