Abstract:
This research focuses on an online education program for students with visual impairments and blindness. This article reports on the initial 8 weeks of the study, including evaluation of the online technology to improve accessibility for the targeted population, the design and functionality of the course, and early data regarding student outcomes. Forty‐four students with visual impairments and blindness at two universities in the United States were enrolled in classes and randomly assigned to treatment and control groups. Participants in the treatment group were exposed to two semester credits of online information technology training. These participants provided data that allowed early evaluation of the accessibility and functionality of the online course. As a baseline, the majority of the students reported having little or no prior experience with computer‐based information technology. In addition, many students reported having low‐bandwidth access to the Internet and/or insufficient computer and software skills; these students were less likely to complete survey measures on course accessibility and functionality. Among those who reported having some proficiency with computers and software, overall acceptance of the program was high with 81 percent of students responding that they would recommend the program to others. The most important program strengths were the opportunity to take the course for college credit and to access course content 24/7 without being affected by travel to campus. Additional research is needed to further examine program impact on academic performance and career development.

Primary Outcome Measure:

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- R0 resection rate: Complete removal of the tumor in the operation with microscopically negative margins. Evaluated after surgery, an average of 4 weeks.
- 3-year overall survival rate: Rate of overall survival for 3 years. Assessed from randomization until the date of death from any cause, up to 3 years.
- 3-year disease-free survival rate: Rate of disease-free survival for 3 years. Assessed from randomization until the date of first documented progression or death from any cause, up to 3 years.
- Grade 3-4 adverse effects rate: Rate of severe adverse events related to chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and immunotherapy. Assessed from randomization until death from any cause, up to 5 years.
- 3-year local recurrence-free survival rate: Rate of local recurrence-free survival for 3 years. Assessed from randomization until the date of first documented local-regional failure, up to 3 years.
- Surgical complications: Rate of surgical complications, such as intraoperative hemorrhage, anastomotic leakage, intestinal obstruction, etc. Assessed up to 5 years from the surgery.

Abstract:
The European Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy issued guidelines with recommendations supporting the use of insulin titration for diabetes management during colonoscopy and ERCP. This study aimed to develop a peri‐intervention diabetes management algorithm (DIAPI) that would guide glycemic management in a prospective and objective manner. The DIAPI algorithm was developed using a systematic approach with the involvement of multidisciplinary stakeholders from various healthcare disciplines. The algorithm follows a stepwise approach and incorporates the following key steps: screening for patients with diabetes, performing a medical check, evaluating patients' glycemic status, providing insulin titration recommendations based on a decision tree, monitoring patients' glycemic status during the peri‐intervention period, and assessing the efficacy of the algorithm. DIAPI is currently undergoing pilot testing in a clinical trial to evaluate its effectiveness and provide feedback for improvement. By automating glycemic monitoring, reducing human error, and ensuring consistency and accuracy, DIAPI has the potential to improve patient outcomes, reduce the risk of complications, and ensure optimal patient safety during interventional endoscopic procedures.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this clinical trial is to evaluate the clinical efficacy of a non-invasive, low-frequency (LF) ultrasound vibration therapy (UVT) combined with low-level laser therapy (LLLT), known as vibracure ™ (VC), in the management of pressure ulcers (PU).

Detailed Description
-----------------
The primary purpose of this study is to determine whether vibracure ™ (VC) can effectively manage stages (stage 2, 3, 4) 2 pressure ulcer(s) in the patient's posterior or buttocks area by enhancing vasoconstriction and tissue oxygenation compared to the sham group where both the patients and the treatment staff are blinded to the type of treatment. The secondary purpose of the study is to determine whether VC can improve the symptoms of pain and discomfort associated with pressure ulcers, as measured by the Patient Pain Measurement Questionnaire (SPMQ) and the Visual Analog Scale (VAS), respectively. The third purpose of this study is to develop the research protocol for assessing the treatment effectiveness using vibracure therapy by testing the proposed hypotheses. The fourth purpose of this study is to evaluate the economic and health resource implications of using VC in the treatment of PU.

Effect of Ultrasound Vibration Therapy Combined With Low-level Laser Therapy in Managing Pressure Ulcers: A Randomized, Double-blind, Trial

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The purpose was to evaluate the effects of adding a 17 alpha alkyl ester of dehydroepiandrosterone (17‐OHP) injection to the standard treatment care of women with severe alopecia areata, in order to reduce symptoms and improve quality of life. OBJECTIVE: To assess the effects of the addition of 17‐OHP to the standard treatment care of women with severe alopecia areata, in order to reduce the total number of plucked hairs and increase the hair pull test response. METHODS: The 17‐OHP injection was given once every 4 weeks for 3 months to women who were diagnosed with severe alopecia areata. The patients were evaluated immediately before and after treatment with a 5‐point scale of 0 (no activity) to 4 (symptoms controlled). RESULTS: Fifty‐seven of the 167 patients completed the study with results as follows: plucked hairs decreased from 1055 before treatment to 81 after treatment; hair pull test response increased from 0.154 before treatment to 0.513 after treatment; the symptom score decreased from 3.63 before to 1.13 after treatment; and patient satisfaction increased from 2.03 before to 3.99 after treatment. CONCLUSIONS: In women with severe alopecia areata, the addition of a 17‐OHP injection resulted in a decrease in plucked hairs. Treatment also produced an increase in hair pull test response, an improvement in symptoms, and a great increase in satisfaction level. Long‐term research is required to compare these results with current treatment options.

Abstract:
The purpose of this study is to assess the effects of resistance training and whole‐body vibration training on mobility and strength in women aged 75 and older. The study includes 16 female participants that will be randomly assigned to a resistance training (RT) group, a whole‐body vibration training (WBVT) group, or a control group that will not exercise for 12 weeks. During the initial assessment, the participants will undergo a range of assessment tests including: 1) a mobility test, 2) strength assessment, 3) walking speed tests, and 4) health surveys. After the tests, the participants in the RT and WBVT groups will undergo resistance training and whole‐body vibration training, respectively, for 12 weeks. The follow‐up assessment will be conducted after the intervention period to assess the mobility and strength levels. The results of the study will enable us to understand the effects of resistance training and whole‐body vibration training on mobility and strength in older women.

Introduction
Autonomy and daily mobility are crucial for older people to live independently and actively participate in social life . Maintaining mobility is associated with numerous benefits, including decreased risk of falls, a lower risk of functional decline, and reduced dependence on health care services . However, mobility and strength decline with age, increasing the risk of falls, functional limitations, and reduced quality of life . Mobility and strength play a crucial role in maintaining the daily activities of individuals and reducing the risk of injuries, falls, and hospitalizations .
Exercise interventions such as resistance training and whole-body vibration training can be effective in improving mobility and strength in older adults . Resistance training involves lifting weights, which can increase muscle size and strength . Whole-body vibration training involves standing on a vibrating platform, which can stimulate muscle contraction and increase bone density and muscle strength . Both types of exercises have been shown to be safe and effective in improving mobility and strength in older adults . However, it is essential to assess the impact of these exercises on mobility and strength in older women as they may experience unique challenges and limitations related to aging, reduced hormone levels, and decreased bone density . This study aims to evaluate the independent and combined effects of resistance training and whole-body vibration training on mobility and strength in elderly women. The study hypothesis

Scientific title
=================
Implementation of a pain neuroscience education program to patients with chronic lower back pain: a cluster-randomized controlled trial

Study hypothesis
=================
The aim of this study is to investigate the effects of a pain neuroscience education program, delivered during patients' admission in hospital, on pain intensity, disability and patient compliance in physical therapy. For this purpose, a quasi-experimental, parallel, controlled, two-arm intervention trial was carried out with patients with low back pain. The protocol adopted a randomized controlled design. Patients were allotted by block randomization to the experimental and control groups. The intervention group was the experimental group, while the control group was comprised of patients who received usual care. The intervention consisted of eight sessions of pain neuroscience education. Data regarding intervention adherence as well as physical outcomes were collected via self-report scale.The participants were assessed through questionnaires at 30-day intervals over a follow-up period of six months

Abstract:
PURPOSE: To determine the effects of 6 weeks of low‐dose flunisolide and 10,000 iu oral vitamin D supplementation on bone mineral density (BMD) in postmenopausal women.METHODS: In this randomized double‐blind study 82 ambulatory postmenopausal pre‐ and post‐menopausal women with no history of vitamin therapy over the past 5 years and osteoporosis were enrolled and randomized to groups that received either oral vitamin D plus flunisolide or oral flunisolide for 6 weeks. Spine and calcaneus BMD measurements were performed at baseline and at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months.RESULTS: The average age of the women was 49 (range 35‐65) years with an average BMD of spine 0.683 +/‐ 0.13 g/cm(2) and a calcaneus BMD of 0.597 +/‐ 0.10 g/cm(2) at baseline. Vitamin D alone was not effective in increasing the spinal BMD over the course of the study, in increasing the calcaneal BMD over the course of the study (at best 1 month, and only in females randomized to flunisolide without vitamin D), or in decreasing the percent change in the spinal BMD over time. There was no increase in the spinal or calcaneal bone mass, and overall there were no differences in either BMD or in the percent change on BMD with the addition of the vitamin D to the flunisolide treatment group.CONCLUSION: The present study shows definitively that 6 weeks of low‐dose flunisolide therapy does not alter spinal BMD in postmenopausal women and, further, that oral vitamin D does not increase spinal BMD or prevent the loss in spinal BMD over time when combined with flunisolide therapy.

Background
-----------------
Fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva (FOP) is a disabling genetic disorder characterized by progressive heterotopic ossification. FOP is caused by postzygotic activating mutations of the ACVR1-related gene, or ActaRIA (ALK2), and it affects all racial and ethnic groups. FOP is characterized by a typical clinical course defined by two distinct but overlapping phases, a soft-tissue phase, followed by a progressive skeletal phase. Musculoskeletal manifestations occur throughout FOP, affecting multiple anatomic sites and resulting in joint ankylosis, fused skin, and severe disability. It is estimated that 30 patients in the United States are affected by FOP.  
Rationale
-----------------
In most of the literature, skeletal involvement in FOP is described in detail. However, reports on extra-skeletal disease manifestations are less common. The American Academy of Neurology (RAND, 2015) has noted that the description of the different stages of the disease are inaccurate or incomplete, with most attention given to the skeletal manifestations. However, a recent review of musculoskeletal manifestations of FOP (Schaefer, et al, 2022) has concluded that there remains a need to better characterize the course of the disease, which we hope the OSCAR database will help accomplish. 
Methods for collection of patient information
-----------------
The OSCAR database was developed to meet the lack of standardized data collection criteria in the characterization of FOP. Data collected as part of the OSCAR database will include patient characteristics including medical history, family history, age at onset of the signs and symptoms of the disease, and outcomes measures.  Measuring disease outcomes with a multi-institutional approach will increase diagnostic and treatment accuracy and may lead to more specific indicators and treatments in the future.

Study Overview ================= Brief Summary ----------------- Dermal lymphangiosarcoma (DLKS) is a rare malignant neoplasm of the soft tissue, mainly arising from areas of chronic lymphedema. Treatment of choice is wide local excision followed by radiotherapy. However, due to the slow growth pattern, treatment usually has to be postponed until tumor sizes are large enough to cause local symptoms. The rarity of this disease and poor knowledge of clinical trial design has led to the creation of a number of different guidelines on treatment of this disease. The optimal treatment, however, remains under debate. In the present study, we will investigate the long-term effect of treatment with radiotherapy with respect to survival, local control, number of recurrences, development of new DLKS and the quality of life of patients treated in Denmark in 2000 to 2010 at Copenhagen University Hospital. The purpose of this phase 2a study is to investigate the safety and efficacy of three different doses and two dosing regimens of KPT330 in participants who have primary immune deficiencies (PID) caused by the absence of an active common gamma chain (γc) or its receptor. PID patients are at increased risk of developing infections, autoimmune diseases, and malignancies. KPT330 is a dimerized, in vitro‐activated version of the γc that binds with a higher affinity to the IL‐13 type II IL‐13 receptor (IL‐13Rα2) and IL‐4R (comprised of IL‐4Rα and IL‐13Rα1) than IL‐13. Two parallel randomized 3‐period, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled treatment designs will be used. Participants will receive the first 2 doses of KPT330/placebo in a fixed dose design within a 14‐day period, separated by a drug washout period, followed by 2 doses of active drug in an ascending dose design, with each dose separated by a 28‐day washout period. The treatment regimen duration is 98 days. Participants will receive KPT330 at doses up to 400 mg or 4 mg/kg, with or without a 30‐minute premedication with 10‐mg oral dexamethasone. The treatment effect on clinical efficacy endpoints will be evaluated using the Mann‐Whitney U test, generalized estimating equation (GEE) analysis model, or Wilcoxon signed‐rank test. Safety will be evaluated through adverse event (AE) and laboratory assessments. Statistical significance will be determined at p < 0.05. The safety and tolerability of KPT330 will be assessed by AEs or symptoms and laboratory assessments reported by participants or collected during routine study follow‐up.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Studies evaluating the effect of testosterone treatment over 6 months for androgenic alopecia, are inconclusive regarding a 6 months efficacy on hair growth, as the majority of the studies report a transient effect, with loss of the therapeutical benefit soon after the end of the treatment. Testosterone has long been known to stimulate hair growth when applied topically. In the recent years, the use of topical estradiol in post-menopausal women was reported to induce significant hair growth. The efficacy of topical testosterone and estradiol has been associated with the effect on AR, which has been reported to stimulate hair growth when upregulated. Androgen receptor (AR) belongs to the superfamily of steroid hormone receptors. It is a ligand-dependent transcription factor that regulates gene expression, and its activity is positively regulated by the endogenous male hormone androgen. Although androgen is crucial for hair growth and development, androgenic alopecia (AGA) and hair loss is associated with AR mutation, it is unclear how AR functions in the growth of all hair types. The primary objective is to assess the efficacy of a hair treatment formulation enriched in plant estradiol versus placebo in patients with alopecia in a 6 month period.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Seventy-five male patients, affected by AGA will be randomly divided in three groups: topical testosterone, plant estradiol or placebo control. 75 Female patients, affected by AGA will be randomly divided in three groups: topical testosterone, plant estradiol or placebo control.

Abstract:
Background: Injection drugs users (IDUs) are at increased risk of developing respiratory infections. To date, there is a paucity of research regarding prevalence of respiratory infections in the IDU population. Methods: We performed a cross‐sectional study of bacterial respiratory infection and associated predictors in 70 IDUs. Univariate and multivariate regression analyses were conducted to determine the relation of predictors with infection. Results: Significantly more females were found to be infected compared with males (34.5% vs. 10.5%, respectively; P = 0.025). The most common bacterial species was Haemophilus influenzae (47%), followed by Streptococcus pneumoniae (40%). Multivariate analysis found alcohol use (adjusted odds ratio (AOR): 3.92, 95% confidence interval (CI): 1.08‐ 14.46) and opiate use (AOR: 3.19, 95% CI: 1.00‐10.09) to be significantly related to respiratory infection. Conclusion: In our sample, females had a higher propensity to develop respiratory infections than males despite using fewer intravenous drugs and having a lower prevalence of alcohol use disorder. Those with more frequent opiate use were found to be associated with higher odds of respiratory infection.

Brief Summary
-----------------

In this randomized phase II portion of the study, participants will be randomized to receive either standard dose bevacizumab or standard dose bevacizumab in combination with nab-paclitaxel, at 125 mg/m2 administered every 2 weeks until disease progression. The study will evaluate overall survival as a primary endpoint, quality of life and objective response rates as the secondary endpoint, and the maximum tolerated dose of bevacizumab and nab-paclitaxel in pBC patient as a safety endpoint. The participants of the study will receive a treatment of 3-6 cycles before further analyses of efficacy and safety will be performed. Patients will still be followed even after they discontinue treatment, with planned follow-up visits every 2 months on study up to 4 years.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The aim of this multicenter, randomized controlled study was to investigate the effect of treatment with the drug prazosin on the sleep structure in patients with sleep apnea syndrome (SAS).MATERIALS AND METHODS: Two hundred and eighty‐seven patients with SAS were included in the study. Patients were randomly assigned to the treatment group (received 200 mg of prazosin at bedtime) and 200 mg placebo group. The structure of sleep was studied using nocturnal polysomnography (PSG).RESULTS: Sleep architecture was improved in both groups: the sleep onset period was shortened, and the total sleep time (TST) increased, which was statistically significant. The TST was higher in the treated group than in the placebo group, but the difference was not statistically significant. Both polysomnography criteria for apnea syndrome in the absence of other somnopolarities (apnea‐hypopnea index < =10, percent saturation < 89%, percent saturation decrease >3% in at least a 5% reduction from baseline, snoring >2 snoring episodes per minute of sleep, arousal index >10/hour) and the diagnostic criteria of SAS on the basis of all above‐mentioned indicators were reduced in favor of the treated group.CONCLUSION: The use of prazosin significantly improved the parameters of sleep structure and polysomnographic criteria for the diagnosis of secondary (due to sleep apnea) hypertension in patients with SAS.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine the immediate effect on musculoskeletal fatigue, pain intensity, and pressure pain thresholds after one set of 10 repetitions of two variations of the cervical lateral flexion exercise, each of which lasts 7 seconds, and which are the cervical lateral flexion exercise with head up and cervical lateral flexion exercise with head down, respectively.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Cervical lateral flexion exercises (CLF) are recommended for people with neck pain. There are two different variations of the CLF exercise. However, there has been no study comparing the immediate effects of these two variations on musculoskeletal fatigue, pain and pressure pain thresholds. Therefore, this study aims to compare immediate effects of two variations of CLF exercise. This study is a crossover, single-blind, comparison study to be carried out for healthy control individuals (HCI) and patients with chronic nonspecific neck pain of grade 2 and above to determine the immediate effects of CLF exercises with head up or CLF exercises with head down. The study includes the following three phases: first, a measurement-free familiarization phase, second, a main study including a muscle fatigue test and pain measurements (Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), Pressure Pain Threshold (PPT) test) before (T0) and immediately after (T1) exercise, and finally, recovery phase. The primary aim of the study is to determine the immediate effects of cervical lateral flexion exercises (CLF) with head down (E1) or CLF with head up (E2) on muscle fatigue measured with the 10-Reps Cervical Lateral Flexion Test (CLF10) in healthy individuals. Abstract:
Background: Hysterectomy is one of the commonly performed surgeries in adult women, and postoperative pain is a common complication following this surgery. This study aims to evaluate the effects of oral sodium cromoglycate on postoperative pain in patients undergoing hysterectomy. Methods: This double‐blind, randomized, parallel experimental, controlled clinical trial was conducted on women undergoing hysterectomy at Ayatollah Rouholamini and Ayatollah Taleghani hospitals in Semnan, Iran in 2021. In this study, 120 patients were randomly divided into two groups of experimental and control. The intervention group received oral sodium cromoglycate, and the control group was only given normal saline. Pain medication (intravenous morphine 0.05 mg/kg) was used for them in the case of pain. The pain level was assessed according to a 10 cm visual analog scale (VAS) immediately before and 1, 2, and 4 hours after surgery. Changes in VAS scores were compared between the two groups. Results: The mean age of the patients was 34.08 ± 5.83 years. In the intervention and control groups, the mean VAS score was 13.30 ± 2.33 and 14.51 ± 2.75 immediately before surgery, 4.95 ± 3.41 and 5.45 ± 2.93 one hour after surgery, 2.65 ± 3.71 and 3.05 ± 2.35 two hours after surgery, and 2.12 ± 2.24 and 2.25 ± 2.59 four hours after surgery. The differences between the groups were not statistically significant. Conclusion: The results of this study indicate that sodium cromoglycate has no effect on reducing postoperative pain in women undergoing hysterectomy.

Abstract Background:
Background: To our knowledge, there are only five published randomized controlled trials of cognitive behaviour therapy (CBT) specifically designed for people with early rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and the effect of CBT on long‐term disability is unclear. Objectives: The aim of this study was to compare the effect of a 10‐session manualised CBT or a 10‐session manualised social cognitive theory (SCT) control intervention for people with early RA on disability and on other outcomes associated with wellbeing during an 18‐month follow‐up period. Methods: This randomised controlled trial involved 84 participants with early RA (2 months ‐ 1 year). Participants were randomly assigned to 10 sessions of specialist CBT or 10 sessions of a SCT‐based manualised control group. The primary outcome was the functional ability component of the Stanford health assessment questionnaire (HAQ‐DI) at 18 months. Results: The primary outcome was completed for 76 patients (56 CBT, 20 SCT) at 18 months. There were no significant differences in mean changes in HAQ‐DI score or the other outcomes evaluated (pain, fatigue, anxiety, depression or global change rating). There were no significant differences in mean scores for the cost‐effectiveness data collection, though there were significant differences in cost outcomes at 5 months (p=0.016) and 50% of participants reported health‐related quality of life was a key factor in choosing the study intervention. Conclusions: Manualised CBT or manualised SCT were equally effective in people with early RA. Future studies should use cost modelling analysis to determine the most effective use of resources. BACKGROUND: 1.	RATIONALE: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) has long been considered a curative treatment option for patients with leukemia, lymphoma, and other blood disorders. Despite the widespread adoption of HSCT, the management of persistent fatigue remains a significant concern for patients and healthcare providers. According to a meta-analysis of 25 studies, overall fatigue post-allogeneic HSCT persists in approximately 35%-50% of patients one year post-transplantation.  In a recent study, the authors reported that 15% of patients who underwent non-myeloablative allogeneic HSCT experienced moderate to severe fatigue at 24 months post-HCT. Fatigue persistence has been associated with decreased quality of life (QoL), impaired functional ability, decreased adherence to medical care, and increased healthcare utilization, thereby incurring a substantial economic burden. Furthermore, some studies have shown that persistent fatigue after HSCT is an independent predictor of overall survival (OS) and is associated with an increased risk of death in patients with multiple myeloma (MM). 2.	OBJECTIVES:  To evaluate the efficacy of a group-based Cognitive behavioral therapy for fatigue (CBT-F) intervention on functional disability, pain, and quality of life in adult HSCT recipients with persistent post-allogeneic fatigue relative to usual care (UC).HYPOTHESIS: Patients in the intervention arm will report lower fatigue scores compared to the control arm at 3 and 5 months. Additionally, the intervention arm will report lower levels of pain, psychological distress, functional impairment, and depression

Intervention Description:: This single-centre, parallel, wait-list control study evaluates the immediate effect of the CBT-I intervention on patient outcomes. Eligible participants are randomised on a 1:1 basis to receive the CBT-I intervention or take part in the waitlist control group. The outcome measures are assessed at baseline (prior to the start of intervention session 1), at the end of the post-intervention treatment phase, and 12 months later. A waitlist control group is created by randomly assigning individuals to the group that receives the intervention in the second half of the study. Those in the intervention group have access to the intervention after waiting six weeks. 
Intervention Dose Description:: The eight 1-hour CBT-I intervention sessions are delivered in the morning (9:00 - 10:00), followed by a booster session one month post completion of all 8 sessions. The treatment is offered between March and September of 2019, and is provided on weekdays mornings. Participants will be asked to attend the clinical practice of the University of Tasmania, located in the state capital of Hobart.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a pilot study aiming to evaluate the feasibility of applying a combination of mindfulness and health psychology (MHP) intervention in people with mild cognitive impairment in a residential treatment center. In total, 42 patients with mild cognitive impairment will be recruited and randomized to an experimental group and a control group. For the 12-week experiment and control group, participants are required to undergo functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) on 3 occasions: at the baseline (T1), mid-experiment (T2) and post-experiment (T3), which is 4 to 6 months later depending on the patient's condition. In addition to the fMRI experiments, the participants will need to complete questionnaires, blood and urine tests, neuropsychology assessments, electroencephalogram (EEG) and a medical interview at each time. The results will be used to evaluate the treatment process, the treatment effect of cognitive function and the mechanisms of action of MHP intervention.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Patients receive mindfulness and health psychology intervention for twelve weeks. A total of 42 patients with mild cognitive impairment are recruited according to the inclusion and exclusion criteria, and grouping is random. Inclusion criteria: 1. Patients with dementia meet the diagnostic criteria of mild cognitive impairment; 2. aged 60-80 years; 3. can cooperate with the treatment and follow the treatment program. Exclusion criteria: 1. Neuropathy in peripheral nerves and skeletal muscle diseases; 2. Brain hemorrhage, traumatic brain injury, etc.; 3. Patients with major depressive disorder, history of stroke, and abnormal electroencephalogram (EEG), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and other scans; 4. Unmanageable diseases (e.g., malignant tumors); 5. Suffering from serious diseases (such as lung, heart and liver failure, etc.), with other cognitive interventions at the same time, or participating in other interventions; 6. Have a history of alcohol and other drug addiction. 7. Cannot accept MRI scans; 8. History of mental illness;
groundtruth: The Rate of Enrollment evaluates the feasibility of enrolling participants in the randomized trial. The goal is to enroll at least 60% of eligible participants. This measure helps assess the practicality of recruitment strategies and the interest of the target population in participating in the intervention. It will be measured at recruitment.

The Rate of Retention assesses the feasibility of retaining participants in both arms of the randomized trial. The study aims for at least 70% retention throughout the study period, from baseline (pre-randomization) up to the 5-month follow-up. This measure provides insights into the effectiveness of the intervention in maintaining participant engagement and adherence.

The Rate of Intervention Completion evaluates the feasibility of participants completing the intervention sessions. The study sets a goal of at least 70% of participants completing at least 70% of the intervention sessions from baseline to the 3-month follow-up. This measure helps gauge participant engagement and adherence to the intervention protocol.

Absolutely! For the secondary outcome measures, I recommend focusing on the Improvement of Fatigue, Improvement of Quality of Life, and Improvement of Mood. These measures will provide insights into the impact of the intervention on various aspects of participants' well-being. What do you think?

Certainly! Let's start with the Improvement of Fatigue. This measure assesses the impact of the intervention on reducing fatigue levels among participants. It will be evaluated using the Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy-Fatigue subscale (FACIT-F). The score range for FACIT-F is 0-52, with lower scores indicating greater fatigue. The time frame for this measure is from baseline (pre-randomization) up to the 5-month follow-up.

The Improvement of Quality of Life measure focuses on assessing the intervention's impact on enhancing participants' quality of life. It will be evaluated using the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy-Bone Marrow Transplant scale (FACT-BMT). The FACT-BMT score range is 0-164, with higher scores indicating better quality of life. This measure will also be assessed from baseline to the 5-month follow-up.

The Improvement of Mood measure aims to evaluate the intervention's effects on anxiety and depression symptoms among participants. It will be assessed using the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS). The HADS anxiety and depression subscale score ranges from 0 to 21, with higher scores indicating worse anxiety and depression symptoms. This measure will also be evaluated from baseline to the 5-month follow-up.

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Pain is often underestimated and unrecognized in the treatment of patients with brain damage, despite being a very important symptom for improving the quality of life of patients. In this work, we aimed to investigate the effect of the pain level on the treatment outcomes in patients with aphasia who were randomly allocated to a group that received standard group therapy or individual therapy at rehabilitation clinics.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Pain is often underestimated and unrecognized in the treatment of patients with brain damage, despite being a very important symptom for improving the quality of life of patients. As a result, treatment is often focused exclusively on motor treatment, leaving pain problems unresolved and limiting the improvement of physical functioning. In aphasia, pain-related problems may include head and neck pain, pain in the jaw muscles, oropharyngeal or pain when speaking or feeling of muscle tension around this joint. In the literature, there are many studies in which pain is considered as a sub-category of speech disorder. However, there are only a few studies which investigate the effects of treatment on pain. In our work, 2000 stroke patients with aphasia treated in rehabilitation centers were included. These patients were randomly allocated to a group that received standard group therapy or individual therapy. As a result of pain assessment, patients with pain were included in the group to be studied. Patients were evaluated with FACQ questionnaire, McGill Pain Questionnaire, and Functional Assessment of Anxiety at three different time periods. In line with our hypothesis that there will be an improvement in pain-related functions as the aphasia treatment progress, we aimed to examine the relationship between pain severity and treatment outcomes in patients with aphasia.

Official Title
-----------------
The Effect of Pain-Related Symptoms on the Functional Improvement of Patients With Aphasia

Abstract:
Background: Aphasia is a stroke consequence associated with social isolation, cognitive decline, and increased risk of death from stroke and other types of comorbidity. Aphasia is an acquired language disorder caused by impairment of the left hemisphere, affecting the domains of language, which are phonology, fluency, syntax, and semantics. Stroke survivors with aphasia and their family caregivers (FCGs) showed a reduction in the quality of life and a greater level of anxiety and depression. Consequences for the couple's relationship are a decrease in social interaction and an increase in emotional distance. Consequently, they can generate physical and psychological distress for the post‐stroke patients with aphasia and their FCGs. Objectives: To examine quality of life (QoL), depression, and marital satisfaction, 6 months after intervention. Method: A longitudinal, quasi‐experimental study was conducted with a time lag of 6 months in a community health institution, with thirty‐four family caregivers (FCGs) (16 cases) and thirty individuals with aphasia (ISA) (16 controls). The QoL of both the ISA and the FCGs was assessed with a semistructured questionnaire validated in the French language (QSF‐VAS) and adapted for family caregivers (QSF‐AFA). To evaluate the depression of ISA, the General Health Questionnaire was utilized. To measure marital satisfaction, the Satisfaction with Marriage Scale (SMS) was utilized with specific adaptations to the Brazilian society. A Wilcoxon test is performed to compare the variables before and after the intervention, and an independent t‐test will be applied to compare the two groups. Results: The QoL level of the ISA showed a statistically significant p < 0.05, between the pre‐ and post‐intervention. The QoL of the FCGs showed a statistically significant p < 0.05 in the post‐intervention when compared to the pre‐intervention. Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To evaluate effects of acupuncture analgesia on patient pain and anxiety during elective caesarean section without analgesia.DESIGN AND METHODS: A total of 80 patients undergoing elective caesarean section without analgesia were randomly divided into two groups, the control group and a treatment group. Patients in the control group only accept the conventional non‐pharmacologic analgesia during surgery, the treatment group is also with acupuncture analgesia at the end of surgery. The anxiety was measured by using the STAI scale and the pain was measured by using the VAS (the visual analogue scale).RESULTS: After the treatment, the score of anxiety in treatment group was (27.25±11.05), higher score in the treatment group than the control group (p<0.05). And the pain score in the visual analogue scale (VAS score) in the treatment group was (67.30±3.28), lower score in the treatment group than the control group (p<0.05).CONCLUSIONS: Acupuncture analgesia combined with conventional non‐pharmacologic analgesia is an important method to relieve patient perioperative anxiety and pain during elective caesarean section without analgesia, and it needs to be popularized.

Scientific title
=================
Assessment of the Efficacy and Feasibility of an Educational Intervention Program Using the Digital Platform of the MUSE-Medical University of Slovakia ePlatform in Preoperative Planning of Elective Inpatients

Plain English Summary
=================
Introduction: Nowadays, patients tend to be more informed before undergoing major elective surgery and, therefore, have higher requirements of the preoperative planning process. The present state of e-communication in both healthcare and education provides a valuable opportunity to develop an efficient and effective communication tool for preoperative planning. There is a lack of studies describing the implementation of patient-specific preoperative planning in a European setting. This clinical trial aims to develop and evaluate the ePrepSurgery preoperative planning tool based on the educational concept of the Healthcare Preoperative Procedure (HCPP). The primary aim of the study is to assess the accuracy of this ePrepSurgery preoperative planning application. The secondary aim is the evaluation of its feasibility and acceptance among medical staff and hospital patients. Methods: The study was conducted as a prospective, non-randomized cohort study. The study included 140 inpatients planned to undergo elective surgery. The enrolled individuals were divided into two groups (both inpatients). Both groups underwent surgical preoperative planning on the same day. The first group used the ePrepSurgery application, while the second group received an individual consultation with an anesthesiologist. The patients' knowledge of the disease and treatment plan was evaluated using a self-completed questionnaire. The feasibility and acceptance of the ePrepSurgery application both among patients and healthcare personnel (anesthesiologists) were evaluated using a questionnaire. Patient satisfaction with the application was evaluated with a 5-point scale (very low, low, moderate, high, and very high). The accuracy of the ePrepSurgery application was assessed

Brief Summary

This study investigates the effects of balance training combined with fall prevention education on the balance and fall risk factors in elderly patients with vertigo, dizziness and dizziness of various reasons, which are divided into four groups as follows: Group 1 (healthy group): it was assigned into a healthy group as a control group, it is not treated with any treatment method. Abstract:
This observational study aimed to assess the impact of the COVID‐19 pandemic on the care of patients in a tertiary healthcare service. The main objective was to evaluate the effect of COVID‐19 on the use of telemedicine as a platform for communication between the multidisciplinary team and patients with cystic fibrosis (CF) over the course of an annual review. A secondary objective was to explore the experience and preferences of patients and clinicians with this platform. The study compared data of patients assessed before and during the pandemic. The time point before the pandemic was defined as December 2019, whereas the time point during the pandemic was defined as March to September 2020. In total, a group of 77 patients were included; 32 of whom were assessed before and 45 during the pandemic. Mean age of patients in both groups was 29.9 ± 16.7 and 28.3 ± 12.5 years old, respectively. Only 21.9% of the patients in the pre‐COVID‐19 group underwent telemedicine at the end of the visit compared to 88.9% of the patients in the in‐pandemic group (p<0.0001). The preference for telemedicine expressed by patients was 71.89% (p<0.0001). The COVID‐19 pandemic has increased the use of telemedicine as an alternative medium to face‐to‐face meetings, which, according to the patients, is preferred in their experience of follow‐up during the annual review.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The aim of this study was to analyze the data from the randomized trial of vitamin C and D therapy on cardiovascular risk management in the presence and absence of metabolic syndrome.METHODS: Randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled parallel trial, conducted in 172 patients with dyslipidemia and metabolic syndrome (MS) and 76 controls. The risk factors were blood pressure, low‐density lipoprotein‐cholesterol (LDL‐C), high‐density lipoprotein‐cholesterol (HDL‐C), triglycerides, plasma glucose and 25‐hydroxyvitamin D levels. One hundred seventy‐two (mean age of 44.64 + 4.67) patients with cardiovascular risk factors and 76 controls (mean age 40.42 + 4.49) were included in the study.RESULTS: The treatment group (vitamin B9, nicotinamide and vitamin E, 211 patients, mean age 45.73 + 4.42), received 900 mg/day for eight weeks, and the control group (placebo, 81 patients, mean age 43.76 + 4.49) received matching placebo in a randomized, double‐blind manner. After treatment, a significant decrease in blood pressure in hypertensive patients and a significant decrease in LDL‐C, TG and glycemia in patients with dyslipidemia and diabetes occurred compared to the baseline values. Changes in triglyceride levels were lower in patients with MS compared to controls.CONCLUSION: The long‐term use of B vitamins, nicotinamide and vitamin E as a supplementary therapy for six months is safe in terms of preventing and managing dyslipidemia and metabolic syndrome, blood pressure and the development of type 2 diabetes. However, further placebo‐controlled, double‐blind studies are warranted.

Thank you for providing all the necessary information. Now, let me summarize the outcome measures we have designed for your clinical trial:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Physical Activity Scale for the Physically Disabled (PASIPD): This 13-item scale assesses activities of daily living, domestic activities, and professional duties over the last 7 days. The time frame for measuring the PASIPD is 7 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Exercise Benefits/Barriers Scale: This scale consists of 43 items and assesses the individual's level of belief in the benefit of exercise. The time frame for measuring the Exercise Benefits/Barriers Scale is 7 months.
- Berg Balance Scale (BBS): This 14-item scale evaluates balance and fall risk. It measures the patient's ability to maintain balance while performing static or various functional movements. The time frame for measuring the BBS is 7 months.
- International Fall Effectiveness Scale (FES-I): This scale assesses the self-confidence of individuals in daily activities and their fear of falling. The time frame for measuring the FES-I is 7 months.
- Fatigue Severity Scale (FSS): This scale assesses the fatigue status of individuals over the past week. Those with an FSS score of 4 or higher are considered tired. The time frame for measuring the FSS is 7 months.
- Beck Depression Inventory (BDI): This inventory measures the symptoms of depression. It consists of 21 items graded between 0 and 3 points. The time frame for measuring the BDI is 7 months.
- Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI): This scale assesses the quality of sleep and disturbances experienced by individuals over the past month. The time frame for measuring the PSQI is 7 months.

Abstract:
Liposomes are used in numerous pharmaceutical formulations. As a result of their unique properties, including liposome‐targeted drug release, liposomes can increase drug efficacy and patient safety. Liposomes are composed of phospholipids and are able to carry drugs into the bloodstream without being broken down by cell membranes. Once in circulation, liposomes can deliver drugs to specific cells or organs. The size and shape of liposomes determine their ability to carry drugs to different parts of the body. Recent studies have shown that the clinical outcomes of breast cancer can be improved by using cisplatin‐ loaded liposomes in combination with traditional chemotherapy. However, the treatment of metastatic breast cancer remains a challenge. This report aims to provide an update on the use of liposomes in the treatment of breast cancer. Copyright © 2018 A.T.K. Tan and I.A Purnomosidi.

During the treatment period, both participants and investigators will report any moderate or severe PEs to the study team. Study design
=================
Study type:: Interventional study
Study purpose:: Treatment


Intervention
=================
The intervention consists of two different intravenous infusions of Itepekimab or placebo at week 0 (baseline), week 4, and week 12. The dosing regimens for both Itepekimab and placebo will be administered at doses of 0.25mg/kg or 0.1 mg/kg, depending on the participant's body mass index (BMI). At week 0 (baseline), all participants will receive an intravenous infusion of investigational medicine for approximately three hours. At week 4, all participants will receive a second infusion of investigational medicine for approximately one hour. At week 12, all participants will receive a third infusion of investigational medicine for approximately one hour. Itepekimab or placebo has not previously been evaluated in the treatment of non-CF bronchiectasis, and the study duration is approximately one year.

Abstract:
Introduction: The aim of our study was to perform a single‐center, single‐blind, randomized‐controlled study in order to determine the effect of an intra‐articular injection of PRP combined with autologous platelets concentrate for the treatment of osteoarthritis of the knee. Materials and methods: From March to April 2020, 30 subjects were enrolled randomly and divided into two groups. Ingroup I, 14 patients with osteoarthritis of the knee received an intra‐articular injection of PRP, while ingroup II, 16 patients with osteoarthritis of the knee received an intra‐articular injection of ACP. A visual analog scale (VAS) score and the knee injury and osteoarthritis outcome score (KOOS) were calculated before the start of the study and after 3, 6 and 12 months. Results: All recruited patients completed the study. There was a significant difference between the two groups in the VAS (Figure 2) and KOOS score at three, six and 12 months after injection; however, there was no significant difference between the groups at any time. There were significantly improved outcomes compared to baseline values. Conclusions: Intra‐articular injections of PRP, as well as ACP, are both effective in minimizing pain and increasing mobility. This method of treatment may be a viable alternative to traditional invasive treatments such as surgery. Nevertheless, there were no significant differences between the groups. Keywords: Osteoarthritis (OA); platelet rich plasma (PRP); Autologous conditioned plasma (ACP)

Abstract:
Background: Acanthosis nigricans is a common skin condition characterized by hyperkeratosis, hyperpigmentation and fibrosis. Although the exact cause is unknown, obesity is known to be a contributing factor. Effective treatments for acanthosis nigricans are limited, with topical steroids and topical retinoids as the main therapeutic options. The aim of this study was to compare the effectiveness of topical 15% trichloroacetic acid (TCA) and topical 0.05% tretinoin in the management of acanthosis nigricans. Methods: This randomized, double‐blinded, controlled clinical trial was conducted between September 2021 and December 2021 at Mardan Memorial Hospital. A total of 40 patients with acanthosis nigricans who met the inclusion criteria were randomized. Topical TCA was applied to one side of the body, and topical 0.05% tretinoin was applied to the other side daily. Treatment duration was 2 months. The outcome measures were assessing the efficacy of the topical treatments through serial photographs and measuring improvement in hyperpigmentation before and after treatment, as well as evaluating patient satisfaction with a standardized questionnaire. Results: Both topical TCA and topical 0.05% tretinoin were found to be effective in improving the appearance of acanthosis nigricans, although topical 0.05% tretinoin was found to be more effective (p = 0.030). No adverse effects were observed in both groups. Conclusions: This study suggested that topical 0.05% tretinoin is more effective than topical 15% TCA in the management of acanthosis nigricans, which is consistent with previous studies. However, the choice of treatment should be individualized based on the patient's preferences and treatment history.

Background
-----------------
Mortality due to heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) has been increasing. Recent data demonstrates that the most common adverse cardiovascular outcomes in HFpEF patients hospitalized for heart failure are cardiovascular (CV) death, acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) and cardiovascular death or readmission for decompensated HF1, 2, 3. The risk of death increases along with the number of recurrent decompensated episodes. Patients hospitalized in HFpEF usually have persistent disability, progressive cognitive dysfunction and functional decline. Previous reports emphasized that worsening of clinical outcomes in HFpEF were associated with worse systolic blood pressure (SBP)4, 5 and patients with HFpEF without diastolic dysfunction (HFpEF-ND) had a similar risk of death or CV events, regardless of the presence or absence of diastolic function1, 6. However, the treatment goal for the management of HFpEF should be based on the mechanism leading to the left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. The guidelines for the management of HF suggest that, in patients with HFpEF, hypertension treatment should lead to a SBP ?than 125 millimeters of mercury and a diastolic blood pressure (DBP) ?than 75 millimetres of mercury, according to the 2022 AHA/ACC/HFSA guidelines. In the EMPirical Comparison of ARNI with ARB Global Outcomes (EMPEROR-Preserved) trial, ARNI was demonstrated efficacious in patients with HFpEF with reduced ejection fraction regardless of the type of diastolic function as the primary outcome measure was a composite of CV death or worsening HF. As a consequence, the guidelines indicate that SBP may be a relevant target for the management of HFpEF patients, as in the general population7, 8. However, the impact of optimal SBP control on outcomes in HFpEF remains unknown, as no randomized controlled trial has evaluated this association.

Erythrocyte transketolase activity levels reflect the level of NADPH supply in the body, which can be associated with a variety of diseases and conditions. The expression of this enzyme in red blood cells (RBCs) is thought to be related to the severity of oxidative stress and the level of antioxidant defenses. Low erythrocyte transketolase activity levels may indicate an increase in oxidative stress, while high levels may indicate a decrease in oxidative stress. Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase activity levels can help determine the extent of oxidative stress in the body and may be useful in diagnosing and monitoring the progression of diseases or conditions associated with oxidative stress.

This method describes the steps for measuring erythrocyte transketolase activity levels in the laboratory. It involves the use of a reagent kit to determine the activity of transketolase using glucose-6-phosphate as a substrate. The results of the assay will provide information on the level of oxidative stress in the body, which can help guide treatment and management of related conditions.

groundtruth: Certainly! The AUC represents the total exposure of the drug in the body over time, while the Cmax indicates the peak concentration of the drug in the blood after administration. By analyzing both AUC and Cmax, we can assess the rate and extent of drug absorption, which is crucial in determining the bioequivalence of the two Lamotrigine tablets.

To measure the AUC and Cmax, we will collect blood samples at various time points up to 72 hours after the administration of the drug. The sampling schedule will include pre-dose (0) and additional time points such as 0.25, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4, 5, 6, 8, 12, 16, 24, 36, 48, and 72 hours post-dose.

For the AUC measure, we want to establish bioequivalence by ensuring that the calculated 90% confidence interval (CI) for the ratio of geometric means for AUC72 falls within the range of 80.00%-125.00%. Similarly, for the Cmax measure, the 90% CI for the ratio of geometric means should also fall within 80.00%-125.00%.

We will collect blood samples up to 72 hours post-dose to capture the drug's concentration over an extended period. This timeframe will provide us with insights into the drug's absorption, distribution, and elimination processes.

2. Maximal plasma concentration (Cmax): To establish bioequivalence, the calculated 90% CI for the ratio of geometric means for Cmax should fall within 80.00%-125.00%. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The investigator aims to provide objective parameters to support recommendations of NMES application in rehabilitation of the upper limb. This study will be conducted using a prospective randomised controlled trial which will be followed by a split-body design

Our study is situated in such an emergency. This study consist of four arms, the control arm, and three intervention arms. The intervention will be delivered in 20 different villages (intervention arm: I - V) in the Djida Health Zone (HZ) in the Ouémé Valley. The Djida HZ is a health area of about 23,000 persons. The villages included in the intervention arm were selected randomly with proportional allocation. At the onset of the trial, oral cholera vaccine (OCV) was not available. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine whether the use of a non-narcotic oral rinse can reduce the severity and incidence of opioid induced constipation (OIC) compared to a placebo oral rinse in a population taking long-term opioids. An additional objective is to measure the ability of a non-narcotic oral rinse, compared to placebo, to improve quality of life metrics and opioid treatment satisfaction.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Patients will be enrolled from multiple sites. A screening visit will be conducted following initial contact of the subject by phone or email. All consenting subjects randomized to the treatment portion of the study will be assigned to either active or placebo treatment using a double-blind, parallel group cross over design. Each subject will take medication for 3 weeks followed by 2 weeks rest during the first treatment phase. Then the subjects will stop treatment and enter into the 2 week washout phase before crossing over to the opposite treatment. Subjects will be assigned to either active (Moviprep) or placebo (Conga, a diet soda) oral rinse. The oral rinse treatment consists of a single bottle. Subjects will continue their regular routine medication unless medically necessary. OIC is the most notable side-effect of regularly taking narcotics. There is a pressing need for safe and effective treatment alternatives for chronic pain patients who must suffer with the debilitating effects of OIC. The overall goal of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a non-narcotic oral rinse over a 6 week period in an adult population, aged 18-65, who are prescribed a daily regimen of oral pain medications. Abstract:
We studied the effects of oral dexamethasone on the recovery of motor function after ischemic stroke. For this purpose, thirty‐five patients with middle cerebral artery territory infarction, with neurological deficit from days 1 to 8, were randomized into two groups. Patients of both groups received 300 mg dipyridamole, 25 mcg glyceryl trinitrate and 1000 ml 30% glucose over 12 hours. Treatment group patients also received 8 mg dexamethasone IV over 2 hours. The control group patients received 100 ml of 30% glucose over 2 hours. The modified National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale(NIHSS) was done at the time of admission, before, at 24 hours and 3, 5, 7 and 14 days post treatment. The clinical improvement was more in the treatment group when compared with the control group. The time taken to 50% NIH recovery at day 2 and day 3,14, 28 and 56 was significantly short in the treatment group in comparison with the control group. The study showed faster recovery in the treatment group.

Abstract:
Background: Opioid use disorder (OUD) is a complex and multifaceted condition requiring a comprehensive treatment approach. A significant percentage of patients with OUD experience negative sequelae (complications) secondary to prolonged chronic opioid use. Complications of OUD may include: esophageal issues such as dysphagia, decreased esophageal motility, and reflux; gastrointestinal (GI) issues such as anorexia, nausea and vomiting; and cardiovascular issues. Patients with OUD often present to the emergency department (ED) or undergo outpatient consults to address these various issues. A review of the literature indicates there is evidence that supports various OUD treatment options although there is a lack of clinical guidelines for managing complications of OUD. The purpose of this study is to develop evidence‐based and consensus‐derived clinical practice guidelines for the management of these various complications in patients with OUD. Methodology: The aim is to identify key recommendations based on available literature and expert consensus through a modified modified Delphi consensus panel approach. The process will be led and developed by experts in the field, including clinicians, researchers, and patient advocates. Using an electronic survey, an initial list of clinical scenarios addressing comorbidities and common clinical issues will be developed (e.g. chest pain, esophageal issues, GI issues), and clinicians will be asked to prioritize each scenario based on their clinical relevance. Based on the priority rankings, a modified Delphi consensus panel approach will be used to develop key recommendations to address each scenario. The recommendations will be developed by an expert panel of clinicians and researchers using a structured consensus‐building process. Key recommendations will be based on available evidence ‐ both clinical and literature ‐ and expert opinion. Conclusions: The output from this project will be recommendations for clinicians managing complicated cases of OUD. Evidence‐based recommendations will help physicians better manage the complications that arise in patients with OUD and provide a standardized approach to patient care. This will lead to improved patient outcomes and more efficient use of healthcare resources.

Intervention Description:: The study will be implemented as a non-randomized, single-arm, multicenter, feasibility study. This study will evaluate in-situ conversion of photodynamic-activated lipid peroxides mediated by ROSs during VTP in patients with peripheral stage 1A1/1A2 primary non-small cell lung cancers. A total of 20 participants will be enrolled and evaluated for 8 weeks after randomization.
The robotic assisted bronchoscopic procedure will be performed using RobotMate™ Bronchoscope system (RobotMate, Inc.). It will involve photodynamic diagnosis with hematoporphyrin-derived lipid-soluble photosensitizer (Padeliporfin) before VTP. The first 5 participants will be evaluated using the standard 1400nm 40W light source with different light dosages according to the predetermined treatment schema. The second 5 participants will be evaluated using the VUV-light source with different treatment schema using a similar schedule. The light dosage will vary based on the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) to determine the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D). A total of 10 participants will be treated with the MTD or RP2D of the study drug to achieve an appropriate safety profile for phase 2 assessment.
The treatment safety and efficacy will be assessed at baseline, day 3, 7, 14, postoperative day 30 to month 8. The primary outcome measures of the study include:
- The safety of the robotic assisted bronchoscopic procedure for peripheral stage 1A1/1A2 primary non-small cell lung cancers
- The evaluation of the feasibility of the robotic assist

Several nonpharmacologic interventions have recently been explored in the ED as a potential to increase weight loss. The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether ED intervention for obesity is an effective strategy for achieving weight loss. Methods: This study is a preliminary feasibility trial including patients who present to the ED, are between 18 and 75 years old, and have a body mass index (BMI) ≥30kg/m2. Participants are randomized to receive either the intervention arm (n= 30) or the control arm (n= 30). The intervention arm will be provided with counseling on lifestyle modification, nutrition education, and referral to additional programs available in the community. The control arm will receive standard care by their primary care provider. Primary outcome measure is the change in weight at 30 days. Secondary outcome measures include change in BMI and change in waist circumference. Results: 60 participants were enrolled in the study. Of those, 30 participants in the intervention arm and 30 participants in the control arm completed the study. The intervention arm had a mean weight loss of 4.0 kg and a BMI reduction of 1.8 kg/m2, while the control arm had a mean weight loss of 0.9 kg and a BMI reduction of 0.4 kg/m2. For waist circumference, the intervention arm had a mean reduction of 6.5 cm, while the control arm had a mean reduction of 2.6 cm. Conclusions: This preliminary analysis suggests that a brief ED intervention may be effective in helping patients achieve weight loss goals, with significantly greater reductions in weight and BMI, as well as waist circumference, compared to those in the control group. Abstract:
Introduction Migration to urban areas is considered one of the reasons for increasing road traffic injuries in the province of Mogadiscio, Somalia. Few studies have examined the behavior and driving habits of bus and taxis drivers, who are a significant proportion of people killed or injured in road traffic collisions. Methods This quasi‐experimental study was conducted from October to December 2021 to describe the frequency of risky driving behavior and the frequency of inadequate use of protective gear and personal safety among bus and taxi drivers. The study was conducted in five buses and three taxis in the central district of Mogadiscio, Somalia. Interviewer‐Administered Questionnaires (IAQ) with closed and open‐ended questions were used to collect data. The data were entered into EpiData software and then transferred to SPSS using the SPSS import function. Descriptive statistics were used to determine the outcome of the study. Results We recruited 85 participants, 59 (69.4%) of whom were male. Most of the study participants (72.9%) were uneducated. The average age of the bus and taxi drivers was 26±6 years. The majority of them, 76.5% (65 of 85), did not wear safety equipment when driving a vehicle. Approximately half of them (47.1%) used their mobile phones while driving. The majority of participants (92.9%) did not fasten their seatbelts. Around half (46.5%) wore earphones while driving, and 44 (52.9%) of them did not regularly maintain their vehicle in good condition. Almost half of the drivers (40.0%) worked seven days a week. Conclusion This study showed that the practices and behaviors of bus and taxi drivers in Mogadiscio, Somalia, are unsafe. Furthermore, it is necessary to conduct more research on driver behavior

Study design
=================
Prospective, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multicenter study.

Description
=================
The study is divided into 3 parts. Part I (screening and run in): The investigator will identify potential study participants and screen them to assess eligibility. It is planned that 3 participants will receive the study drug per each participating hospital. Potential participants will be screened for eligibility and undergo a run-in phase of 14 days. The investigator will assess participants during the run-in phase to monitor safety and confirm eligibility. The purpose of the run-in phase is to ensure that participants are stable, without any uncontrolled psychiatric or medical symptoms or exacerbations that may interfere with the study. Once the run-in phase is complete, eligible participants will be randomized to one of the treatment groups.Part II (main): After completing the run-in phase, participants will be randomized to receive either one of the two study drugs, or a placebo, for 12 weeks. The randomization process will be fully automated to help ensure that the study is properly blinded. All participants will be assessed during this phase to monitor safety and efficacy. Participants who successfully complete the 12 week treatment period will enter an open extension phase (Part III) where they will continue to receive the study drug.Part III (optional extension): After completing the 12 week treatment phase, participants may voluntarily continue to receive the study drug for an additional 18 weeks if they meet certain criteria. The criteria for continuing in the open extension period should be determined at the beginning of the study and will be based on the participant's response to the study drug, safety profile, and the availability of the study drug. The open extension phase will help assess the long-term safety and efficacy of the study drugs.The overall duration of the study will be 15.5 months (176 weeks). The trial is estimated to take two years, from the time it is started to the time it ends.

Inclusion criteria
=================
Men and women with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder, with ongoing psychotic symptoms.Stable treatment for at least 30 days prior to study

Acute aortic dissection is treated with either surgical or endovascular aortic repair (EVAR). Acute aortic dissection is characterised by the presence of an intimal tear within the aorta, resulting in the formation of a false lumen. Acute aortic dissection is a life threatening disease, that has a high risk of morbidity and mortality. EVAR is a minimally invasive alternative to open surgery that is associated with less morbidity and mortality and is increasingly being used to treat acute aortic dissections.[1] However, there are no randomised trials comparing EVAR to open surgery in the treatment of acute aortic dissection

Abstract:
Background: The efficacy of acute, low‐dose warfarin following cataract surgery on reducing postoperative inflammation, visual recovery time, and complications such as cystoid macular oedema (CMO) is well known. However, the literature remains inconclusive as to whether the early use of anticoagulant therapy post cataract surgery alters the long‐term outcome. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of early anticoagulation on the retinal outcomes in terms of macular thickness and visual acuity scores. Methods: This randomised, double‐masked, placebo‐controlled study included a total of 190 patients undergoing phacoemulsification with intraocular lens implantation. Subjects were randomly allocated to receive warfarin and patients for controls will take dummy pills. We measured the ciliary body blood flow using color Doppler optical coherence tomography angiography (OCT‐A) and evaluated the change at 30 days and six months follow‐up visit. Results: There was a significant increase in foveal retinal thickness and parafoveal retinal thickness from baseline (P<0.001) in the study group at both 30 days and 6 months’ follow‐up. However, there was no significant increase in macular thickness in the control group (P>0.05). Best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) improved within the first two months, and maintained for 30 days follow‐up visit. Conclusion: Early anticoagulation post cataract surgery is effective to reduce macular thickness, as demonstrated by the reduction in CMO incidence as shown in the OCT‐A.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of the present study is to examine the impact of a specific intervention called Problem-Solving Therapy (PST) on the levels of quality of life experienced by cancer patients with advanced, metastatic cancer in palliative care at the Clinical Oncology Department at the Regional Hospital in Pocking, Czech Republic. A mixed-methods and longitudinal design will be used for this study.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Taking into consideration the fact that an increased sense of quality of life is a significant factor of improving the outcome of palliative care, the aim of the study is to assess different quality of life models in advanced cancer in the terms of the impact on patient reported pain and quality of life (QOL) as the primary dependent variables. Aspects of QOL of patients with advanced cancer will be assessed by the use of two standardized questionnaires and a questionnaire, adapted by the authors of this study. The qualitative study will use two in-depth semi-structured interviews for the patients' evaluations, which are divided into a pre-intervention and a post-intervention assessment.

Impact of Psychotherapeutic and Nursing Interventions on the Levels of Quality of Life of Advanced Cancer Patients: A Longitudinal Mixed-Methods Study Exploring Interoceptive Factors

Anonymity Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Cryotherapy has already been demonstrated to be effective for improving wound healing in humans in many studies. The investigators aim to determine the efficacy of cryotherapy on leg ulcers and on venous trophic skin ulcers. The investigators will also determine whether the use of cryotherapy reduces the risk of secondary amputations, and increase the healing time of the lesions.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The investigators propose to use of this modality in patients in order to improve the healing process in wounds secondary to peripheral arterial disease and venous trophic ulcers. The investigator has already a protocol for the use of cryotherapy in wounds, which is currently applied in the population attending the emergency room of the Clinical Hospital of the Faculty of Medicine of the Federal University of Goiás and in patients with vascular disease. The investigators currently do not have the material to perform a research to support the protocol being used. The investigators intend to perform a clinical trial to determine the effects of the freezing mode, a well known action of cryotherapy, in venous ulcers and peripheral arterial disease.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This randomized, prospective, controlled trial is designed to compare the effects of four different treatments of the acute phase in severe heart failure: thioridazine or intravenous lidocaine alone and thioridazine plus lidocaine. Thirty patients with severe acutely ischemic heart failure will be assigned randomly in four equal groups. For the thioridazine group, patients will receive thioridazine (12.5 mg) by intravenous injection every day twice for three weeks. For the lidocaine group, patients will receive intravenous lidocaine (2 mg/kg/hour) with an upper limit of 200 mg/hour continuously after admission. For the thioridazine plus lidocaine group, patients will receive thioridazine and intravenous lidocaine as described above. For controls, patients will receive placebo of intravenous lidocaine. The primary endpoint of this study is the improvement of left ventricular function as shown by left ventricular ejection fraction as measured by echocardiography at the seventh and thirtieth day after admission.

Thioridazine as an Anti-Inflammatory Treatment in Severe Acute Heart Failure

INTRODUCTION
Surgical resection with curative intent remains the standard of care for most patients with colorectal cancer (CRC). Chemotherapy with or without adjuvant radiation therapy is recommended for patients with high-risk pathologic features or Stage III disease. The most commonly used adjuvant chemotherapy regimen is adjuvant FOLFOX (5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, and oxaliplatin). The effectiveness of adjuvant chemotherapy is well-established based on many large randomized trials, but adherence to the prescribed treatment regimen is often suboptimal. In addition, the incidence of chemotherapy delays and interruptions due to toxicity is high (1-13). Oxaliplatin is one of the principal anti-cancer agents used in both adjuvant and metastatic chemotherapy regimens. Its use is associated with increased rates of acute and late toxicity, which may account for delays and interruptions in chemotherapy (3).
Acute toxicity is most well-known and is characterized by sensory neuropathy. Neurotoxicity begins shortly after initiation of oxaliplatin therapy and is marked by symptoms of neuropraxia and paresthesias that often intensify with continued treatment. Delay in recovery and unresolved neuropathy may have a considerable impact on a patient's quality of life (4-5) and ability to participate in clinical trial data for cancer survivors undergoing aerobic exercise. In addition to acute neurotoxicity associated with chemotherapy, aerobic exercise may also be hindered in cancer survivors due to other

Abstract:
Introduction: The aim of this study is to assess the effectiveness of re‐feeding as the initial nutritional treatment in severely emaciated patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). Materials and Methods: A total of 51 patients were enrolled in a randomized controlled trial and were randomly assigned a high‐protein/high‐energy re‐feeding diet (HPHER Group) or a low‐protein (15–20 g/day) and low‐energy (<1500 kcal/day) diet (LPLEL Group) using a minimization method. The primary endpoint of the study is 12‐month weight gain. The secondary endpoints are changes in nutritional indices, the change in serum amino acid levels, and the rate of conversion to initiation of dialysis therapy from the time of intervention. Results: At the time of assessment of primary and secondary endpoints, we were able to evaluate 27 participants in the HPHER group and 28 participants in the LPLEL group. No significant difference was found in the primary endpoint, but the HPHER group had significantly higher levels of prealbumin compared to the LPLEL group. Serum leucine levels were significantly lower in the HPHER group than in the LPLEL group. A significant decrease in the rate of dialysis initiation was observed in the HPHER group. Conclusion: The re‐feeding program (HPPHER) is safe and does not increase serum urea nitrogen (ureaN) levels to a clinically significant level. It could help prevent the rate of conversion to dialysis therapy and improve weight and serum amino acid levels in some patients with severe emaciation and CKD.

Abstract:
The increasing global burden of dengue and emerging evidence about the benefit of dengue vaccines in reducing its incidence suggest their urgency and implementation for dengue prevention. Vaccine efficacy is a critical factor in determining their success. We review and discuss the importance of vaccine efficacy and how it is measured to help understand its meaning and interpretation in the context of dengue vaccines. We discuss different strategies and metrics used to evaluate vaccines' efficacy, including efficacy by vaccine type, serotypes protection, waning immunity, safety and effectiveness, and their importance in making an informed decision about dengue vaccines. Additionally, we provide recommendations for enhancing vaccine efficacy, focusing on the need for more effective vaccines and improving access and the use of existing vaccines in resource‐limited settings. Understanding and interpreting vaccine efficacy is critical to evaluating the effectiveness and feasibility of dengue vaccines. Developing more effective vaccines and improving access and use in resource‐limited settings is imperative to reduce the incidence of dengue globally.
