Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary objective of this study is to characterize the pharmacokinetics (PK) of the investigational drug (ID) (CytoSorb) for the treatment of patients with hyperbilirubinemia in an attempt for the treatment of liver-related complications in ACLF. The secondary objective is to assess hemodynamic stability in patients with acute-on-chronic liver failure (ACLF) when treated with a sorbent type of therapy.

Detailed Description
-----------------
CytoSorb therapy may be performed in the intensive care unit (ICU) setting as a treatment for patients with acute-on-chronic liver failure (ACLF), due to a hyperbilirubinemia above 8mg/dL. Acute-on-chronic liver failure (ACLF) can be caused by a range of insults, including viral hepatitis, alcoholic hepatitis, and hepatocellular carcinoma. CytoSorb therapy utilizes a polystyrene bead column extracorporeal circuit to remove a various range of circulating toxic agents by extracorporeal detoxification of plasma passing through a column in conjunction with plasma filtration through a membrane in the circuit. Sorbents have been shown to be effective in reducing the level of pro-inflammatory mediators (cytokines) in the body, and they may also be useful in the treatment of hyperbilirubinemia. Patients with acute-on-chronic liver failure (ACLF) often develop complications such as hepatic encephalopathy (HE), coagulopathy, and multi-organ failure, which can be difficult to treat. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Acylation Stimulating Protein (ASP), is a hormone released from adipocytes in response to stressors [1]. Under physiological conditions, high levels of insulin oppose a stress-induced elevation of ASP through direct repression of its mRNA expression and stimulation of lipolysis in adipose tissue by promoting lipid oxidation, decreasing fatty acid availability in adipocytes. In critically ill septic conditions, however, insulin resistance may lead to elevated levels of fatty acids and ASP, which may contribute to organ dysfunction, inflammation and vasoplegia. ASP binds to its cognate receptors with high affinity, which leads to various effects on endothelial cells resulting in vasodilatation, increased vascular permeability, pro-inflammatory cytokine production, endothelial cell migration and adhesion. These observations suggest that ASP is a novel target in the treatment of sepsis and should be targeted in order to attenuate sepsis-mediated organ damage. Although the role of ASP in mediating septic myocardial dysfunction is unknown, our preliminary data indicates that there exists an inverse correlation between ASP and global longitudinal strain, in patients with septic shock in ICU setting (data not yet published). In this study, we propose to measure ASP levels before and after intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) device removal compared to the control group, in order to investigate the role of ASP in the development of septic cardiac dysfunction.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
In patients with myocardial infarction (MI) and/or atrial fibrillation (AF), kinesiophobia and fear of movement are common and affect physical activity and quality of life. Fear of movement causes these patients to be more worried about physical activity. This fear also leads to inactivity, which can worsen cardiovascular health. The aim of this study is to conduct a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate the effect of a digital patient education program on reducing kinesiophobia, promoting physical activity, and improving quality of life in these patients. The research hypothesis is that a digital patient education program will reduce kinesiophobia, promote physical activity, and improve quality of life in patients with MI and/or AF. The targeted population for this study is adults with MI and/or AF who have been discharged from hospital. The digital patient education program will consist of 8 weeks of daily exercises and educational materials to promote physical activity and reduce kinesiophobia. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or the control group. Patients in the intervention group will receive the digital patient education program, while patients in the control group will receive standard care. The study will last for 3 months, with multiple measurement points during the study period. The primary outcome measures are kinesiophobia, physical activity, and quality of life. Abstract:
Background: Anxiety is prevalent, and can occur as a response to stress or illness. Excessive anxiety can lead to negative consequences such as reduced quality of life and loss of social function. A recent study on the effects of a virtual reality treatment for patients with severe anxiety disorder has demonstrated that immersive virtual reality provides an effective treatment in patients experiencing social anxiety. The patient stands in front of a high‐resolution 200‐incher display and sees and hears the virtual scene as if looking through a window. It thus allows the patient to experience and approach feared situations without having to physically confront them. Objective: Here we present the Virtual Reality Exposure (VRE) program and its effectiveness in a group of 34 patients with an anxiety disorder or phobia. Method: A randomized double‐blind study comparing VRE to no treatment. We used two anxiety‐provoking situations, namely entering an elevated walkway and giving a speech. During treatment, the patient stands in front of a projection screen with a picture of the feared situation in which he or she can be placed by way of an avatar. The patient enters the feared situation incrementally (desensitization) by walking down the road or by being led away through the building. The therapist is present during the session but his image is not shown on screen. Results: We found that the treatment reduced fears in both situations. No side effects were registered. Participants rated the exposure as highly acceptable and found it helpful for future copings. We found that it is more effective for situations that are less emotionally intense. Conclusion: Our results suggest that VRE is an effective treatment for fear of social situations and exposure in heights.

Measuring the relative burden of AF can provide a more comprehensive assessment of the impact of AF on patients' daily life and cardiac health. Finally, measuring the rate of stroke events and changes in treatment for patients with AF recurrence will provide real-time information on the clinical implications of AF recurrence, enabling physicians to offer treatment options that are tailored to individual patient needs.

This measure will capture any treatment modifications that occur as a result of AF discovery. The time frame for assessing changes in treatment will also be up to 2 years after ICU discharge.

Study type
=================
Interventional

Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary objective of this study is to evaluate if an intervention such as yoga, as part of the exercise therapy, will improve the clinical and functional condition of patients with heart failure who are symptomatic to conventional therapy. The secondary objective of this study is to evaluate if an intervention such as yoga, as part of the exercise therapy, will improve quality of life and quality of care in patients with heart failure who are symptomatic to conventional therapy.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Heart failure is the first cause of hospitalization in patients older than 65 years. Despite the pharmacological progress of the last 20 years, heart failure is associated with a high mortality and it is one of the main causes of hospitalization and mortality in the elderly population. Yoga, a traditional and holistic therapy, has recently reported favorable effects in patients with chronic heart failure, being more cost-effective than conventional treatments. Yoga has shown beneficial effects on cardiovascular risk factors, such as blood pressure and lipid profile, among others. The objective of Yoga is the use of techniques that allow obtaining physical and mental relaxation, and it is well accepted and cost-effective among the population. The present study aims to evaluate if an intervention such as yoga, as part of the exercise therapy, will improve the clinical and functional condition of patients with heart failure who are symptomatic to conventional therapy.

Official Title
-----------------
Effect of Yoga in the Treatment of Chronic Heart Failure: A Prospective Randomized Clinical Trial

Conditions
-----------------
Heart Failure

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Other: Yoga

They should be in NYHA functional classes II and III and be controlled with medications. Ambulatory subjects, able to sign the informed consent. Exclusion Criteria: Cognitive impairment with a modified MMSE score ≤ 12. Recent (< 2 months) myocardial infarction

Abstract:
PURPOSE: The aim of the study was to establish normal reference values for the uveal vasculature indexes (UVI) in order to allow objective evaluation of retinal vascular reactivity during drug trials.METHODS: A total of 20 healthy individuals with no ocular disease were evaluated. The UVI was recorded using an automatic noninvasive diagnostic system (NonMyd X‐800, Canon, Japan) capable of measuring the pupillary diameter, blood pressure, heart rate, and electrocardiography. All subjects underwent UVI measurements in the dark and during a 20% CO2 challenge. Using Spearman correlation coefficients, we tested various physiologic parameters for their correlations with the UVI.RESULTS: The UVI was calculated over 50 consecutive cardiac cycles. The mean values of the UVI for the right and left eyes under both conditions were significantly correlated (right eye, 0.93; left eye, 0.91). Compared with baseline values, in the 50 consecutive cardiac cycles during the CO2 challenge, the change in the UVI of the right eye was negatively correlated with the mean blood pressure (‐0.93) recorded for the 20‐second CO2 infusion and the maximum blood pressure (‐0.90) achieved during the CO2 challenge. In the 100 consecutive cardiac cycles, the change in the right eye's UVI was also negatively correlated with the mean heart rate for the 20‐second CO2 infusion (‐0.96) and the maximum heart rate (‐0.95) achieved during the CO2 challenge. The UVI of the left eye was also correlated with the mean blood pressure recorded during the 20‐second CO2 infusion.CONCLUSION: During a CO2 challenge, the UVI of the right eye could be decreased by a change in the mean and maximum blood pressure. Because the changes in the UVI of the left eye were correlated with mean blood pressure, the evaluation of the left eye is not suitable to assess the effect of a drug trial for CO2‐induced vasodilation. Abstract:
The aim of this study was to conduct an intra‐individual comparison of the effects on aerobic capacity of two different intermittent resistance exercises (IRR) and to relate these effects to the blood lipid profile. Fifteen sedentary female subjects were randomly divided in three groups: Group A: performing high intensity IRRExercise (IREE); Group B: performing medium‐intensity IRR (m‐IRRE); Group C: control group. In all the groups the intensity and the weekly duration of the exercise remained unchanged. Aerobic energy expenditure was assessed using a VO‐2 curve and the blood lipids profile (high‐density lipoprotein (HDL) and low‐density lipoprotein (LDL), triglyceride (TG) and total cholesterol (TC)) was determined before and after the exercise program. Both IRR protocols improved the aerobic capacity of the subjects at 60% and 70% of the VO‐2 max. The m‐IRRE effect was significantly greater than the IREE (p = 0.039). HDL increased significantly in all groups, but no significant differences were found among the groups (p = 0.361). No effects were found in LDL, TG and TC. The results indicate that IRR is a useful tool for increasing aerobic capacity, without reducing the HDL level, and that the m‐IRRE seems to have a greater effect on aerobic capacity than high intensity IREE.

Study of a Novel Pancreatic Cancer Risk Score Based on 80,672 Patients for Early-Detection of Intraepithelial Neoplasm and Invasive Carcinoma in Pancreas Using Magnetic Resonance Imaging

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: The aim of this study is to develop a diagnostic model to predict the presence of histopathologically high‐ or low‐grade pancreatic ductal epithelial neoplasia (PanIN) and pancreatic ductal carcinoma (PDAC) based on a combination of various factors and the performance of magnetic resonance (MR) imaging in patients undergoing resection for PDAC. Background. MR imaging has very high sensitivity to detect PDAC. However, few studies have investigated the capability of MR imaging in detecting precancerous lesions.METHODS: A total of 80,672 consecutive patients who underwent pancreatic surgery for PDAC were retrospectively analyzed. Histopathologic outcomes were used as ground truth for 10‐fold cross‐validation. The predictive performance of a novel MR imaging‐based risk score was evaluated for high‐grade PanIN and PDAC.RESULTS: The MR imaging‐based risk score combines T2 values, T2 contrast, and diffusion and performs well (area under the curve=0.97, 95% confidence interval [CI]=0.95‐0.98).CONCLUSION: This MR imaging‐based risk score may improve the detection of intraepithelial PanIN and PDAC compared with histopathology alone and is applicable for patients without imaging evidence of malignancy.

[Title]
=================
A comparative study of hot versus cold loop electrosurgical technique for endoscopic resection of serrated colonic polyps 12mm or larger

Scientific title
=================
A comparative study of hot versus cold loop electrosurgical technique for endoscopic resection of serrated colonic polyps 12mm or larger

Plain English summary
=================
Background and study aimsResearch has shown that around 10-15% of colorectal cancers start as sessile serrated lesions (SSLs), a type of large and flat polyp that appears like a sausage and has a surface texture similar to coral reefs. These lesions are located in the outermost layer (epithelium) of the bowel wall and usually look smooth or slightly wavy. Sessile serrated lesions (SSLs) are precursors of colorectal cancer; therefore, their early removal is important because it prevents them from developing into colorectal cancer. Endoscopic resection is the primary means of detecting and removing sessile serrated lesions (SSLs) during colonoscopies. It is important to remove sessile serrated lesions (SSLs) that are ≥ 12mm in size or show high-grade dysplasia on biopsy, as they are more likely to develop into colorectal cancer.Currently, there are two techniques for endoscopic resection: Hot electrosurgical technique and cold loop electrosurgical technique. The hot electrosurgical technique is a faster and more efficient method compared to cold loop electrosurgical technique, however its use in colonic resection remains debated.It is unclear which resection technique is more effective and more efficient in endoscopic resection of sessile serrated lesions (SSLs) of size ≥ 12mm. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Advance Care Planning is a systematic effort to support adults at any age or stage of health in understanding and sharing their personal values, life goals, and preferences regarding future medical care. This study will examine the effect of advance directives and advance care planning interventions on preferences, values, and attitudes of formerly homeless older adults living in permanent supportive housing.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This was a 1-year, randomized, controlled trial (RCT) with interventions designed to increase engagement in advance care planning among formerly homeless older adults residing in permanent supportive housing. Study participants were recruited using a convenience sample strategy. Participants received either facilitated group advance care planning sessions (Group), facilitated one-on-one advance care planning visits (Individual), or did not receive any interventions (Control). The study participants were aged 55 and older and the average age was 60. The participants who were recruited as part of this study were diverse in terms of race/ethnicity, as well as in sociodemographic characteristics, including age, gender, and educational attainment. All enrolled subjects with advance care planning documents were randomly assigned to Group or Individual. The Group intervention was made available to subjects in advance care planning documents who had not completed advance care planning documents. Subjects in Group received eight two-hour sessions of facilitated group advance care planning. The Individual intervention was provided to all enrolled subjects in Individual with advance care planning documents but not Group, and these subjects received four two-hour sessions of facilitated one-on-one advance care planning visits. The Control group consisted of ten participants who did not receive any advance care planning interventions. The control group was asked an initial three questions that served as an outcome measure and did not receive any further assessments from the research team. Each question was scored using a 0 (no) to 4 (yes) scale. The answers to the first question ("Do you have an advance directive?") received 1 point if the response was yes, and 0 points if the response was no. The answers to the second question ("Are your preferences for end of life care documented?") could score a total of 4 points, depending on the participant's advanced directive status. They received 4

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Prevention of stroke with rivaroxaban in transient ischemic attack (TIA) and minor ischemic stroke due to intracranial artery stenosis will be investigated in the present randomized, multicenter, open-label trial. It is assumed that rivaroxaban is superior in reducing the 90-day combined rate of recurrent stroke, myocardial infarction (MI), or vascular death over aspirin.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Intracranial artery stenosis leads to transient ischemic attack (TIA) or minor ischemic stroke (IS) in 10-20% of the cases. In the European Intracranial Atherosclerosis/Aneurysm Study (eICAS) 38% of patients had TIA/non-disabling IS due to intracranial artery stenosis. In all, 42 cases of hemorrhagic transformation were identified, and 48% of hemorrhagic transformation led to death. There is a clinical need to determine which patients may benefit from more intensive antiplatelet treatment such of a direct oral anticoagulant in secondary stroke prevention after TIA/IS due to intracranial stenosis. This will be investigated in the present randomized, multicenter, open-label trial, in which about 2000 patients with minor stroke or high-risk TIA and intracranial artery stenosis will be randomised to aspirin (100mg/day) or rivaroxaban (10mg/day or 20mg/day). The study will evaluate the superiority of rivaroxaban (10mg/day or 20mg/day) over aspirin (100 mg/day) in preventing the 90-day combined rate of recurrent stroke, myocardial infarction (MI) or vascular death in patients with TIA or minor stroke and intracranial artery stenosis.

Official Title
-----------------
Stroke Prevention With Rivarox

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Limited English proficiency (LEP) is a major public health challenge in the United States, particularly in rural communities. LEP individuals often face barriers to accessing healthcare services and understanding health information, leading to worse health outcomes. This randomized controlled trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a multifaceted language access intervention in improving LEP individuals' health-related outcomes. The intervention consists of training healthcare providers to provide culturally and linguistically appropriate care, language support services, and community outreach efforts. Participants will be enrolled across two arms: intervention and control. The intervention group will receive the language access intervention, while the control group will continue to receive standard care. The primary outcome measure is the improvement in blood pressure control among LEP individuals, while the secondary outcome measures include diabetes control, tobacco cessation rates, and overall patient satisfaction. The study will utilize qualitative and quantitative methods to evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention on health outcomes and healthcare access among LEP individuals.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Limited English proficiency (LEP) is a significant public health issue in the United States, particularly in rural communities. LEP individuals often face barriers to accessing healthcare services and understanding health information, leading to poorer health outcomes. This randomized controlled trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a multifaceted language access intervention in improving LEP individuals' health-related outcomes. The intervention consists of three components: 1) training healthcare providers to provide culturally and linguistically appropriate care; 2) language support services, including interpreting services and health information materials in multiple languages; and 3) community outreach efforts to promote awareness of healthcare services and resources available to LEP individuals. Participants will be enrolled across two arms: intervention and control. The intervention group will receive the language access intervention, while the control group will continue to receive standard care. The primary outcome measure is the improvement in blood pressure control among LEP individuals, while the secondary outcome measures include diabetes control, tobacco cessation rates, and overall patient satisfaction. The study will utilize both quantitative and qualitative data

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The goal of this study is to investigate the effect of nitrate supplementation with beetroot juice on blood pressure reduction in hypertensive individuals. Additionally, the impact of nitrate supplementation on blood cholesterol levels, glycemic control, and serum lipids will be explored.METHODS: A randomized, placebo‐controlled, double‐blind design will be used to evaluate the effects of nitrate supplementation in hypertensive individuals. The study will enroll a total of 60 participants (30 healthy controls and 30 participants with hypertension) in the United Arab Emirates. Participant baseline data will be collected, and participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: the treatment group (beetroot juice supplementation) and the placebo group (placebo). Participants will consume the study supplements for 12 weeks. Outcome assessments will include blood pressure monitoring for the treatment group, blood cholesterol analysis, glycemic control assessment, and serum lipid analysis. A p‐value < 0.05 will be considered significant.DISCUSSION: This study aims to establish the impact of beetroot juice supplementation on blood pressure and other related biomarkers in health and hypertensive individuals. The results of this study will contribute to the literature on nitrate supplementation and its effects on cardiovascular health, thus furthering our understanding of the benefits of this approach.TRIAL REGISTRATION: This trial was registered at ClinicalTrials.gov, registration number NCT05372279.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Systolic and diastolic hypertension during pregnancy is a significant public health issue that affects approximately 10% of pregnant women in the United States. The gold standard for lowering blood pressure (BP) in pregnant women is lifestyle modification and antihypertensive medication. However, patients can develop medication resistant hypertension which usually requires addition of multiple antihypertensive drugs or escalation of dosages, sometimes requiring parenteral medication. Non-pharmacologic therapy is an alternative that can be used alone or added to medical therapy. Our group has shown that nitrate-rich beetroot juice is a promising non-pharmacologic approach that modestly lowers BP in a dose dependent manner. In addition to direct vasodilatation through reduction of vascular sympathetic activity, beetroot juice supplementation reduces hypoxia induced vasoconstriction via increase in nitric oxide. This occurs in two ways. First, in hypoxic conditions, endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS) is reduced in the setting of impaired oxidative phosphorylation. Second, reduced endothelial function reduces the availability of l-arginine to eNOS. Supplemental dietary nitrate is believed to act as an alternative electron acceptor, replacing oxygen and thereby restoring oxidative phosphorylation and increasing l-arginine availability to eNOS. The beneficial effects of beetroot juice supplementation on BP may wane when the levels of dietary nitrate in the body are reduced. Therefore, we will test whether increasing maternal dietary nitrate intake as well as monitoring compliance to the dietary nitrate protocol by objective measurements (24 hour monitoring) will improve or maintain its BP lowering effects. Since increased oxidative stress levels is a significant contributory factor for development of preeclampsia

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a prefrontal transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) study exploring the effectiveness of low intensities of current to improve self-reported psychological well-being following stressful testing and treatment procedures.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Objectives: The overall objective is to explore how the stimulation of the prefrontal (i.e., frontopolar) cortex via transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) affects self-reported psychological well-being and performance on a variety of psychosocial and neurocognitive tasks. Participants will complete a battery of tasks both pre- and post- tDCS, including performance on an n-back task, Stroop Interference, verbal fluency, and self-reports of psychological symptoms (anxiety, depression, psychological quality of life, and stress). Results: Findings will be helpful in understanding how tDCS can be used as a neurotherapeutic tool to better manage individuals' symptoms of psychological distress following a stressful procedure.

Abstract:
The REEV SENSE Gait Tracker is a new wearable device that continuously records the 3‐dimensional location of a user's thigh. We present how REEV SENSE gait data compare with a motion capture system. Sixteen able‐bodied individuals walked at constant speed over 200 meters on a treadmill. REEV SENSE calculated 56 gait parameters: 10 kinematic (kin) and 46 kinetic (kin) parameters at 50 Hz, with 20 kin and 34 kin parameters at 125 Hz. The kin parameters were stride length, cadence, stride‐to‐stride (S2S) time, and hip, knee, and ankle joint angles in the sagittal plane. The kin parameters were compared with motion capture data: S2S time, stride length, hip, knee, and ankle angles in the sagittal plane; and moments generated from joint angles and segmental inertia. For S2S time, gait initiation, peak, and flight, the bias (error), relative standard deviation (ratio of error to motion capture data standard deviation), and coefficient of variation (ratio of error to motion capture data mean) were determined. REEV SENSE was within 0.20 cm of motion capture data and had bias ≤ 1%. The relative standard deviation and coefficient of variation were < 0.05. The root‐mean‐square error was < 0.40 cm, except for gait stance near gait termination, where it was < 1.75 cm. For joint angles, the bias, relative standard deviation, and coefficient of variation were < 0.05 degree for most angles per cycle. Kinematics were measured without error; kinetics were measured with bias of < 0.75 N‧m.

Description
=================
In the Netherlands, cardiovascular comorbidity and polypharmacy are common among patients with psoriatic arthritis (PsA). The risk of CVD mortality is higher among PsA patients and is even increased in young patients with early arthritis. In a prospective cohort study among patients with PsA it was demonstrated that a comprehensive assessment of CVD risk in rheumatology practice is of great interest for both patients and rheumatologists and that the uptake of these recommendations can be increased if supported by online tools, education and the use of a patient card. 
At present, cardiovascular drugs are not prescribed in patients with PsA, despite the risk of CVD. In the EU, the prevalence of metabolic syndrome (MetS) is high in PsA patients. Since patients with MetS are 75 times more likely to have a CVD than patients without MetS, the presence of even 1 MetS component may indicate a need for further investigation into individual CVD risk in patients with PsA and/or rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The first step to address this clinical need is to optimize the management of patients with MetS by including an assessment of CVD and CVD comorbidity into routine care in both patients with RA and PsA. 
This is a cluster, randomised, controlled study based on current standard practice in outpatient rheumatology care in the Netherlands. Each participating centre will be randomized into one of two groups. The centers in the intervention arm will be given a protocol and the cardiologist will supervise the data collection and the interpretation of the results. They receive a web-based calculator for CVD risk (CVD-Today) (http://www.cdv-today.com/) and a patient card which contains information about MetS and CVD risk. This will be given to the patients in both arms. After 1 year, the patient card and calculator

OBJECTIVE: To determine the prevalence of adenocarcinoma in resected lobectomy specimens for cancer of the cervix and to compare the demographic and clinical characteristics of these patients with those found to have squamous cell carcinoma.METHODS: The medical records of all patients having a definitive biopsy diagnosis of cervical cancer who underwent surgical resection or conization between 1990 and 2001 were reviewed. Patients with stage IB or IA2 tumors who had lobectomy and underwent conization or loop electrosurgical excision procedure without prior chemoradiotherapy were included in the study.RESULTS: One hundred and ninety‐three patients had invasive carcinoma (92 squamous cell and 101 adenocarcinoma) with a mean age of 45.4 years (range 27‐90). The mean age of patients with adenocarcinoma was significantly higher than that of patients with squamous cell carcinoma (56.3 vs. 45.1 years; P <.05). Most adenocarcinomas (78%) were in stage IA2. Most patients with adenocarcinoma had larger tumors than those with squamous cell carcinoma (mean size 2.62 cm vs. 2.12 cm; P <.05) and higher‐grade disease (90% of adenocarcinoma were grade 2 or 3 compared with 55% of squamous cell carcinoma; P <.05). The histopathologic diagnosis in 8 (8%) patients underwent endometrial sampling at the time of the primary biopsy. Four of these 8 patients (50%) had adenocarcinoma.CONCLUSION: Although adenocarcinoma of the uterine cervix is rare, it is seen more commonly in women older than 55 years. Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to compare the effects of resistance training (RT) and aerobic interval training (AIT) on inflammation in postmenopausal women. We aimed of comparing the change in inflammatory cytokines before and after 7‐weeks of RT (n=13, 57 ± 3 years, BMI= 30 ± 4) and AIT (n=10, 50 ± 4 years, BMI = 31 ± 4) in women (n=23; age=51 ± 2 years, BMI=31 ± 5). We determined the cytokine TNF‐α, IL‐1β, IL‐6 and IL‐8 pre‐exercise (T0), at 24‐hours (T1), 1 week (T2), and 7 weeks (T3). Blood samples were analyzed by Luminex 100 platform (Luminex, Austin, USA). The changes in inflammation were compared using a Student's t‐test for paired comparisons and a linear mixed model for two‐way comparisons (p < 0.05). The results show that the values for TNF‐α, IL‐1β, IL‐6 and IL‐8 at 7‐weeks decreased in both groups, with a significant decrease in the plasma TNF‐α level in the RT group (p ≤ 0.05), a significant decrease for plasma IL‐6 and IL‐8 in the AIT group (p ≤ 0,05) and plasma IL‐8 decreased in the AIT group (p ≤ 0,05). Conclusion: Both interventions were effective in reducing plasma inflammatory cytokines but with different profiles over time.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Acute decompensated heart failure is a common and life‐threatening condition. Current guidelines recommend the use of angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs), angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), beta‐blockers, mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRAs), and diuretics for the treatment of heart failure. However, the benefits of these agents are modest and many patients do not respond adequately. Copaxone is a biosimilar drug that has been shown to have anti‐inflammatory effects in patients with multiple sclerosis. We have recently shown that Copaxone therapy reduces myocardial inflammation and improves hemodynamics in a rat model of heart failure. Therefore, we hypothesize that adjuvant treatment with Copaxone may improve clinical outcomes in patients with acute decompensated heart failure. METHODS/DESIGN: This is a prospective, double‐blind, randomized, placebo‐controlled trial evaluating the efficacy of short‐term Copaxone therapy on patients with acute decompensated heart failure. Patients with decompensated heart failure, NYHA functional class (FC) III or IV, age between 21‐85 years, LVEF between 30‐65% will be randomly assigned to two groups: 1) intervention group to receive Copaxone subcutaneous injection 22 mg/placebo 2.mL (once daily) for the first 3 weeks, 2) control group to receive placebo injection 2.mL (once daily) for the first 3 weeks. All patients will receive standard care with guideline recommended medications, including ACEIs, ARBs, beta‐blockers, MRAs, and diuretics. The primary endpoint of the trial is the change in the levels

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with an increased prevalence of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) but little is known about its role as a risk factor for vascular calcification (VC). We aim to investigate the role of OSA in a cross‐sectional study of hemodialysis (HD) patients with CKD.METHODS: In a post‐hoc analysis of the EPIHEART study, incident CKD patients were recruited, and vascular calcification (VC) was assessed as the occurrence of at least one coronary artery plaque at multislice CT coronary angiography and in the carotid or aortic regions at carotid ultrasound (US). A continuous VC score (VC‐SCORE) was constructed to assess the associations of OSA (identified with a cut‐off value of 14  on the apnea‐hypopnea index (AHI) from a home‐based polysomnography monitoring) with coronary plaque, carotid plaque, and aortic calcification. Inflammation‐related markers were determined and body fat percentage was assessed by DEXA scans. In addition, OSA was analyzed as a risk marker for vascular calcification in CKD patients with and without a history of cardiovascular disease.RESULTS: 183 CKD patients (92 in each group) were included. Mean age at baseline was 69.3 ± 11.3 years, and 64.2% of patients were male. Of these patients, 52.1% had a history of cardiovascular disease. Incidence of coronary plaques was 47.6%, carotid plaques 15.3%) and 74.9% of the subjects experienced coronary calcification. OSA scores with AHI < 14 had higher levels of serum β2‐microglobulin, interleukin‐6, C‐reactive protein, tumor necrosis factor‐alpha

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the PerQdisc Nucleus Replacement System. This device is designed to restore the normal function and height of disc space in order to relieve pain and disability due to painful lumbar disc herniation. The study involves a single intervention and subjects will be followed long-term post-index procedure.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Lumbar interbody fusion (IBF) is considered a gold standard for the treatment of degenerative spinal disorders, even though it has several drawbacks such as loss of mobility and postoperative loss of height of treated segments. Nucleus displacement is considered to be the most common source of failed back syndrome after lumbar fusion. Thus, the development of devices able to both restore disc height, and retain physiological mobility across the treated segment may be necessary to improve fusion outcome. To this aim, new nucleus replacement systems have been recently studied and presented. The PerQdisc concept is based on a spacer made of medical grade Poly-L Lactic Acid (PLLA), designed to restore the intradiscal space and facilitate bony healing in the treated segment. To prevent the loss of height and minimize subsidence rates, this design uses a polymeric device that has a non-constraining structure and a height of up to 7 mm. The PerQdisc Nucleus Replacement System is inserted into the nucleus pulposus of a degenerated disc, under visual control through the microscope. The PLLA spacer is expanded to fit the nucleus pulposus and then compressed mechanically. The spacer expands in the sagittal direction to restore disc height, preserving the flexibility of the intervertebral disc and the physiological movement of the treated segment. As it is made of PLLA, the PerQdisc Nucleus Replacement System undergoes tissue in-growth in the months following application. After implantation, a gradual bioresorption is expected to occur as PLLA

Abstract:
Melanoma is the most deadly form of skin cancer, with mortality rates exceeding those of breast or prostate cancer, and treatment options are limited. This clinical trial tests the efficacy of diallyl trisulfide, the bioactive compound in garlic, for advanced melanoma. Patients with histopathologically confirmed diagnosis of melanoma with liver, lung, or brain metastasis are eligible for this Phase II, open label study at University Hospitals of Cleveland. The minimum dosage is 500 mg of diallyl trisulfide daily, with a tolerable dosage of up to 1500 mg daily. Patients are randomly assigned to one of four groups, and treatment proceeds for up to 24 months or until study drug termination. The primary objective is to determine the efficacy of diallyl trisulfide for advanced melanoma based on overall survival. Secondary objectives include assessment of toxicity associated with diallyl trisulfide treatment, progression free survival, and change in quality of life scores. This trial's primary and two secondary objectives are highly significant because there are no effective chemotherapy or molecular therapy treatments for advanced melanoma. The data that will be produced by this trial should lead to further evaluation of the role of garlic and its derived compounds in the treatment of melanoma.

Abstract:
Introduction: Crohn's disease (CD) is a relapsing and remitting disease which is treated with biologic drugs, among which is infliximab (IFX). Biosimilars are biologic drug products which are similar to an existing biologic in their structure and functions. The aim of this study was to determine the efficacy and safety of a biosimilar form of IFX (b‐IFX, Inflectra®, PT BIS) and to compare it with the innovator product IFX (R‐IFX, Remicade®, JANSSEN). The study tested the hypothesis that b‐IFX, in addition to the standard regimen of IFX, is safe and effective as a treatment for patients with CD who had disease relapse despite IFX treatment. Methods: This was a randomized double‐blinded study conducted on 94 CD patients with a moderate to severe disease activity (CDAI ≥220). Patients were randomly assigned to receive biosimilar IFX (n=53) or innovation IFX (n=44) as a standard regimen (every 8 weeks). The primary endpoint of this study was the clinical response, defined as a CDAI score <150. At Week 26, the efficacy of both drugs (in terms of CDAI and CDAI‐HIBD scores, along with biomarkers, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and fecal calprotectin) and safety data were assessed. Result: After 26 weeks of treatment, the efficacy of both drugs was found to be comparable with CDAI‐remission rates of 66.0% for b‐IFX and 75.0% for R‐IFX. As for safety data, adverse effects such as leucopenia and neutropenia were noted in three patients at baseline. By the end of study, these effects were observed in 4 b‐IFX patients and 5 R‐IFX patients were affected. Additionally, b‐IFX and R‐IFX showed similar

1. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients with metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma (mPDAC) have a poor prognosis with a median survival of about 10 months. The majority of mPDAC patients present with metastatic disease, and in the past few years only three drugs were approved for the treatment of mPDAC: Erbitux® (cetuximab), Gemzar® (gemcitabine hydrochloride), and Tarceva® (erlotinib hydrochloride). Erbitux® and Tarceva® are both monoclonal antibodies approved by the FDA for mPDAC treatment; Gemzar® is an antimetabolite approved for other solid-tumor diseases. The addition of chemotherapy has shown to increase survival by a median of 3-4 months, thus a major unmet therapeutic need remains.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Despite the limited treatment options, the majority of patients treated with available chemotherapeutics benefit from improved survival and tumor response. However, none of the current treatments can achieve an objective tumor response (CR or PR) of 20%, and the median survival benefit in the second line setting is modest (2-3 months). Furthermore, most patients who achieved objective shrinkage of their disease will eventually develop resistance and disease progression. There is an unmet need to treat patients with mPDAC; however, one significant challenge has been the high cost and long treatment times associated with currently available chemotherapeutics. In particular, patients who have progressed on 1 line of therapy (Gemzar®, Erbitux®, or Nab-Paclitaxel) often do not qualify for the second round of treatment because it is too expensive to continue using these therapies alone. Thus, there is an urgent need to identify a lower cost, more efficacious therapy for patients who are unsuitable (e.g. due to financial considerations) for second-line chemotherapy. Additionally, there are increasing efforts to develop novel targeted therapies; however, many of these agents are currently only approved as adjunctive therapy

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to prospectively evaluate the effect of initiating treatment with sGLT2 inhibitor or sGC stimulator on the metabolic and clinical parameters of patients with functional heart failure. The objective is to collect baseline and follow-up information on clinical and metabolic parameters in patients with heart failure who will soon start treatment with gliflozin or i.v. iron.

-----------------
The study will be conducted at a single institution and focus on 60 patients who meet the pre-registered inclusion and exclusion criteria. Baseline and follow-up clinical parameters, including B-type natriuretic peptide, N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide, iron biomarker, and body parameters will be analyzed. The data collected will be used to compare the effects of initiating treatment with sGLT2 inhibitor vs. sGC stimulator on clinical outcomes. Blood samples will be analyzed for sGC activity before and six weeks after starting the treatment.

Study of SGLT2 Inhibitors in Cardiovascular Disease

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study is an observational clinical trial of diabetes patients with a history of heart failure or coronary artery disease undergoing coronary angiography. Patients will be recruited from cardiology wards. We will compare the changes in hematocrit levels in patients prescribed SGLT2 inhibitors to those not prescribed any such medication. We will also analyze the effect of diuretics and beta blockers on hematocrit levels.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Diabetic patients show a higher prevalence of anemia, especially in the presence of kidney problems. Since diabetes is one of the major risk factors for heart disease, diabetic patients also have a higher prevalence of heart failure. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin-receptor blockers, SGLT2 inhibitors, neprilysin inhibitors, beta blockers, diuretics, and digoxin have been established as important treatments for patients with cardiac conditions such as heart failure, hypertension, ischemic heart disease, and diabetic nephropathy. Most of these medications are thought to improve cardiovascular health through their effect on the cardiovascular system, such as by lowering blood pressure, promoting vasodilation, and improving metabolic function. In recent years, SGLT2 inhibitors, which are new medicines, have also been shown to be effective for improving cardiovascular health. Additionally, the effect of SGLT2 inhibitors differs from that of traditional cardiovascular drugs, so it is important to investigate their effect on hematological parameters. In this study, we will examine the changes in hematocrit levels in 50 diabetic Japanese patients who are being treated with SGLT2 inhibitors or traditional cardiovascular drugs, to clarify the association between SGLT2 inhibitors and the prevention of anemia.

Official Title
-----------------
Comparison of the Effect of SGLT2 Inhibitors

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The goal of this trial is to assess the safety and efficacy of Dihydroartemisinin and a fixed dose combination of artesunate and dihydroartemisinin (DHAA/ASA/DHA) in the treatment of uncomplicated Plasmodium vivax malaria. The investigators hypothesis is that Dihydroartemisinin and a fixed dose combination of artesunate and dihydroartemisinin may be more effective in clearance of the malaria parasite and prevention of relapse compared to the currently recommended treatment with artemether-lumefantrine.

Detailed Description
-----------------
A randomized trial will be implemented comparing the efficacy and safety of Dihydroartemisinin and a fixed dose combination of artesunate and dihydroartemisinin (DHAA/ASA/DHA) as single dose treatment with artemether-lumefantrine (AL) as double dose treatment, in uncomplicated P. vivax malaria. A total of 240 participants will be screened and 210 (men and women) eligible patients will be stratified (based on age groups, 2-4 years vs 5-15 years) and randomized to double dose AL or single dose treatment with the Dihydroartemisinin and a fixed dose combination of artesunate and dihydroartemisinin. The dose of AL administered will be artemether 80 mg base plus lumefantrine 320 mg base daily for two consecutive days (4 doses) and the DHA-ASA-DHA dose administered will be DHA-ASA tablets and tablets for DHA 24 mg base daily (single dose) for both groups. The drug administration will be based on weight-class. A 28 days follow-up will be performed to monitor and treat any recurrence with primaquine (15 mg base/kg/day) plus tetracycline (4 mg/kg/day).

Official Title
-----------------
Comparative Clinical Evaluation of the Efficacy and Safety of Dihydroartem

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Background and Purpose: Atrial fibrillation is the most common cardiac arrhythmia. Patients with atrial fibrillation are at high risk for cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. In the past, a new medical therapy with low molecular weight heparins (LMWH) has shown excellent results as anticoagulation in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation (NVAF). The combination of a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) with low dose acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) may offer an alternative to the common therapeutic concept. The DOACs are direct thrombin or factor X inhibitors developed for anticoagulation therapy and are not considered antithrombotic agents. Therefore, the use of an additional antiplatelet drug such as low-dose aspirin has to be considered when planning the combination of DOAC and low-dose aspirin. Despite the fact that the direct thrombin inhibitor dabigatran and the direct factor X inhibitor rivaroxaban have a proven superiority in comparison to conventional therapies for secondary stroke prevention, the current combination of DOAC plus low dose acetylsalicylic acid is still not scientifically evaluated. In addition, the prognostic significance of a switch from warfarin to direct oral anticoagulants has not been evaluated adequately. Aim of the study: The aim of this study is to present a new combination therapy from the current practice, which is the combination of a DOAC plus low-dose acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin 75mg-100mg) for NVAF with a high stroke risk and a history of acetylsalicylic acid monotherapy (> 3 Months) when converting or switching from warfarin to an antagonist. Objective response rate (ORR) is a measure of tumor response in a clinical trial. It refers to the proportion of participants who experience a complete response (CR) or partial response (PR) to the investigational treatment. A CR is a complete disappearance of all signs of cancer, while a PR is a significant reduction in the size of the tumor. A higher ORR indicates that the treatment is effective in inducing a tumor response.

The disease control rate (DCR) is calculated as the proportion of participants who achieve a confirmed complete response (CR), confirmed partial response (PR), or stable disease (SD) for at least six months. Baseline disease status and best overall disease status on study treatment are used to determine DCR. This metric helps us assess how effective BAY2862789 is in controlling disease progression. Abstract:
Background: Background: Immunotherapy has emerged as a promising treatment modality for various cancers and has improved outcomes in many indications. However, there is still a need for more effective immunotherapy options to address the heterogeneity of responders and the development of treatment resistance. Antibody-drug conjugate (ADC) therapy is a novel immunotherapy approach that combines the targeting specificity of monoclonal antibodies with the cytotoxic properties of chemotherapy drugs. BAY2862789 ADC is an investigational immunotherapy agent that targets CD20-expressing B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL), a type of cancer that originates in white blood cells. In previous safety and efficacy studies, BAY2862789 has shown promising results in relapsed or refractory NHL. This article will discuss the outcome measure design for a clinical trial under development for BAY2862789 ADC in relapsed or refractory CD20-positive NHL. Methods: As of March 2023, the protocol for this study is still under development and has not yet been finalized. The objective of this phase I/II study is to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, maximum tolerated dose (MTD), recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D), optimal interval between doses in the phase 1 portion of the study, and efficacy of BAY2862789 in relapsed or refractory CD20-positive NHL. The study will be conducted in both cohorts: 1) a dose escalation cohort to determine the MTD, RP2D, and optimal dose sequence, and 2) a dose expansion cohort to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of BAY2862789 at the RP2D. Safety and tolerability will be assessed based on adverse events (AEs), clinical laboratory tests

Progression-free survival (PFS) at 6 months is measured from the first dose of study treatment until progression (PD) or death (if death occurs before progression is documented). It provides a measure of the time that participants lived without PD or death. PFS at 6 months plays an important role in understanding the duration of response and the impact of treatment on disease progression. 

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and preliminary efficacy of BAY2862789 in participants with advanced solid tumors and malignant ascites. The trial is an open-label, multi-center, dose-escalation study in multiple countries, designed to assess clinical and pharmacological activity of BAY2862789 monotherapy in a group of participants with advanced solid tumors and limited additional treatment options. The study comprises of a Dose Escalation Part and an Expansion Part. Eligible participants will be adults aged 18 years or older. They will provide written informed consent before any study procedures are performed.

Detailed Description
-----------------
In this study, BAY2862789 will be administered orally, once daily, in ascending dose regimen (each dose level in 3 cohorts depending on dose level). In the Dose Escalation Part, dose level escalation will be performed in accordance with a defined algorithm. The Expansion Part of the study will enroll participants in one of the cohorts identified in the Dose Escalation Part as safe and with promising preliminary activity from the Dose Escalation Part. In the Expansion part, participants will receive a fixed dose level of BAY2862789 and will be evaluated for ongoing response. The study will be conducted in multiple countries, and eligible participants will be adults (>18 years) with advanced solid tumors or malignant ascites. Participants should have failed standard treatment options or are ineligible for further standard treatment options. Dose limiting toxicities (DLTs) will be determined by monitoring for adverse events including hematological, gastrointestinal, neurological symptoms, skin changes, and liver injury. Treatment doses will be adjusted or participants will be withdrawn from the study if needed. The

Overall survival (OS) at 12 months is the time from the initiation of study treatment to the date of death of any cause. It helps us assess the overall effect of the treatment on participant survival over a longer period. By measuring OS at 12 months, we can determine how effective BAY2862789 is in prolonging participant survival.

The measures related to the activation of effector T memory cells (CD8+ Teff) and ex vivo stimulated short-term activation of Interleukin 2 (IL2) and interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) are biomarkers that help us understand the underlying immune response to BAY2862789. These biomarkers provide insight into the pharmacodynamic effects of BAY2862789 on the immune system and potential clinical implications.

groundtruth: The number of participants experiencing dose-limiting toxicities at each dose level in the Dose Escalation part of the study helps us determine the maximum tolerated dose of BAY2862789. Dose-limiting toxicities are adverse events that are considered too severe or intolerable to continue treatment. By monitoring these toxicities, we can identify the highest dose that can be safely administered to participants.

The recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) is determined in the expansion part of the study based on multiple parameters, including safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and efficacy. The final decision about the RP2D is made by the Sponsor in consultation with the Investigators. The RP2D represents the dose of BAY2862789 that will be used in future phase 2 studies.

Monitoring the maximum concentration (Cmax) and area under the curve (AUC) of BAY2862789 after single and multiple doses helps us understand the drug's pharmacokinetic profile. Cmax reflects the highest level of the drug in the blood, while AUC represents the total exposure of the drug in the body over time. These measures are important for optimizing dosing regimens and assessing the drug's efficacy and safety.

The secondary outcome measures for this clinical trial include the objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), duration of response (DOR), progression-free survival (PFS) at 6 months, overall survival (OS) at 12 months, activation of effector T memory cells, and ex vivo stimulated short-term activation of Interleukin 2 (IL2) and interferon-gamma. These measures focus on evaluating the efficacy of BAY2862789 in terms of tumor response, disease control, survival outcomes, and immunological effects.

Certainly! The objective response rate (ORR) is defined as the proportion of participants whose best overall response is either a confirmed complete response (CR) or confirmed partial response (PR) according to Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors version 1.1 (RECIST 1.1). ORR helps us assess how effective BAY2862789 is in shrinking or stabilizing tumors.

The disease control rate (DCR) is defined as the percentage of participants whose best overall response was either complete response (CR), partial response (PR), or stable disease (SD). DCR considers the requirement for confirmation of CR and PR. It provides a broader understanding of the treatment's impact on disease control by considering not only tumor shrinkage but also stability.

The duration of response (DOR) is defined as the time from the first documented objective response of PR or CR, whichever occurs earlier, to disease progression or death (if death occurs before progression is documented). It helps us understand how long the treatment's effects last in terms of tumor response. DOR is an important measure of the sustainability of treatment response.

Progression-free survival (PFS) at 6 months measures the time from the start of study treatment to the date of first observed disease progression by investigator assessment or death due to any cause, if death occurs before progression is documented. It provides valuable information on the treatment's ability to delay disease progression for at least 6 months.

Overall survival (OS) at 12 months measures the time from the start of study treatment to death due to any cause. It helps us evaluate the treatment's impact on prolonging overall survival. OS at 12 months provides important information on the long-term benefits of BAY2862789.

Monitoring the activation of effector T memory cells and ex vivo stimulated short-term activation of IL2 and interferon-gamma helps us assess the immunological effects of BAY2862789. These measures provide insights into the drug's impact on T cell activation and cytokine production, which are important for understanding its mechanism of action and potential anti-cancer effects mediated through the immune system.

Study design

Single-center open-label

Description
=================
A pilot study to investigate the feasibility of a randomised controlled trial comparing warm compresses with control, for reducing perineal trauma with a second stage intervention during labour in nulliparous women between 37 and 42 weeks gestation. The study aims to recruit women from the Department of Obstetrics, The Hospital of Guys' and St Thomas' and Kings College London, London. Participants will be approached while they are admitted with a confirmed diagnosis of labor and cervical dilatation of 4 cm or more. All participants will receive conventional pain relief during the first stage on trial, using NICE guidance where epidurals are used. The intervention group will receive an additional intervention of an initial perineal massage followed by warm compresses and perineal massage from 10 cm in the second stage of labor, plus conventional second stage pain relief. The control group will receive the normal standard care. A questionnaire will be used to assess any adverse events, including nausea, vomiting, blood loss, and infections. Women with a previous caesarean or previous forceps or ventouse births, or a diagnosis of placenta praevia will be excluded from the study.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The main objective of this study is to assess the effect of the application of perineal warm compressions during the second stage of labor upon the occurrence of postpartum infections in the vulvo-vaginal region (VVR).

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study will be prospective, randomized, double blind, controlled and non-inferiority, and it will include 226 pregnant women over 18 years of age with a singleton pregnancy, under their first labor, scheduled for vaginal delivery under epidural with dura. Before starting intravenous antibiotic prophylaxis, all patients will have an assessment of the degree of perineal preparation, being classified as 0 (perineal very clean), 1 (perineum very dirty) and 2 (perineum moderately dirty). The application of perineal warm compresses (PWC's) will be made in the second stage of labor for 15 minutes, using a device for this purpose, and in the same time the control group will get a sham, using a device of the same characteristics, but without the hot water system activated. Will be evaluated the occurrence of infection in the region of the VVR (perineum and introitus) before and after the application of PWC's and the control group.

=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of linvoseltamab in patients with high-risk smoldering multiple myeloma. The study will enroll a total of 130 participants who have not been treated for their smoldering multiple myeloma. Participants will receive linvoseltamab every 4 weeks for a maximum of 36 weeks. The study will evaluate the overall response rate to linvoseltamab and assess the proportion of participants who achieve a complete response (defined as disappearance of the serum M-protein, normalization of the involved free light chain ratio along with bone marrow plasma cell reduction or bone marrow plasma cells less than or equal to 1%), as determined by the investigator. The study will also measure the time to progression to multiple myeloma and overall survival.

-----------------
Participants in this open-label, Phase 2, multiple-dose study will receive linvoseltamab every 4 weeks for a maximum of 36 weeks, or until disease progression, withdrawal of consent, initiation of treatment for multiple myeloma, or unacceptable toxicity, whichever occurs first. The study will enroll a total of 92 participants, 73 participants from the US, and 19 participants from outside of the US. Eligibility criteria include: participants with high-risk smoldering multiple myeloma; participants who are treatment-naive; participants with an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status ≤ 2; and participants with adequate organ function. Participants will be screened for eligibility, including a physical examination, medical history review, and laboratory tests. Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
The main purpose of the study is to describe the safety and efficacy of the GBT140 phase I clinical trial program to treat multiple myeloma.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Given that multiple myeloma (MM) is a disease of the bone marrow, the treatment strategy is based on the principle of high-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation. The primary reason for combining thalidomide (T) and dexamethasone (D) with chemotherapy is an attempt to increase response rates, improve duration of remission, improve overall survival, and minimize treatment-related toxicities, with the latter being a critical factor in the treatment of MM due to the age-associated physiologic decline and the presence of comorbid conditions in older patients.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a Phase 3, randomized, open label, non-comparative clinical trial to assess the immunogenicity of G100 following the primary series of immunization in infants aged 6 to 12 weeks of age. All subjects will have received one dose of licensed vaccine for protection against group B meningococcal disease (MenB) (Neisseria meningitidis strain MenAB) at 12 weeks of age. Subjects will be randomized in a 1:1:1 ratio to receive either active G100 vaccine or a dose containing adjuvant alone. A total of three doses of G100 or adjuvant alone will be given. Subjects will be observed for four weeks for safety evaluations. Safety and immunogenicity results of the primary series immunization will be evaluated.

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study will compare how well different types of surgery work to help control high blood pressure and high blood flow in the kidney.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Hypertension is associated with kidney injury and increased risk of kidney failure. Hypertension and kidney disease lead to increased risk for stroke, brain cell damage, and even death. Surgical techniques offer a possible treatment for high blood pressure. These include nephrectomy and nephroligament ligation. This study will compare how well these procedures work to control blood pressure. The results of the study may provide useful information about using surgical techniques to treat high blood pressure in patients with kidney disease.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to treat the ascending aorta with the St Jude Medical TCX CVR TM Aortic Arch Device during an initial staged endovascular descending thoracic aortic replacement. The hypothesis is that the aortic arch will remain patent, that the patient will have a functional aortic valve, and that the aortic stent-graft placement will be the single stent-graft procedure required to achieve long term sealing. The following measures of efficacy will be collected: 1) Successful stent graft coverage of the aortic arch branch vessels including but not limited to aneurysm repair or aortic arch replacement 2) Freedom from branch vessel-related end-organ ischemia related to device embolization

Detailed Description
-----------------
This pilot study's primary aim is to evaluate the safety and feasibility of the first generation self-expanding stent graft in the ascending aorta without the use of branched grafts in a small number of anatomically similar patients. A secondary aim is to confirm the accuracy of the currently used end-organ imaging protocols by using standardized imaging protocols.

Study design
This study is a prospective study. The study will involve two stages. Stage 1 will consist of three rounds of qualitative interviews with participants who have received the counseling tool. Eligible participants will be identified by their health care provider, and the study team will reach out directly to them. The study population and recruitment method for the post-trial evaluation will be the same as that for the intervention. In stage 2, eligible participants will include Black or African American men with metastatic prostate cancer who have utilized the intervention during the trial period.

The inclusion criteria for the post-trial evaluation will be the same as those for the intervention. Participants must be willing to participate in post-trial interviews and provide the required data for the evaluation. The study will not exclude participants based on their willingness to participate in the follow-up interviews. The study team will make every effort to ensure participation is possible for all eligible participants. 
1. Stage 2: data collection

The interviews will be audio-recorded, transcribed, and analyzed using a qualitative framework approach. The first round of interviews will focus on pre-intervention experiences and perceptions, while the second and third rounds will explore post-intervention experiences and perceptions. The transcripts will undergo thematic analysis to identify behavior change models and techniques that are likely to be effective in promoting engagement with genetic testing options. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The current prospective exploratory study aims to analyse possible changes in the gait pattern after gait training in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) or Parkinsonism.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The study aims to quantify the extent and variability of the gait pattern in PD and its response to physiotherapeutic therapy over the course of three months. These data should provide clues as to how the graft (or graft) can be improved by physical therapy. This knowledge may be able to be used to individualise therapy and improve the patient's quality of life. The gait pattern was characterized by means of 555 recordings of the three-dimensional movement of the lower extremities of eight subjects (four with Parkinson's disease and four healthy subjects) in a laboratory environment. Gait was measured before therapy and after three months of exercise therapy. During the three months, the patients performed three different types of therapy, which alternated monthly. Each training session lasted 15 minutes and was complemented by a stretching program.

Official Title
-----------------
The Influence of Gait Training on Walking Patterns in Parkinson's Disease

Conditions
-----------------
Parkinson's Disease (PD)

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Behavioral: Exercise training

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Recurrent pregnancy morbidity is associated with long-term sequelae and increased morbidity and mortality, although in many cases, the origin remains unknown. One of the most well-described causes is endometritis, an inflammatory process that can be associated with various symptoms, such as an abnormal uterine bleeding and pelvic pain, affecting between 9-17% of pregnancies. The term asymptomatic bacterial vaginosis (BV) is used when there is positive detection of anaerobes in the vaginal flora regardless of clinical findings (without purulent cervicitis or Puerperal infection), a normal vaginal pH ≥4.5, but also the presence of clinical symptoms such as vaginal discharge and perineal pain during sexual intercourse. The investigators hypothesize that asymptomatic endometritis diagnosed from a sample taken during post-pardum bleeding has long-term implications for reproductive health. The aim of this study is to analyze the impact of asymptomatic bacterial vaginosis, determined by polymerase chain reaction (PCR), on the risk of endometritis, the risk of reproductive morbidity and to determine possible reproductive and maternal effects of asymptomatic bacterial vaginosis. The investigators will compare the risk of reproductive morbidity after the presence of asymptomatic bacterial vaginosis (confirmed by PCR) in cases of recurrent pregnancy; also, they will compare the characteristics of the endometritis of pregnancy; histological findings; characteristics of post-cesarean endometritis; pregnancy follow-up and post-cesarean sequelae related to the presence of asymptomatic bacterial vaginosis and the association between the post-surgical course and possible pelvic reproductive sequelae.

4. Ethics and Dissemination
=================
4.1 Ethics
All study participants will provide written informed consent and assent as appropriate. The study will adhere to the tenets of the Declaration of Helsinki and the clinical study will be conducted in accordance with and comply with the FDA Good Clinical Practice (GCP) Guidelines and all applicable regulatory requirements. The study was approved by the institutional review board (IRB) of Ain Shams University (IRB#1101708).
4.2 Dissemination plans
The interventional results will be disseminated via peer-reviewed publications in the form of scientific articles in high impact peer-reviewed journals. The research team will also present the results at local, regional, and international medical conferences. The results will be shared with healthcare practitioners and relevant healthcare organizations to ensure the dissemination of evidence-based practice. The study team will share the outcomes with patients and their families to improve patient safety and provide healthcare providers with information on potential adverse effects. Intervention Description:: The study will consist of three parts. In the first part, we will characterize the expression profiles of Che-1 in normal plasma and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) of healthy volunteers and patients with MM. To obtain a comprehensive understanding of the expression profile of Che-1, we will use gene expression profiling, whole exome sequencing, whole genome sequencing, and single-cell transcriptomics.
In the second part, we will examine the binding patterns and association with chromatin remodeling of Che-1 in both normal plasma and PBMC of healthy volunteers and patients with MM. We will utilize ChIP-seq and Hi-C technology to conduct these analyses.
In the third part, we will use CRISPR-Cas9 technology to assess the importance of Che-1 in oncogenesis and explore the underlying molecular mechanisms. We plan to use patient-derived stem-like MM cells to establish xenotransplantation models and examine the impact of Che-1 depletion.
We will use the data collected from these three parts to determine the importance of Che-1 in chromatin remodeling and global gene expression in MM. We believe this study will advance our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the pathogenesis of MM and identify potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of MM.

Use CRISPR-Cas9 technology to assess the importance of Che-1 in oncogenesis

Primary Outcome Measure:
1. Albumin degradation rate by stable isotope:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure aims to determine the catabolic rate of albumin by measuring the disappearance rate of 2H5-phenylalanine labeled albumin over time in blood samples. It will be compared between patients with liver disease and healthy volunteers.
   - Time Frame: The albumin degradation rate will be measured over a period of 12 weeks.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Albumin synthesis rate:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure involves comparing the oral flooding dose with historical controls where the isotope was given intravenously to measure albumin synthesis rates in volunteers and patients with liver disease.
   - Time Frame: The albumin synthesis rate will be assessed within 120 minutes after the administration of the stable isotope labeled amino acid.

2. Albumin degradation by modeling different fractions of oxidized albumin over time:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure aims to investigate the relationship between oxidation and degradation of albumin by modeling different fractions of oxidized albumin over a period of 12 weeks.
   - Time Frame: The modeling of albumin degradation based on oxidized fractions will be conducted over a 12-week period.

3. Correlation between oxidation and degradation rate of albumin:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure seeks to determine if there is a correlation between oxidation fraction and albumin degradation rate, particularly in patients with liver disease over 12 weeks.
   - Time Frame: The correlation between oxidation and degradation rate of albumin will be assessed over a 12-week period.

Abstract:
Dyspepsia is a syndrome that includes symptoms such as abdominal discomfort, pain, nausea, feeling of distension and bloating and has a wide variety of causes, including organic and functional disorders. The diagnosis is based on the identification of an underlying pathology through a detailed medical history, physical examination, laboratory tests and, in some cases, endoscopy. Patients with uninvestigated dyspepsia will usually be assessed for Helicobacter pylori infection, which can be treated with antibiotics followed by endoscopy to rule out malignancy. In general, dyspepsia is managed with lifestyle changes, dietary modifications, and the use of antacids or proton pump inhibitors. However, some patients may require additional treatments, such as antispasmodics, antidepressants, or 5‐HT3 receptor antagonists. Treatment options will depend on the underlying cause and symptoms. In conclusion, uninvestigated dyspepsia is a common symptom requiring a thorough evaluation to identify the underlying cause and manage the signs and symptoms. Patients should be assessed for Helicobacter pylori infection, and treatment strategies should be based on the etiology and symptoms. A tailored approach, incorporating lifestyle modifications, pharmacological treatments, and referral to specialist if necessary, will result in the best patient outcomes.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
The goal in this research study is to improve health and well-being in women with cancer.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study will be recruiting patients at MD Anderson, a top 3 ranked hospital by U.S. News & World Report. Half of these patients will be randomly placed into one of two groups. For those in the experimental group, the investigators will invite 20% of women within 3 months of their hospital visit to share their feedback in a series of interviews. For those in the second group, the investigators will not do any interviews. The investigators will learn from survey responses to develop ways to provide patients information they need for their care, tailored to their preferences. The investigators predict that more women will receive tailored information, which will improve their health and well-being as a result. The investigators will follow-up with participants one month after they share their opinions and will also send them surveys to track their health. This will help the investigators understand how the information they share influences patients over time. The investigators will look at differences between the study groups to make sure study methods do not affect patient care.

Abstract:
Background: The number of patients with multiple risk factors for chemotherapy‐induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) is increasing as more patients receive platinum‐based cancer chemotherapy. However, the current understanding of the effects of multiple factors on the risk of CIPN is limited.Methods: Using data from a randomized clinical trial and a large observational cohort study, we evaluated patients with multiple risk factors for CIPN and quantified the effect of each risk factor on the risk of CIPN.Results: In this study, we evaluated 215 patients in the PLAN‐AHEAD clinical trial (arm A) and 580 patients with non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and multiple risk factors for CIPN (CIPN+) from a large observational cohort study. The most common risk factors for CIPN were male sex (70.3%), diabetes (60.2%), pre‐existing neuropathy (48.5%), and concomitant antiviral (47.6%) and antidiabetic (34.5%) medications. The presence of concomitant antiviral medications (65% vs. 30%, P=0.01), pre‐existing neuropathy (52% vs. 40%, P=0.05), and concomitant medications for Parkinson's disease and rheumatoid arthritis (26% vs. 16%, P=0.01) was associated with an increased adjusted risk of CIPN. In addition, the occurrence of CIPN+ in patients prescribed cisplatin+pemetrexed and cisplatin+gemcitabine (the regimens with the highest incidence of CIPN) was 21% and 10%, respectively. Conclusions: These results support an increased risk of CIPN in patients with metastatic non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and multiple potential risk factors. (Figure Presented).
