Abstract:
Erectile dysfunction (ED) is a common comorbidity in men with both prostate cancer (PCa) and coronary artery disease (CAD). However, whether ED is affected by different modes of PCa treatment (radical prostatectomy or radiation therapy) remains unclear. Moreover, there have been few studies on the correlation between ED after PCa treatment and various CAD clinical factors or their effect on the prognosis of men with CAD after PCa treatment. We investigated this correlation between ED after PCa treatment and CAD clinical factors, especially the effect of PCI during hospitalization. We retrospectively analyzed the correlation between the presence of ED/hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) during and two‐year follow‐up after radical prostatectomy or radiation therapy and 14 factors related to PCa treatment and/or CAD severity. The incidence of ED/HSDD after PCa treatment was significantly higher among patients who had received PCI during hospitalization (50.0% vs. 14.3%; p = 0.001). Multiple logistic regression analysis revealed that the factors with significant differences in the incidence of ED/HSDD after PCa treatment were age ≥75 years at operation/baseline (OR 5.6, 95% C.I. [2.0‐15.6]; p = 0.001), preoperative transcutaneous troponin‐T (cTnT) level >99th percentile (OR 6.9, 95% C.I. [1.6‐30.7]; p = 0.02), and PCI during hospitalization (OR 3.8, 95% C.I. [1.5‐9.7]; p = 0.007). Furthermore, 4‐year AMI‐free survival in patients with PCI during hospitalization was significantly lower than that without PCI (p = 0.02). In summary, PCI during hospitalization is associated with a higher incidence of HSDD and ED after PCa treatment and may be a risk factor for AMI‐related death in these patients.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: In order to investigate the effect of a patient‐directed online information system (the Swedish Health Nutshell at www.vagnsark.se, in Swedish) on patient satisfaction, the number of questions asked in the patient encounter and referrals to other healthcare workers, we used an experimental design with a randomised control group. Aim: To investigate the effects of patient‐ directed online information system on patient satisfaction, the number of questions asked in the patient encounter and when patients request consultations. METHODS: A randomised controlled trial was conducted in a primary‐care clinic in Stockholm between August and November 2010. Consecutive patients aged 18 to 55 years were randomised to either an experimental group that received access to the patient‐directed online information system; or a control group where no information system was available. Data was collected during preliminary visits using an observation questionnaire and interviews at post‐visit with questions regarding patient satisfaction and reasons for requests. RESULTS: A total of 237 patients answered the questionnaire and 44 in the information group and 48 in the control group answered the post‐visit interview. A significantly higher number of patients in the information group answered the questions asked by the doctor correctly. The information group scored significantly higher on the questionnaires regarding understanding the patient encounter, the information provided on the Internet, and the ability to provide the doctor with relevant information. Significant differences were also found between the patient groups regarding the requests made by the patients. CONCLUSIONS: The study shows that the use of a patient‐directed online information system in general practice contributes to increased patient satisfaction and a more efficient patient encounter. The patient‐ directed information system seems to facilitate patient empowerment. Regardless of intervention, an increased number of patients were given telephone consultations.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to assess if the use of a nasal CPAP device (BreatheEasy® Nasal Device), improves quality of life (QOL) in adults who have both obstructive sleep apnea (OSAS) and hypertension (HTN). This is a randomized, cross-over design study. It will require 2 hospitalizations for a medical evaluation and 1 for an overnight sleep study. Subjects will be in a hospital setting for the first 3 days, in an outpatient clinic setting for a total of 3 days and overnight stay in the hospital. Participants will be asked to wear a nasal CPAP device from a medical supply company at home for 2 weeks and then return the device and undergo an overnight sleep study to test how well the CPAP device works for them. They will also wear the CPAP device at home for another 2 weeks and return the device and undergo an overnight sleep study again. They may keep the device to use at home following the second study if their sleep study demonstrates significant sleep apnea. The study is expected to last approximately 10-12 weeks.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of AND017 in children with idiopathic (not caused by a known disease) myelofibrosis (MF). The study will assess the effects of three different oral doses of AND017 for 7 days on Hgb (hemoglobin), the number of red blood cells (RBCs), and the level of iron in the blood (serum iron), in children with MF.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Idiopathic myelofibrosis (iMF) is a common bone marrow disorder in childhood, causing a drop in the production of blood cells. Anemia is the most common blood disorder associated with iMF. The main aim of this study is to evaluate and compare the safety and efficacy of three different doses of AND017 over 7 days in children with iMF aged 3 to <18 years. AND017 is a new pharmaceutical iron compound that may potentially stimulate red blood cell (RBC) production by increasing iron absorption in the body. A total of 21 children will be enrolled in the study and divided into three dose groups, each comprising seven children. Children enrolled in this study will first receive a maximum of four weeks of standard medical care under the supervision of local physicians. This period will be used to obtain baseline values, which are the data collected before starting the study. Following standard medical care, participants will then enter the dosing phase of the study, where they will be assigned to one of the three dose groups and receive daily doses of either 1, 10, or 100 mg oral iron supplement with AND017 for 7 days. After completing the daily dose of AND017, participants will proceed to the end of the dosing phase and return for a post-dosing assessment. The safety and efficacy of each dose group will be evaluated at the end of the study. Abstract:
The aim of our study was to determine the effect of pre‐operative ketamine on the inflammatory cytokine profiles and post‐operative systemic inflammatory responses after major knee operations. This prospective, randomized, double‐trial was conducted in our hospital on 98 patients who underwent major knee arthroplasty. On the day of surgery, 49 patients received 0.5 mg/kg ketamine, and the other 49 patients served as the control group. In both groups, plasma IL‐6, IL‐8, TNF‐α, and C‐reactive protein (CRP) concentration were determined on the day of surgery, on days 1, 3, and 7 post‐operatively. The pre‐operative and post‐operative inflammatory mediator levels in blood were not significantly different when the entire cohort was compared between the groups. Additionally, significant differences in the CRP levels were detected among all four groups, suggesting that ketamine might have an effect on the systemic inflammatory responses after major knee operations. To our knowledge, this was the first study to examine the anti‐inflammatory effects of pre‐operative ketamine on the post‐operative inflammatory responses after major knee operations. The results suggested that pre‐operative ketamine plays an important role in attenuating the elevation of systemic inflammatory responses after major knee operations.

Study Overview

Brief Summary

This study is designed to evaluate the long-term efficacy, safety, and tolerability of repeat administration of subtherapeutic doses of G-CSF [Filgrastim] to healthy subjects during repeat weekly dosing for 16 consecutive weeks and will enable dose finding in healthy subjects to inform future studies with subjects with cancer.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study is divided in two parts A and B (Safety Cohort A & Dose Escalation Cohort B). Part A will assess the safety and tolerability of single and repeated doses of G-CSF in healthy subjects while Part B will determine the maximum dose level that does not result in significant neutropenia for the proposed multiple repeat dosing regimen of G-CSF. In Part A, multiple rising doses of subtherapeutic 50, 300, 500 or 800 micrograms/kg as an infusion will be administered to groups of six healthy subjects each. Part A will be followed by Part B, in which multiple rising doses of subtherapeutic G-CSF will be administered in ascending doses from 1000 to 8000 ug/ day to six subjects per cohort. Subjects will be withdrawn from the study if any subject develops severe neutropenia, defined by an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) of <0.5 x 109/L. Neutropenia is a form of neutropaenia characterized by low neutrophil counts within the blood. In subjects who reach severe neutropenia, additional ANC and differential counts as well as hematology and chemistry analyses will be performed, and bone marrow aspirates and samples may be obtained as specified by the investigator. Abstract:
STUDY OBJECTIVE: To investigate the relationship of the cardiac biomarker high‐sensitivity troponin T (hs‐TnT) with renal function among adults with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and to evaluate the impact of interventions on hs‐TnT levels.METHODS: We used data of 409 patients with CKD stage 1‐4 from a randomized controlled trial evaluating a home‐based intervention to improve lifestyle behaviors. Multivariate linear regression models were used to examine associations between hs‐TnT (categorical analysis at a cut point of 14 pg/mL), estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR), and diet, exercise, and smoking behaviors evaluated at baseline and follow‐up (3 and 12 months).RESULTS: We observed that a higher baseline hs‐TnT level was associated with a decrease in eGFR (P=.038). However, hs‐TnT did not independently contribute to the regression model including age, sex, race, urinary albumin/creatinine ratio, body mass index, and cardiovascular disease diagnosis (P=.433). There was an association between hs‐TnT level at follow‐up and a greater change in eGFR in those randomized to the intervention.CONCLUSIONS: High hs‐TnT levels were associated with lower eGFR values, although the association was no longer significant after adjusting for important confounders. Higher hs‐TnT levels were associated with greater improvements in renal function among patients who received an intervention to improve diet, exercise, and smoking habits. These findings support the potential importance of troponin in the assessment of CKD patients for screening and monitoring purposes.

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary goal of this study is the assessment of efficacy (measured by serum zinc level and urinalysis for zinc metabolism markers) and safety (measured by adverse events) of pre-operative administration of zinc sulfate on post-operative outcomes (complications due to surgery, length of stay, and duration of antibiotic use) in pediatric patients with Hirschsprung's disease undergoing open, transanal endorectal pull-through (TERP). The secondary goal is to investigate the role of zinc supplementation on fecal microbiota of pediatric patients with Hirschsprung's disease by 16S ribosomal RNA microbial sequencing. Our hypothesis is that preoperative oral zinc supplementation during the preoperative period can modulate children's intestinal microbiome, leading to beneficial postoperative outcomes. Thus, we will evaluate the preoperative effects of zinc supplementation on complications, length of hospital stay, and duration of antibiotic use.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Hirschsprung's Disease is a congenital intestinal motor disorder caused by the absence of ganglion cells on the distal bowel. It is characterized by dysfunction in gut motility due to decreased secretion of acetylcholine on the intestinal wall. This dysfunction is one of the most important causes of enterocolitis in the pediatric population and is associated with gastrointestinal diseases. Surgery is the primary method of treatment; however, it may lead to significant complications. The prevalence and frequency of complications vary among the literature. The most common complications are ileus, dehiscence, sepsis, and peritonitis. Severe neonatal sepsis, especially in young infants, is highly correlated with high mortality in the perioperative period. In this randomized clinical trial, children with Hirschsprung's disease will be included, and a randomized controlled clinical trial will be performed to investigate the effects of oral zinc supplementation in patients undergoing TERP operation.

Abstract
=================

Background
-----------------
Zinc (Zn) plays an important role in immune function, intestinal function, and wound healing, while zinc deficiency (ZnD) is associated with multiple surgical outcomes affecting immune function, gastrointestinal function, and wound healing. Many patients with Hirschsprung's disease (HS) have nutritional deficits due to malabsorption and poor appetite. The nutritional condition could aggravate the patient's postoperative recovery. This prospective, single-center, open clinical trial aimed to evaluate the efficacy of zinc supplementation in improving postoperative recovery and outcomes in children with HS undergoing surgical interventions.

Objective
-----------------
To evaluate the role and efficacy of zinc preparations in the treatment and prevention of postoperative complications in children with HS.

Design
-----------------
The study designed a single-arm, open-label, parallel controlled clinical trial on children with Hirschsprung's disease undergoing transanal endorectal pull-through surgery. The zinc group was comprised of children who received zinc supplementation before surgery, while the control group only had routine nursing care.

Methods
-----------------
In this prospective, single-center, open clinical trial, a total of 50 children with HS undergoing elective transanal endorectal pull-through surgery were included from February 2023 to January 2024 with two years as the follow-up time. The zinc group and the control group included 25 patients

Abstract:
To assess the quality of life in patients with major depressive disorder after an effective antidepressant intervention: a randomized controlled trial.METHODS: 91 adults with DSM‐IV major depressive disorder (not psychotic, severe melancholic or bipolar) were assessed at assessment (T1), then in three times at follow‐up: 1st month (T2), 3rd month (T3) and 12 months (T4). Treatment was antidepressant drug discontinuation (control group) or continuity of medication during 12 months (intervention group). A battery of quality of life assessment scales were used, including a new scale for measuring the quality of life in patients with major depressive disorders (QLMDD).RESULTS: 74 completers (QLMDD only) were included at follow‐up. Statistically significant differences between groups in favor of continuity of medication were found on the QLMDD only at T3 and T4. These differences involved all QLMDD scales. Scores on all WHOQOL scales improved significantly at T4 compared with T1. Statistically significant improvements, involving all scales, were also observed in favor of intervention regarding mental health. The WHOQOL scores did not significantly differ between groups. The QLMDD scores were significantly related to some sociodemographic and clinical variables, such as higher age, marital status, higher education level, less suicidal ideation, lower scores on somatization symptoms and lower severity of depression. The WHOQOL scores were significantly correlated with the QLF scales with higher quality of life.CONCLUSION: Antidepressant continuity was the best predictor of quality of life in patients with major depressive disorders.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) replacement is increasingly used in patients with high‐grade osteoarthritis of the knee and failed ACL reconstruction. To date, no clinical trials have determined whether ACL replacement improves the outcome of total knee arthroplasty (TKA). Our primary aim was to determine whether ACL replacement was associated with improved clinical outcome compared to primary TKA in patients with osteoarthritis and unfixed ACL. Our secondary objectives were to compare the change in the International Cartilage Repair Society (ICRS) score and Oxford Knee Score (OKS) between groups; to assess the rates of component failure, complications, and reoperations between groups; and to compare patient satisfaction and level of activity between groups.METHODS: We performed a retrospective review of 148 patients who had primary TKA between July 2007 and July 2015 with preoperative documentation of unstable ACL (ACLTKA) and 148 patients who had primary TKA between July 2007 and July 2015 without previous ACL tear and repair (CTRL). The groups were matched for age and gender. The primary outcome was change in ICRS score and OKS, which are validated measures of function following ACL reconstruction. Patient‐reported outcomes (score of 10) and radiographic parameters at the last known follow‐up were also collected.RESULTS: The TKA patients in the ACLTKA cohort had greater improvement in OKS and ICRS score compared to the CTRL cohort (both P < 0.0001). Abstract:
Posterior fossa meningioma is a subgroup of extra‐axial brain tumors that have distinct biologic behaviors. The aim of this study is to assess the clinical characteristics and outcomes for posterior fossa meningioma patients treated at a large, cancer‐specialty institution. Methods: A retrospective review of the medical records of 54 consecutive patients with primary or recurrent posterior fossa meningioma treated at our institution from January 2000 to December 2016 was performed. The clinical presentation, surgical management, and tumor‐related and operative‐related complications were assessed. Results: The mean age of the cohort was 55.04 years (range: 34‐80 years). There were 56 primary tumors and 8 recurrent tumors. Thirty‐seven (68.5%) patients were female. Signs and symptoms at presentation were headache (33.3%), cranial nerve palsy (18.5%), ataxia (16.7%), dizziness (13.0%), diplopia (9.3%), hemiparesis (4.5%), and nausea and vomiting (4.5%). Twenty‐five (45.6%) patients underwent total gross resection, 12 (21.5%) underwent subtotal resection and 17 (30.5%) underwent non‐surgical management. Four (7.3%) patients eventually underwent total or subtotal resection after a previously failed attempt. The median post‐operative follow‐up time was 17 months (range: 3–85 months). Forty‐seven (85.5%) patients remained free of recurrence, which was determined by radiological follow‐up. One patient progressed during follow‐up, and one patient developed a new meningioma without prior radiation therapy. The 5‐year progression‐free survival was 96.8% and the overall survival was 100%. No patient experienced a death due to complications from the tumor and/or surgery. The overall complication rate was 11.1%. The most common complications

Brief summary
=================
The purpose of this study is to explore the glycemic response to commercially available starches and their effect on glucose tolerance in humans. Specifically, this study aims to compare the postprandial glycemic response of 2 starches that have been extensively processed (Extrusion Processed Starch) to a native starch (Commercial Native Starch), as well as their effect on glucose tolerance in humans.Study participants will fast overnight and visit the research centre on two separate occasions. On each visit, participants will consume a standard breakfast, which will vary between the two visits only in the starch type ingested. Blood samples will be collected before and for 3 hours after the ingestion of the starch, and blood glucose levels will be measured. Participants will not be allowed to consume other foods during the study visits.The extrusion processed starch is commonly used in the food industry and has been shown to have a lower glycemic response compared to commercial native starches. The commercial native starch is used in a variety of foods and beverages, including baked goods, sauces, and processed meats. This study seeks to compare the postprandial glycemic response of these two starch types and determine whether there is a difference in their effect

We also want to assess gastrointestinal tolerance, satiety, and satiation. We'll compare the two forms of starch based on ratings of tolerance, fullness, and desire to eat, as reported by the participants using validated questionnaires. We'll also assess the effects of both starches on cardiometabolic health, including postprandial lipemia and vascular function.

Background
=================
The incidence of sarcoidosis is rising globally, with estimates of 5 to 10 new cases per 100,000 people per year (1). Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology that primarily affects the lungs. Diagnosis of pulmonary sarcoidosis often requires a high level of suspicion and exclusion of other conditions, with histological confirmation being the gold standard (2). However, obtaining accurate bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) samples from patients with fibrotic changes or non-specific bronchiectasis can be challenging, limiting the diagnostic yield (3).
Tissue sampling via endoscopic bronchial biopsy can provide critical insights into the diagnosis of pulmonary sarcoidosis, but it is technically challenging and poses a risk of complications (4). Additionally, traditional endoscopic methods such as transbronchial biopsy (TBB) or transbronchial lung cryobiopsy (TLB) may not reach peripheral lesions (5). Therefore, peripheral airway biopsies (PABs) have gained attention as an alternative procedure that may provide better diagnostic yields and reduce the risk of complications (6). 
Recent studies have shown promising outcomes with PABs in detecting granulomatous inflammation in peripheral non-cavitating lesions (7). Furthermore, the use of cryoprobes, which allow a more accurate and deeper analysis of the sample, has further improved diagnostic yields (8). However, studies on the use of PABs in different patient populations and clinical scenarios are limited, specifically on patients with pulmonary fibrosis. 
Therefore, the goal of this study is to investigate the diagnostic yield of peripheral airway biopsies with the use of cryobiopsy to detect granulomatous inflammation in patients with pulmonary sarcoidosis, using BAL fluid sample as a control. The

Intervention
=================
Intervention group: Patient will receive one-on-one coaching and counselling and will be asked to follow the intervention for two months. The intervention consists of a personalized tailoring of the current treatment by the treating physician. This intervention will contain general information on lifestyle changes needed, information on heart failure and related symptoms (both physical and emotional), and information on the most recent heart failure guideline for people with heart failure. In addition, the intervention will contain specific information about how to make lifestyle changes (e.g. physical activity, diet, alcohol, and smoking).

Behavioural

Hospitalization due to heart failureReadmission due to heart failureReferrals to outpatient clinic for heart failure readmission

Healthcare utilization

Participant inclusion criteria
=================
1. 18-years or older
2. Known diagnosis of ischaemic heart and/or reduced left ventricular (LV) ejection fraction (≤30%)
3. At least one hospitalization due to heart failure or referral to outpatient clinic for heart failure in the past year
4. Treatment of heart failure should have started at least three months ago
5. No concomitant severe medical illness (e.g. cancer) that prevents compliance with the planned intervention
6. Adequate understanding of the relevant language and ability to complete questionnaires
7. Living in the community (home-based)
8. Currently stable condition
9. Provided informed consent

The second measure is the Patient Global Impression of Change scale. This measures the participant's perception of changes in their pain intensity over the past four weeks, using a 7-point scale. The scale ranges from 'very much improved' to 'very much worse', with a score of 'no change'. This measure has been shown to have good reliability and validity in knee osteoarthritis, making it a reliable and accurate instrument for measuring participant perception of pain intensity change. We can administer it at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is the Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS). This measure assesses knee-related activities, pain, function in daily living, and quality of life. The next measure is the Timed Up-and-Go Test (TUG). This measures the time taken to rise from a seated position, walk a distance of 3 meters, turn, walk back to the chair, and sit down. It is a simple and reliable test that can assess functional mobility in people with knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months. 

The next measure is the Short Form-36 (SF-36). This is a validated self-report questionnaire that evaluates health-related quality of life in people with knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is the Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC). This measures the overall improvement or deterioration in subjective health experienced by the patient over time. It provides valuable information on the perception of the intervention by the patient. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months. 

Finally, we will also be assessing biomarkers of inflammation and oxidative stress at 9 weeks and 3 months. We will use a multiplex assay to do this, which involves measuring a range of biomolecules in the blood. This will give us insights into the biological effects of the intervention. 

Overall, these outcome measures provide comprehensive and multidimensional assessment of the intervention's effectiveness in managing the symptoms and improving the quality of life of adults with knee osteoarthritis. groundtruth: Great. Now, let's move on to designing the outcome measures. We can start with the primary outcome measure. Do you have any ideas for the primary outcome measure?

That's a great suggestion. The percentage of complete follow up is crucial to determine the overall feasibility of the intervention and study design. We can measure the percentage rate of those who complete the study follow-up measures at 9 weeks and 3 months. This will provide valuable information on the reliability of the results obtained.

Absolutely. Let's go through the secondary outcome measures one by one. The first measure is the Brief Pain Inventory - Numeric Rating Scale. This measure assesses pain intensity by asking about worst and least pain intensity in the past 24 hours, pain on average, and pain right now. It uses an 11-point scale, with zero representing 'no pain' and 10 representing the 'worst imaginable pain'. This measure has been shown to have excellent reliability and validity in people with knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is the Modified Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI). This measure assesses the presence of comorbidities in participants, including knee osteoarthritis. The CCI has been widely used in various patient populations, including knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is endogenous pain modulation, which assesses the efficiency of pain modulation mechanisms in individuals with knee osteoarthritis. We can use the conditioned pain modulation (CPM) testing method to evaluate this measure. By assessing the ascending measure of pressure pain threshold (PPT) at the anterior shin and the conditioning stimulus in the form of forearm ischemia, we can calculate the percent efficiency of CPM (%CPM) as PPT2/PPT1 multiplied by 100. This measure can provide insights into the neurobiological effects of the intervention. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks.

The other secondary outcome measures include pain interference, pain catastrophizing, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), multi-joint pain assessed through a body diagram, knee awareness, functional leg strength, medication use, adverse events, patient global impression of change, blinding effectiveness, usefulness of the program for managing knee OA, frequency of the program, duration of the program, acceptability of the delivery of the brain stimulation, acceptability of the delivery of the yoga session of the program, likelihood of recommending the program to others with knee OA, burdensomeness of completing questionnaires and physical assessments, adherence rate, and rate of completion of home sessions. Each of these measures serves a specific purpose and provides valuable information on various aspects of the intervention and study outcomes.

You're welcome! Designing outcome measures can be complex, but it's important to consider various aspects of the intervention and study outcomes. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, feel free to ask.

For the secondary outcome measures, I would suggest "Physical Function", "Sleep Quality", "Emotional State", and "Quality of Life". These measures will provide a comprehensive understanding of the participants' overall recovery.

The "Physical Function" outcome measure assesses the participants' ability to perform various daily activities, including walking, climbing stairs, and doing household chores. This is a validated scoring system that will be assessed on the day before surgery, the first day after surgery, and the third or fourth day after surgery.

The "Sleep Quality" outcome measure is a sleep diary that participants will complete every evening from the day before surgery to the third or fourth day after surgery. This diary will provide valuable information about the participants' sleep patterns and quality during the postoperative period.

The "Emotional State" outcome measure is the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), which is a 14-item scale that assesses participants' anxiety and depression levels. The HADS will be completed on the day before surgery, the first day after surgery, and the third or fourth day after surgery.

The "Quality of Life" outcome measure is the SF-36 questionnaire, which is a validated tool that evaluates participants' self-reported quality of life. The SF-36 will be completed on the day before surgery, the first day after surgery, and the third or fourth day after surgery. 

Are there additional measures you would like to include?

Certainly! The "Elderly Mobility Scale" consists of six items that assess the ability to perform daily activities. It will be assessed on the first day after surgery, the third or fourth day after surgery, and a day after hospital discharge to evaluate the impact of the intervention on mobility and independence.

The "5 Times Sit to Stand Test" measures the ability to stand up and sit down from a chair five times. It will be recorded in seconds and evaluated on the first day after surgery to monitor changes in lower limb strength.

The "Hospitalization Duration" is measured in days and is defined as the time between surgery and discharge. It will be examined to evaluate the influence of the intervention on the duration of hospital stays.

The "Surgery Duration" is measured in minutes and is defined as the time between incision and final sutures. It will be assessed on the day of surgery to monitor changes in surgery complexity and duration.

The "Consumption of Analgesics" is measured in milligrams (mg) and will be compared with the participants' typical analgesic usage. It will be assessed during the first three days after surgery to evaluate whether the intervention influences postoperative pain control.

The "Occurrence of Falls" will be recorded as a yes or no response. It will be tracked for four days after surgery to assess whether the intervention reduces the risk of falls during the postoperative period.

The "Oxford Knee Score Questionnaire" is a self-reported questionnaire that assesses knee function and pain level using a scale of 1 to 5. It will be administered at three time points: before surgery, the first day after surgery, and a day after hospital discharge. 

I hope this information enables you to further evaluate the choice of secondary outcome measures.

Changes in liver enzymes, specifically alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST), were chosen as one of the secondary outcome measures because they are commonly used indicators of liver function. High levels of liver enzymes can indicate inflammation or damage to the liver. By measuring the changes in ALT and AST levels, the study can assess the impact of SIM01 on liver function, specifically in reducing inflammation or damage.

Changes in fasting lipid and HbA1c levels were chosen as secondary outcome measures because they provide insights into metabolic health and the relationship between liver function and other measures of metabolic function. Fasting lipid levels, such as total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, and triglycerides, are crucial markers of cardiovascular risk. HbA1c levels reflect long-term glucose control and indicate the risk of developing diabetes-related complications. By assessing the changes in fasting lipid and HbA1c levels, researchers can evaluate the impact of SIM01 on metabolic health and explore the potential modulation of liver function on these markers.

The time frame for assessing the changes in lipid and HbA1c levels is 3 months after the start of the intervention period. The assessment of these measures is important to determine the short-term effects of SIM01 on metabolic health in NAFLD patients.

The primary outcome measures are changes in Controlled Attenuation Parameter (CAP) score, as evaluated by fibroscan, after taking SIM01 for 3 months. The secondary outcome measures include changes in liver enzymes (ALT and AST), changes in fasting lipid and HbA1c levels, changes in body mass index (BMI), changes in body waist circumference, and changes in interleukin-6 (IL-6) levels. 


Introduction
NAFLD is a common liver disease characterized by an excessive accumulation of fat in the liver in individuals who do not have significant alcohol consumption. With its increasing prevalence, NAFLD has become a public health concern, as it is a leading cause of chronic liver disease and can progress to liver fibrosis, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma. The early identification and management of NAFLD are crucial to prevent disease progression and improve patient outcomes.

Simvastatin is a lipid-lowering medication commonly used to treat hypercholesterolemia, specifically in controlling high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol. It inhibits the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, which is involved in the production of cholesterol in the liver. By reducing cholesterol synthesis, simvastatin helps lower LDL cholesterol levels in the blood and improve overall cardiovascular health.

Sufficient evidence suggests that statins may have additional benefits beyond their lipid-lowering effects, including positively influencing body weight and metabolic health. Studies report that statins can reduce visceral adipose tissue (VAT), a type of fat tissue distributed deep inside the abdominal cavity and associated with metabolic syndrome and insulin resistance. This effect may be mediated by statins’ ability to modulate adipocyte differentiation and metabolism, which could contribute to improved insulin sensitivity and reduced inflammation.

Ingestion of probiotics, also known as good bacteria, has become increasingly popular as a method of supporting gut health. Research suggests that the consumption of probiotics may improve gastrointestinal symptoms, reduce the risk of infections, and modulate the immune system. Probiotics may also have a positive impact on insulin sensitivity

Changes in liver enzymes, specifically ALT and AST levels, were chosen as secondary outcome measures because they are essential in evaluating liver function and detecting liver damage. These enzymes can indicate improvements or worsening of liver health. By assessing the change in ALT and AST levels over the study period, researchers can determine the impact of SIM01 on liver function in NAFLD patients.

Changes in fasting lipid and HbA1c levels were chosen as secondary outcome measures because they are important markers of metabolic health and are commonly dysregulated in individuals with NAFLD. Monitoring changes in these parameters can provide valuable information on the effects of SIM01 on metabolic function and overall health. By assessing the changes in lipid profiles and HbA1c levels, researchers can evaluate the potential benefits of SIM01 in improving metabolic parameters in NAFLD patients.

The time frame for assessing changes in liver enzymes, fasting lipid and HbA1c levels, BMI, body waist circumference, and IL-6 levels is also 3 months. This duration allows for comprehensive monitoring of these measures over an adequate period to capture potential changes in liver function, metabolic health, body weight management, abdominal obesity, and immune response in response to SIM01.

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Change in Controlled Attenuation Parameter (CAP) score by fibroscan after taking SIM01 for 3 months: The change of CAP score measured by fibroscan. This measure assesses the impact of SIM01 on liver fat accumulation.

- Change in liver enzymes (ALT and AST) across the study period: The change in the level of liver enzymes.
- Change in fasting lipid and HbA1c levels across the study period: The change in the level of lipid profiles.
- Change of body mass index (BMI) across the study period: The change in body weight and body height.
- Change of body waist circumference across the study period: The change in waist circumference.
- Change in interleukin-6 (IL-6) across the study period: The change in one of the immunity markers.

These outcome measures will help researchers evaluate the effectiveness of SIM01 in improving liver function, metabolic health, body weight management, abdominal obesity, and immune response in female subjects with NAFLD.

Abstract:
Introduction: Patient recruitment is often the limitation to clinical research. Clinical trials also suffer high attrition rates. This study describes patient recruitment, retention, and loss to follow‐up in a randomized controlled trial (RCT). Methods: This is a pre‐/post‐test design with a single institutional 5‐week RCT comparing a computerized cognitive therapy for major depressive disorder (MDD) (iMood) to an internet‐ based self‐help (ISH) control. In this study, 46 depressed adults were randomized to one of two groups: the treatment group, n = 22, was given access to an 8‐week computerized adaptive cognitive therapy program, while the control group, n = 24, was given access to an informational web‐page for 5 weeks followed by access to a 10‐chapter, MDD self‐help program. Participants completed a battery of pre‐ and post‐treatment measures. Results: For the entire sample, the recruitment and retention rates were 100%. Overall retention rate across the treatment and control groups was 63%. Loss to follow‐up was 37.5%. Treatment completers, who used iMood for more than 19 days, demonstrated a clinically significant reduction in depression across all patients (n = 14) (n = 8 treatment group; n = 6 ISH control group) at the end of treatment. Conclusions: The internet holds tremendous potential as a medium for delivering psychological therapies. Conducting a study that uses both the web and internet‐based technologies can help to identify and reduce potential barriers to research, and can also help guide future clinical trials.

Abstract:
Episodes of acute dyspnoea (AD) are a common symptom with an estimated prevalence of up to 49% in patients with COPD. Adequate management of this symptom contributes to better quality of life and outcomes. ADs are classified according to the time of occurrence into acute exacerbations (AECOPD) and daily AD (DAAD). Despite its clinical relevance and high prevalence, there are no studies that address the daily management of this symptom, and we still lack specific guidelines for its recognition, management and treatment. Knowledge of the characteristics and causes of DAAD is also limited. In this narrative review, we describe the pathophysiology and definition of DAAD, describe the causes and risk factors of DAAD and propose a therapeutic approach to DAAD. The pathophysiological mechanisms of DAAD result from complex interplay between neuronal, muscle and anatomical factors, which lead to a decrease in lung volumes and to the sensation of breathlessness, despite maintaining a normal or hyperinflated state. DAAD episodes are characterized by an increase in the perception or emotional impact of dyspnoea and the worsening of dyspnoea beyond the expectations of daily life variability. The risk factors and causes of DAAD reported in the literature are dyspnoea, fatigue, anxiety, depression, cognitive impairment, comorbidities and environmental factors. The treatment of DAAD is guided by identifying and managing the causes. The evidence for different pharmacological and non‐pharmacological treatment options for DAAD is limited and of low quality. DAAD is a frequent, distressing and clinically relevant symptom in patients with COPD, not just a predictor or consequence of AECOPD. New strategies to identify and manage DAAD in the outpatient setting are necessary.

Abstract:
[Background and aims] It is well known that stroke affects the swallowing function and patients can develop a swallowing disorder (dysphagia). In Japan, acupressure was widely used to relieve stroke and post‐stroke symptoms, but few studies have reported its effect to improve the swallowing function. This study aims to clarify whether acupressure can improve swallowing functions in patients with dysphagia after stroke. Materials and methods: This was a multicenter, randomized, double‐blind (for all except acupuncture and acupressure testers), placebo‐controlled study. Fifty‐seven patients with stroke participated, and 37 patients whose swallowing function met the criteria were included. The participants were equally divided into the acupressure and sham group. The sham group received acupressure at a sham acupuncture point. The intervention group received stimulation at non‐swallow‐related points and the control group received no intervention. Swallowing function was evaluated by a speech pathologist using a fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FEES) score, water swallow test, and videofluoroscopic examination. The outcome measurements consisted of the Faces Pain Scale, the Acupuncture Comfort Scale, and a short‐form version of the Sickness Impact Profile (SIP‐12). The study was registered with the University Hospital Medical Information Network (UMIN) clinical information database (ID: 000012518). Results: The average FFES score showed statistically significant improvement in the intervention group. The water swallowing test results and the modified barium swallow examination results showed significantly higher scores in the intervention group than in the control group. The Acupuncture Comfort Scale score was better in the control group (p < 0.05). There were no significant differences in the SIP‐12 scores between the control and intervention groups. Concl

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Purpose of study: The long-term aim of the study is to investigate the pathophysiological effects of non-invasive ventilation as a supplement to usual care of ALS-patients (i.e. LTMV-NSV-cohort) on the respiratory mechanics of a selected population of ALS-patients with preserved respiratory capacity. Secondly, the investigators compare LTMV with usual ALS care in this population (i.e. ICH-NSV-cohort). Hypothesis: The present study design is an explorative study and therefore the investigators start with a simple randomization into 2 groups; group A, receive NIV (LTMV-NSV-cohort) and group B does not receive NIV (ICH-NSV-cohort). It is expected that in group A, patients have less deterioration on several clinical and respiratory measures relative to group B. Study method: Study design 1:1 randomization into the cohorts. Patients will be recruited for 2 years duration with a follow-up of 5 years. For further details, see the attached manuscript.

Effects of Concentrated Growth Factor on Apicomarginal Defects: a Prospective Study


Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Purpose: Apicomarginal lesions, also called apicomarginal defects, are frequently seen in the apical area of the root, and root canal treatment is sometimes inadequate in the treatment of these lesions. This study aims to compare the outcomes of bone substitute therapy alone and bone substitute therapy combined with growth factors in the treatment of apicomarginal defects, with reference to apical bone filling and recurrence. Methods: This prospective, randomized, clinical study will study 35 subjects with apicomarginal lesions over the age of 18, who received root canal treatment. 50% of the lesions will be treated using bone substitute therapy alone, and 50% of the lesions will be treated using bone substitute therapy combined with growth factors. The primary outcome measure will be the apical bone filling percentage at 6 months, measured using cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT). Secondary outcome measures include the recurrence rate, pain, and adverse effects of the intervention. The study will be conducted in the Department of Endodontics at Seoul National University Dental Hospital. The duration of the study will be 1 year and 6 months. Participants will receive treatment for apicomarginal lesions, and cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) and evaluation of clinical symptoms will be conducted after 6 months and 1 year.

Detailed Description
-----------------
RATIONALE: Although apicomarginal defects occur in up to 60% of endodontic treatment outcomes, conventional root canal treatment is not a viable treatment option. Bone substitutes are used to treat apicomarginal defects, but they have insufficient bone regeneration, and the efficacy of growth factors is limited when used alone or in combination with inorganic and synthetic products. 1. Types of external abdominal hernias: The number of participants with each type of external abdominal hernia was identified and presented as a proportion of all participants with hernia to shed light on the diversity of the condition and assist in clinical classification and management.

2. Associated factors of external abdominal hernias: Multivariate logistic regression analyses were conducted to identify factors associated with external abdominal hernias. The factors that had a significant association with hernia in bivariate analyses were included in the multivariate logistic regression model after checking the multicollinearity of the independent variables. The odds ratio (OR) and the 95% confidence interval (CI) were reported to illustrate the strength of association. This measure helps in understanding the etiology and risk factors for external abdominal hernias.

3. Healthcare knowledge of patients with external abdominal hernias: The knowledge level of patients was assessed using an instrument that included 20 questions related to external abdominal hernias. The score for each participant was calculated, and participants were classified into good knowledge, low knowledge, and no knowledge based on their total score. This measure provides insights into the level of knowledge patients have about their condition and identifies areas where targeted educational interventions could be implemented. 

4. Healthcare seeking behaviors of patients with external abdominal hernias: The proportion of patients who reported seeking healthcare services for their hernia was calculated, and the factors associated with their healthcare seeking behaviors were evaluated. This measure helps in understanding the patient's experience and decision-making processes in seeking medical care. It also highlights the importance of addressing healthcare access challenges to promote early diagnosis and treatment of hernias.

Overall, these outcome measures provide a comprehensive evaluation of external abdominal hernias among adult patients, focusing on burden, characteristics, risk factors, and patient's knowledge and behaviors. Study 2
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Rapid advances in information technology and information processing and the rapid development of health technology have led to the use of many health care tools. In this study, an online health risk appraisal (web app) is used to detect chronic kidney disease (CKD), and the results are compared with clinic measurements including laboratory measurements and body measurements. In this study, a control group (without disease) and a test group (with CKD) will be formed. Within the control group, two subgroups consisting of the disease group and the healthy group will be formed. With the exception of gender demographics and age, the results obtained from the online app will be compared with the results obtained in clinics, and the effectiveness of the software will be examined.

Detailed Description
-----------------
In this study, it is aimed to provide information on the early detection, progression and prevention of chronic kidney disease using a special risk assessment application called KidoScan (based on a comprehensive questionnaire) instead of laboratory and physical examination findings. In this study, a control group (without kidney disease) and a test group (with kidney disease) will be formed. Within the control group, two subgroups consisting of the healthy group and the risk group will be formed. The results of the online application will be compared with the clinic examinations, and the effectiveness of the software will be examined. Within the test group, patients whose protein amounts in urine exceeded 600 mg per day will be included in the study. In the control group, randomly selected adult participants from the community of Turkey who do not have a diagnosis of kidney disease will be included in the study. People who have a health and body mass problem may have a negative perception before the study, and their answers may not be true. In order to prevent this, participants who have been using medications or have a history of surgery for any body system in the last year will not be included in the study.

Official Title
-----------------
Identification of Kidney Disease Using a Health Assessment Software

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a prospective registry of patients undergoing PCI, and will evaluate the effectiveness of an AI software on decision process of physicians and patients.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The main objective is to evaluate the efficacy of AI-based assistance in the decision-making process in terms of the decision time to undergo PCI compared to standard clinical care. The study will be conducted in a single tertiary angiography center with an experienced interventional team performing around 2000 PCIs per year. A total of 600 consecutive PCI patients will be included, split equally between: routine care (control arm, n=300) and the control arm plus the decision support of the AI model (study arm, additional n=300)

Absolutely. Here they are:

Decision-to-departure time: the time between the decision for mechanical thrombectomy and the actual departure of the patient from the hospital. Time frame: within 24 hours of the first imaging evidence of an ischemic stroke.

Decision-to-arrival time: the time between the decision for mechanical thrombectomy and the arrival of the patient at the designated thrombectomy center. Time frame: within 24 hours of the first imaging evidence of an ischemic stroke.

Arrival-to-groin time: the time between the patient's arrival at the thrombectomy center and the time when the groin is prepped for the procedure. Time frame: within 24 hours of the first imaging evidence of an ischemic stroke.

Rate of refusal of transfer requests due to lack of capacity: a measure of the number of transfer requests declined due to lack of capacity (i.e., the hospital is already at full capacity and unable to accept transferred patients). Time frame: within 24 hours of the initial phone call for transfer.

Decision-to-transfer request time: the time between the initial phone call for transfer and the decision to proceed with the transfer. Time frame: within 24 hours of the initial phone call for transfer.

Periprocedural complications: any complications that occur during or immediately following the mechanical thrombectomy procedure. This includes, but is not limited to, procedure-related strokes, bleeds, or other adverse events. Time frame: within 7 days of the mechanical thrombectomy procedure.

Successful outcome of MT (mTICI > 2b): the assessment of the outcome following mechanical thrombectomy based on the modified Thrombolysis In Cerebral Infarction (mTICI) scale. A score of greater than 2b indicates a successful outcome. Time frame: within 7 days of the mechanical thrombectomy procedure.

Groin-to-recanalization time: the time between the commencement of the mechanical thrombectomy procedure and the achievement of full recanalization of the affected vessel. Time frame: within 7 days of the mechanical thrombectomy procedure.

Study overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Albendazole has been shown to improve neurological function in adult patients with CNS hydatid disease by significantly decreasing inflammatory response and neurological symptoms, with no serious side effects in the form of drug-resistance or allergic reactions. In patients aged 3 months to 4 years, cystic echinococcosis is a common infection of the CNS, and the rate of infection among these patients is 71.4 to 91.7%. Hydatid cyst fluid and antibody concentrations are used to evaluate the drug's effectiveness. It is difficult to obtain seroconversion in children with a high initial serum concentration, prolonged treatment duration, or frequent use of adjunctive therapy. To solve this problem, the investigators plan to use the anti-Echinococcus antibody and hydatid cyst fluid concentration ratio to evaluate the treatment effect. Hydatid cyst fluid is difficult to obtain. The investigators will also use the hydatid cyst fluid to blood protein concentration ratio as an indicator. To evaluate the immunological effect of hydatid cyst fluid injection, we plan to use protein concentration, as well as IgG subclasses (IgG1 and IgG4) of protein and eosinophil counts. To evaluate the effectiveness of Albendazole for 2 months versus 6 months, the investigators plan to use this ratio to assess the effectiveness in children.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Echinococcosis occurs when tapeworms of the genus Echinococcus live in the human body. In recent years, echinococcosis has become more common in children, and cystic echinococcosis is considered to be a severe form of infection with increased morbidity and mortality rates. In recent years, there has been an increase in the incidence of echinococcosis with a high risk of complications in the early stage in clinical research. The hydatid cyst may not be detected in the early stage of the disease. If left untreated, they may rupture or be infected, causing serious complications and diseases. groundtruth:
Absolutely! In addition to the CR/CRh rate, there are several other important secondary outcome measures to consider. These include:

1. Incidence and severity of adverse events (safety and tolerability): We can monitor the number and grade of adverse events assessed by CTCAE v5.0 over the course of approximately 36 months. This will help us assess the safety and tolerability of the combination therapy.

2. Duration of response: Measuring the time from randomization to disease progression or death in patients who achieve CR/CRh will provide insights into the durability of treatment response.

3. Post baseline transfusion independence rate: Assessing the rate of conversion from baseline transfusion dependence to transfusion independence will help us understand the impact of treatment on patients' quality of life.

4. Progression-free survival: Evaluating the time from randomization until the first evidence of disease progression or death will provide valuable information on the treatment's ability to control disease progression and prolong survival.

5. Relapse-free survival: Monitoring the number of participants alive without relapse will help us assess the long-term effectiveness of the combination therapy in preventing disease relapse.

6. Overall survival: Measuring the time from randomization to death will provide essential data on the treatment's impact on overall survival outcomes.

7. Percentage of patients bridged to hematopoietic stem cell transplantation: Assessing the number of hematopoietic stem cell transplantations following response will provide insights into the potential of the combination therapy to facilitate curative treatment options.

8. Impact of treatment on HM-PRO (hematologic malignancy-specific patient-reported outcome measure): Evaluating the treatment's impact on patients' health-related quality of life and disease-related signs and symptoms using the HM-PRO scales will provide a holistic understanding of the treatment's effects.

Study design
=============
Brief summary in scientific language
=================
The primary aim of this project is to reduce internalized anti-TNB stigma and to promote well-being through the inclusion and testing of the 4-week Expressive Writing Intervention in 90 transgender and nonbinary individuals age 18 and older who are at high risk for or have been diagnosed with major depressive disorder (MDD). The following outcome measures will be tested: The first primary aim will be assessed through qualitative data on feasibility. The qualitative data will be analyzed following the phenomenological hermeneutic, interpretative methodology. The second and third primary aims will be assessed by recording the number of missed sessions and the total scale scores to the Positive and Negative Affect Scale (PANAS) as documented to the participant record of attendance. Secondary outcome measures will be tested by recording the number of missed sessions and correlating the number of missed sessions with total scale scores to the PANAS and by assessing the differences in total scale scores to the PANAS among participants based on their gender and pronouns.

Abstract:
The aim of this review was to critically summarize published randomized controlled trials (RCTs) on the effects of different types of exercise on cardiorespiratory fitness/VO2max and health‐related quality of life in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI).A systematic literature search was conducted for studies published in English up to December 2020. The articles were evaluated for inclusion/exclusion and the quality of the studies was analyzed according to the Physiotherapy Evidence Database Scale (PEDro scale: 1‐5). The following criteria were used to describe the studies: types of participants, interventions, primary and secondary outcome measures, and results.The review revealed that most of the RCTs were carried out with small sample sizes (small n) and short duration (acute studies, lasting up to 4 months). There are few RCT studies on the effects of different types of exercise on patients with SCI. One RCT study reported that 6 months of arm ergometry training could lead to improved VO2 max and quality of life. In addition, the effect of a single bout of intense resistance training was found to improve VO2 max and quality of life 24 hours after training. In conclusion, few RCTs with small sample sizes were found to examine the different types of training used to assess cardiorespiratory fitness/VO2max and health‐related quality of life in individuals with SCI. It is, therefore, recommended that more high‐quality RCTs with sufficient numbers of participants be published to assess the effects of different types of exercise on VO2 max and quality of life in people with SCI. 2021 Impact Journals, LLC.

Spinal cord injury (SCI) is a neurological condition that prevents the transmission of signals from the spinal cord to the brain. Lay summary
=================
This study aims to investigate the safety and feasibility of an endoscopic endolaryngeal approach for the treatment of cervical spinal cord compression induced by thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS). The study will be conducted on patients 24-80 years old with symptomatic TOS and spinal cord compression confirmed on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or computed tomography (CT). Patients will undergo endoscopic endolaryngeal surgery with a hybrid approach through an endoscopic approach at the base of the neck. After surgery, patients will be evaluated for immediate and late clinical improvements, neurological outcomes, and quality of life. The study hypothesizes that the endoscopic endolaryngeal approach is a safe, effective, and minimally invasive alternative to the open approach for the treatment of cervical spinal cord compression induced by TOS.

Abstract 

Background
-----------------
Auditory neurotransmission occurs via chemical synapses within the central auditory nervous system. However, the precise neurochemical mechanisms remain largely unknown. Auditory brainstem response audiometry (ABR) is a common non-invasive electrophysiological measure used to assess central auditory function. ABR amplitudes are influenced by age and are reduced with peripheral pathology [1]. In patients with auditory processing disorders (APDs), ABRs show changes in their waveform characteristics, including decreases in the ABR amplitude, latency, and inter-peak latency [2], which may be due to central auditory processing deficits. Previous studies have also demonstrated that ABRs are sensitive to changes in the central auditory nervous system, including changes due to lesions, brain injury, and hearing loss [3]. However, few studies have used ABRs to detect changes in the central auditory nervous system in patients with APDs [4]. ABRs may be useful for monitoring changes in the central auditory nervous system in patients with APDs. In addition, ABRs may also help to evaluate the treatment outcomes and monitor the progression of the auditory processing disorder. Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are non-invasive tests that measure the auditory response from the cochlea to acoustic stimulation. OAEs are known to be reliable indicators of cochlear function, as they reflect the inner ear's ability to produce sounds. ABRs provide a measure of the central auditory nervous system's response to acoustic stimuli, and they provide a way to assess the integrity of the auditory pathway. In patients with APDs, there is a higher incidence of abnormal ABRs. This may be due to deficits in the central auditory nervous system, which can result in reduced auditory signal transmission. Conversely, OAE

We can measure speech perception in noise scores annually for 4 years. 
Overall, these outcome measures provide a comprehensive evaluation of hearing-related symptoms and outcomes in pediatric participants with OTOF, GJB2, or GJB2/GJB6 mutations.

A prospective study was conducted to determine the degree to which patients perceived the outcomes in a randomized controlled trial of intraluminal hemodialysis versus conventional treatment were influenced by psychological and social variables. In a previous study of 1,348 patients receiving intraluminal hemodialysis, a significant change had been demonstrated with this technique. The subjects were selected randomly from patients who entered the study before May 1978. Fourteen questions were asked of each patient, and these questions encompassed social desirability, self‐control, emotional awareness, perceived choice, anxiety, and depression. Scores on the psychosocial questionnaire for the 30‐ and 60‐day subjects showed a significant decline between the baseline evaluation and 2–12 months later. The score for the 2‐ to 4‐month group was not significantly different at baseline and follow‐up interviews. Analysis of questions suggested that patients' perceptions were not influenced by their responses to the intraluminal hemodialysis procedure.

Brief summary
=================
Myofascial trigger points (MTrPs) are hyperalgesic, hyperirritable spots that are part of palpable taut bands in skeletal muscle. MTrP palpation is one way to determine whether a person has MTrPs. Manipulation practitioners can use direct or indirect MTrP treatment methods to alleviate pain. As a result, MTrPs can be seen in a variety of muscle groups such as the masseter, splenius capitis, Flexor Digitorum Brevis (FDB), and others. Studies have shown that pressure release can be used to treat pain and improve muscle function. There are very few studies on the direct pressure release of MTrPs in the Flexor Digitorum Brevis (FDB) muscle, especially on progressively increasing pressure release at the trigger point of FDB bilaterally, and the mechanism of pain relief and increased range of motion after pressure release is still unknown. Therefore, our goal is to determine the effect of progressively increasing pressure release at the FDB trigger points on pain and range of motion. The purpose of this research is not to evaluate the effect of pressure release on pain and range

2019 Aug;18(8):452-453.
Abstract:
The management of adult knee osteoarthritis (OA) is focused on pain management and joint physiotherapy. However, there is no effective treatment that will halt the articular cartilage degeneration that is characteristic of this condition in the elderly. This article is the second of two by Woo et al that looks at the effects of physical therapies on joint health. In this study, 144 patients were randomized to be treated with continuous passive flexion/extension (a form of traction) or a placebo version of the same treatment. After 6 weeks of therapy, significant improvements were seen in both treatment groups with regard to knee mobility, gait index, and pain reduction. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan analysis showed that cartilage deterioration was arrested in the placebo group; however, the rate of cartilage deterioration was significantly increased in the continuous passive motion (CPM) group.

Brief Summary
-----------------
Traditionally, patients with flat foot were managed conservatively. More severe cases underwent surgical treatments. More and more interventional methods, such as progressive pressure release, fascial release, eccentric exercise, have been applied to patients with flat foot without surgery in recent years. Although many of them are effective, these therapeutic methods mainly focus on changing the function of the tibialis posterior tendon, not on changing the anatomy of the fibula. Therefore, the effects of progressive pressure release on latent myofascial trigger points around the Flexor Digitorum Brevis (FDB) should be further explored. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effects of bilateral progressive pressure release in latent trigger points of the FDB muscle on foot length, static footprint, and various stabilometry variables.

Muscle activity patterns of the hip external rotators, recorded through surface electromyography using a three-dimensional motion capture system.

=================

The Brunnstrom Classification of Motor Performance (BCMP)
A three-dimensional motion capture system (Vicon 4) and force platform (Kistler), that measures the kinematics and kinetics during an obstacle negotiation task.

Abstract
=================

Background
-----------------
Background: Cerebral palsy is the most common motor disorder in children. Children with cerebral palsy often have reduced motor abilities and increased activity in the muscle-groups responsible for muscle-tone. Several motor impairment characteristics have been associated to altered muscle activity for the hip external rotators. Research in the field is needed in order to investigate muscle activity patterns during the performance of gross motor functions. 
Objective: The aim of this study is to investigate differences in hip external rotator muscle activity patterns between children with cerebral palsy and their typically developing peers. Methods: This cross-sectional study will use preliminary data from a previous study. Children will undertake gross motor functions and these movements will be filmed. A three-dimensional motion capture system will track full body position and the electromyography activity of the hip external rot

The purpose of this interventional study is to evaluate the efficacy of using visual and sensory stimulants in the form of balance balls, balance sticks, and balance plates as tools for early intervention, in addition to daily educational activities for disabled children, in improving their balance during untrained activities and preventing falls. The participants of this study are children with developmental disabilities in the early developmental period, including children with cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy, and Down syndrome. The study is divided into two groups, an experimental group and a control group. Children in the experimental group will start a training program on balance balls, balance sticks, and balance plates at specific times, according to their age and developmental needs. Children in the control group will continue their usual daily educational activities without participating in the training program. All children's balance will be measured at the beginning of the study and at the end of the study using the Tinetti balance scale, including three items: support surface, distance from the edge of the support surface to the foot, and forward and backward walking. The measurement results will be presented at the end of the study in comparison with the beginning of the study

Abstract:
There is a paucity of well designed, randomized clinical trials that evaluate postdischarge clinical outcomes of bipolar disorder (BD) in a real‐world setting. A postdischarge assessment of patient outcomes across multiple domains might help to understand short‐ and long‐term clinical outcomes of BD. We recruited adults who met current Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (4th revision) criteria for BD. We evaluated their clinical outcomes using the International Society for Bipolar Disorders Clinical Global Impression (CGI) Scale, Columbia Suicide‐Severity Rating Scale (C‐SSRS), Quick Inventory of Depressive Symptomatology (QIDS), and Cognitive and Physical Functioning Questionnaire (CPFQ). During a 3‐month follow‐up, the bipolar I (BP‐I) group had significant improvements in C‐SSRS (p = 0.002), CGI (p < 0.001), and QIDS scores (p < 0.001). Bipolar II disorders (BP‐II) did not show an improvement in C‐SSRS (p > 0.05). However, BP‐II had similar CGI (p = 0.002) and QIDS scores (p < 0.001) as the BP‐I group. The CPFQ scores did not change in either group (p > 0.05). BPs had a better postdischarge treatment outcome when compared with major depressive disorder. Clinicians prescribing second‐generation antipsychotics should remain vigilant about the possibility of medication‐induced cognitive impairment because of their use as mood stabilizers and treatment for persistent anxiety, depression, or psychosis.

Brief summary
=================
Congenital cleft lip and palate (CCLP) is a facial deformity that occurs when the upper lip and/or palate do not completely develop during fetal development. Cleft lip and/or palate is a congenital condition that can cause various problems, including speech and language difficulties, which are some of the most prevalent and disabling long-term problems faced by individuals with cleft palate. Despite advances in treatment, many CCP children have persistent speech problems that can significantly impact their quality of life and ability to communicate effectively. Speech difficulties in CCP children are often related to impaired oromotor control of the muscles used in speech production and to poor intelligibility of speech sounds. One approach to measuring speech and language outcomes is through standardized measures of language and speech. These measures vary in duration and complexity, and are often based on the ability to understand, repeat, and produce different speech sounds and words. Common measures of language include the Expressive One-Word Picture Vocabulary Test, which measures receptive and expressive vocabulary, and the Peabody Picture Test of Intelligence, which measures nonverbal reasoning and problem-solving skills. However, these tests can be difficult to use with young children and may not accurately capture the specific speech behaviors of CCP children. In this study, we will measure speech and language outcomes in CCP children using a variety of standardized measures. The study is called "Speech and Language Correlation Analysis in Cleft Palate Children at 5, 10, and 15 Years of Age." The study aims to evaluate the relationship

Abstract:
Introduction: This study aimed to identify the impact of preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis on dental caries experience in Thai adults. Methods: A randomized, double‐blind clinical trial was conducted in two groups: (i) study group with preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis and (ii) control group without antibiotic prophylaxis. The dental caries experience was analyzed using the international caries detection and assessment system using the DMFT/DMFS index. Results: Sixty patients participated in the study, 27 in the study group and 33 in the control group. There was no statistically significant difference in dental caries status between the two groups based on DMFT/DMFS index scores (p = 0.331). Conclusion: The results indicated that antibiotic prophylaxis did not affect dental caries experience in this study. Therefore, preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis may not be necessary for patients undergoing periodontal surgery.

Abstract:
Background: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a life‐threatening condition characterized by severe lung inflammation and impaired oxygenation, with a high mortality rate. The use of spinal cord stimulation (SCS) has shown promising results in patients with chronic pain, but its potential benefits in ARDS are unknown. The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of high spinal cord stimulation (HSCS) in terms of respiratory function, patient‐clinician communication, and quality of life in ARDS patients. Methods: This is a prospective, single‐center, pilot trial involving a sample of 10 patients admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with ARDS. The patients will be randomized to the HSCS group and the control group (usual care). The patients in the HSCS group will receive HSCS for 5 min at an electrical pulse frequency of 2‐10 Hz and a pulsing duration of 50‐70% of the total duration. The outcome measures will include the respiratory rate, SpO2, ventilator settings, and communication skills of the health care professionals. Quality of life will be assessed using the EuroQoL‐5 Dimensions questionnaire and the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale. Results: The results of the study will be presented in the form of descriptive statistics, with comparisons between the groups using t‐tests or Mann‐Whitney U‐tests, as appropriate. The effects of the HSCS will be analyzed using linear mixed models or generalized estimating equations, with adjustments for potential confounders. Conclusion: The results of this study will provide valuable insights into the potential benefits of HSCS in ARDS patients. The study will also contribute to the development of innovative therapies for this complex condition.

A double-blind, randomized controlled trial to evaluate the analgesic efficacy and functional improvement effect of injected triamcinolone acetonide extended release suspension on thumb osteoarthritis.

Intervention type
=================
Drug

Primary outcome measure
=================
To identify the difference in pain score change between the groups between the baseline and the final follow-up by using the visual analogue scale.

Secondary outcome measures
=================
Difference in functional evaluation of the QuickDash thumb function questionnaire score in the final follow-up compared with baseline in both groups.

Participant inclusion criteria
=================
1. Age older than 30 years old.
2. The diagnosis of CMC1 joint OA is based on the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) criteria, and the clinical diagnosis should be diagnosed by a physician.
3. With right or left thumb CMC joint pain, the pain lasts longer than 2 weeks, and is easily aggravated by various activities.
4. Pain score VAS 60mm
5. Having no history of previous surgical or percutaneous treatment.
6. In the last month of use, the pain score on VAS is < 5.
7. The physician decided to perform single point injection of the thumb CMC joint.
Participant type(s): Patient
Age group: Adult
Sex: Both
Target number of participants: 45

Intervention
=================
Severely impaired subjects (WOMAC pain score > 50) with CMC OA may be considered for surgical CAP + RSD or CAP (surgical and non-surgical group). Patients will be stratified by gender, age, baseline WOMAC pain score, and baseline CMC ICRS stage. In addition, they will be randomized to a surgical CAP group (with a silicone release capsule and a resection of intra-articular osteophytes) or a non-surgical CAP group (capsule only). Both groups will additionally receive an intra-articular knee injection of TA with or without HA. Subjects will be evaluated preoperatively and postoperatively at 3 and 6 months post-injection.

Drug

Primary outcome measure
=================
To determine if CAP can enhance the efficacy of intra-articular TA injection in osteoarthritis. A decrease in WOMAC pain score at 6 months post treatment between the surgical vs non-surgical intervention arms
