Excellent. So, it is a clinical trial. Now, let's talk about the study design. Could you tell me if it's a randomized study or an observational study? 

The study will have a cross-over design and will be randomized under the assumption that the study participants will not experience any significant worsening in respiratory mechanics. The randomization will be carried out per patient, with the order of the trials assigned by computer using a random number generator. This randomization is to eliminate the possibility of a bias in the study design that may arise from the order of treatment. The study will compare the effect of different types of patient-initiated expiratory cycling methods on the mechanical parameters observed in these patients. 

The first cycle of the experiment will be carried out using a fixed flow expiratory cycling with the patient triggering the start of an inspiratory cycle at 40% of the tidal volume, and the second will be carried out using a variable flow expiratory cycling with the patient triggering the start of an inspiratory cycle after completing the expiratory time set as 150% of tidal time. The tidal volume of the patient-triggered mechanical ventilation will be determined by the ventilator based on pressure support, tidal time (40% of the tidal volume), and the set positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) value in the first trial (experimental) and the second part of the study (control). 

We have a total of 10 study participants with respiratory failure who have been randomized using the computerized random number generation system mentioned above. After the patients recover from their present illness, they will be included in our study. Each study participant will undergo two parts of the study (expiratory cycling with different methods), which will be carried out in random order for each patient by computer-generated randomization. Therefore, the order in which the patient participates in the study will not be predetermined. 

In terms of the follow-up of the patients, they will be continuously evaluated by our study team throughout the expiratory cycling intervention, and relevant data will be recorded on paper-based data collection forms.

A follow-up process will be carried out to ensure that the study is conducted safely and ethically. There is no possibility of long-term follow-up,

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This prospective, open-label, randomized controlled study will be conducted to identify whether in critically ill or comatose patients with brain injuries, the use of a gastric residual volume of 300ml as a threshold for holding feeding tube will be more effective to keep patients' digestive tract functional than a threshold of 200ml.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Recent studies show that the use of a higher threshold of GRV to hold feeding is safe and effective. However, few studies have reported on the influence of this in patients with brain injury. Thus, the investigators conducted a prospective, open-label, randomized controlled study to verify whether a higher threshold of gastric residual volume can maintain the gastrointestinal tract of critically ill patients without aspiration. A total of 200 patients who require enteral nutrients and are receiving intracranial pressure monitoring will be randomly divided into two groups according to the GRV threshold used for holding feeding. The control group will use a threshold of 200ml and the experimental group will use a threshold of 300ml. All patients will undergo routine daily nutrition support by nasogastric tube feeding. If the above-mentioned threshold is reached, the amount of residual gastric contents will be drawn within one hour, and if there is aspiration or the patient shows signs of gastric distension, gastrointestinal obstruction, nausea and vomiting, feeding will be terminated. The investigators will follow up with clinical data and record the frequency of nutritional volume ratio in patients taking different thresholds in order to evaluate whether different thresholds of GRV can maintain the gastrointestinal tract of patients without aspiration. The investigators will also follow the patient's diet, nutritional status, gastrointestinal function, electrolyte levels and clinical outcomes during monitoring.

Official Title
-----------------
Effects

Abstract:
Purpose : To compare and analyze the accuracy of the prediction value of early pregnancy bleeding for early diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy based on the medical history questionnaire in traditional Chinese medicine and western medicine. Methods : A total of 100 women with clinically diagnosed ectopic pregnancy, 100 women with spontaneous abortion without placenta retention, and 100 women with non‐obstetrical causes admitted to our hospital from January 2008 to December 2012 were enrolled as the test group and the control group. At admission, the above three groups were randomly divided into 90 women each in the test group and 70 and 60 women in the control group according to the time of admission. The two groups of women were diagnosed according to the different methods of traditional Chinese medicine and western medicine, respectively. The accuracy of the early symptoms and signs of women undergoing traditional Chinese medicine and western medicine diagnosed with ectopic pregnancy were compared. Results : After three months of post‐treatment, the incidence of late pregnancy in the test group treated with traditional Chinese medicine was significantly higher than that in the control group treated with western medicine (P<0.05). In the test group, more patients with early symptoms and signs were diagnosed with ectopic pregnancy by traditional Chinese medicine and western medicine compared with the control group (P<0.05). Correlation analysis showed that the incidence of early pregnancy bleeding was significantly correlated with ectopic pregnancy (r=0.619, P<0.05), and the incidence of pregnancy bleeding was significantly correlated with ectopic pregnancy (r=0.573, P<0.05). Conclusion : The accuracy of traditional Chinese medicine in the early diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy is higher than that of western medicine. Early symptoms and signs based on medical history can be used to diagnose, which can effectively improve the early diagnosis rate of ectopic pregnancy.

Abstract:
Aim: To evaluate the efficiency of the use of PET‐CT to detect and assess colorectal cancer liver metastases (CLM) before and after induction chemotherapy in a randomized trial.Methods: 30 patients were included before starting first‐line treatment. FDG‐PET‐CT scans were made at baseline and three monthly after induction chemotherapy. The scans were independently evaluated. 24 lesions (60%) were confirmed as CLM (17 lesions before and 7 lesions after induction chemotherapy). Results: The number of metastatic sites increased from 7.0 at baseline to 12.0 after induction chemotherapy (9.9‐13.7 vs 14.2). A positive PET‐CT was observed in 16 patients and a negative PET‐CT in four patients. There was no difference in progression‐free survival (PFS) according to PET‐CT results. However, after induction chemotherapy, survival in the no positive scans group was 21.8 months (95% confidence interval {CI}, 12.6‐33.1) compared to 8.1 months (95% CI, 4.3‐13.3) in the positive scans group (P = 0.025).Conclusions: The PET‐CT scan is a reliable baseline staging method for CLM. Patients with no positive PET‐CT scans show better survival after induction chemotherapy.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: We compared the efficacy of a short and an extended treatment for patients with chronic subdural hematoma (cSDH). Aims: To evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of high‐dose of valdecoxib (VDX) vs. the standard‐dose, to reduce the intracranial pressure (ICP) caused by chronic subdural hygroma/hematoma associated with malignant glioma. METHODS: Forty patients with cSDH associated with malignant glioma between January 2017 and January 2019 were enrolled in this prospective study. Twenty patients were treated with the short course of VDX and valproate (VPA), and the other 20 with the extended course of VDX and VPA, which were grouped according to the time point of starting VDX (weeks 0‐1, 2‐3). Tumor‐related ICP was decreased and maintained significantly in the short‐term group and the trend of ICP was higher in the long‐term group. There was no significant side effect for the patients in both groups. However, the dose‐intensity of the drug in the extended‐term group was significantly decreased. There was no significant correlation between the baseline characteristics of the patients and the therapeutic efficacy. CONCLUSIONS: The short‐course treatment of valdecoxib and valproate may be a safe and effective regimen for the treatment of brain tumor‐associated ICP.

Abstract:
Background and aims: Previous literature showed that 45% of critical care patients had unrecognized hypophosphatemia (UH). To improve this UH rate, we aimed to compare the effects of the two different approaches: routine prophylactic phosphate supplementation (PS) vs. selective PS based on phosphate biochemistry markers (BS) on UH rate in critically ill patients admitted in the intensive care unit (ICU). Method(s): A total of 67 patients admitted to the ICU at a tertiary hospital were enrolled in this prospective randomised study from April 2010 to January 2022. They were randomly assigned to the group with routine PS or the group with selective PS based on phosphate biochemistry markers. Results: One hundred and ten patients were enrolled in the study, with a mean age of 64.8 ± 20.6 years and 52 being male. The overall prevalence of UH was 42%. Patients had a UH rate that was significantly higher in the control group (62%) than in the intervention group (83.3%, p value = 0.004). There was no statistically significant difference in the length of stay and length of mechanical ventilation in the control group compared to the intervention group. Conclusion(s): We found that a phosphate depletion prevention strategy using serum phosphate as a biochemical marker may be considered more appropriate in terms of costs, avoiding the risk of hyperphosphatemia, but does not appear to reduce the rate of UH in the critically ill. However, further research is needed to determine which of many biochemical markers that can reduce UH is more effective.

Abstract:
Purpose The effect of low‐level laser therapy (LLLT) on tissue remodeling, pain intensity, and range of motion (ROM) at the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) have been previously evaluated; however, the effects on the temporalis muscle activity have not been explored yet. The aim of this study was to analyze the effects of low‐level laser therapy, in combination with exercise therapy, on the temporalis muscle activity during clenching. Material and Methods Forty individuals (mean age 26 years; 20 men; 20 women) were included in the study which lasted for 4 weeks. Participants were randomized into the study group (LLLT + exercise therapy) and the control group (exercise therapy). The temporalis muscle activity was evaluated with electromyography (EMG) during clenching (maximum voluntary contraction, MVC) at the beginning (BASE), one week (WK1), and 1 month (WK2) after the beginning of treatment. Participants were evaluated with respect to their demographic data, occlusal relationship, and occlusal interferences using dental models. Results There was a statistically significant difference between the groups in terms of age (t = ‐3.704, p < 0.001), EMG amplitude during clenching (F = 30.195, p < 0.001), and anterior displacement during MVC (F = 46.513, p < 0.001). Statistically significant differences in time and group were also found in EMG amplitude and anterior displacement of the condyle. The results obtained showed a greater decrease in EMG amplitude and anterior displacement of the condyle in the study group compared to the control group. Conclusion The combination of LLLT and exercise therapy showed effectiveness for temporary changes during clenching.

Brief Summary
-----------------
Higher levels of prothrombin are associated with increased risk of bleeding. Patients with liver disease, inflammation and infections are at increased risk for bleeding. However, the role of increased prothrombin levels during sepsis is unclear. We hypothesize that high prothrombin levels during sepsis are associated with adverse outcomes. We aim to examine the association of prothrombin levels with clinical outcomes in critically ill patients with sepsis. This is a pre-specified analysis of secondary outcomes in the prospective observational observational study "VASCUTORE". A study protocol has been published previously. We prospectively collected blood samples from septic patients and non-septic controls over a two-year period. 1070 patients with sepsis were included in the primary analysis. Prothrombin levels were measured centrally within 48 h from the time of positive culture for pathogens associated with sepsis. The association of prothrombin levels with clinical outcomes was analyzed using multivariable logistic regression. The main outcome was 28-day mortality. Secondary outcomes included length of ICU stay and length of hospital stay. Sensitivity analysis was conducted by excluding patients with baseline prothrombin levels <80%

Detailed Description
-----------------
VAScUlatORE was a prospective observational study conducted in the ED, ICUs and wards of the Department of Intensive Care Medicine, University medical center Utrecht from January 2016 to May 2018. 1070 patients with septic shock were included in the primary analysis of the original study. Prothrombin levels were measured within 48 hours from the time of positive culture with pathogens associated with sepsis, according to the European criteria. Prothrombin levels were measured centrally by a commercial laboratory. We conducted a pre-planned analysis of this dataset. What is the rationale for the proposed research question?
=================
Background
Growth and spread of bacteria in the blood are important determinants of infection-related morbidity and mortality. Bacterial growth and spread are dependent on a variety of clinical, epidemiological and microbiological factors, including the ability of bacteria to form biofilms.  The mechanisms that underlie these phenomena and how they may be modified by antibiotics and other antimicrobial agents in the setting of infection are poorly understood.  Bacterial growth in the bloodstream may take place both in the presence and absence of biofilm and both of these processes contribute to bacterial pathophysiology, antibacterial drug tolerance, and dissemination.  It is hypothesized that the growth of Gram-negative pathogens in the bloodstream occurs most readily in patients with an intact immune system as these patients lack the immunological mechanisms that interfere with bacterial spread in vivo.
The proposed project will utilize in vitro, ex vivo, and in silico models to understand the mechanisms responsible for the accelerated growth of organisms in the bloodstream.  The study will also explore how immune-modulating drugs can influence growth and spread of bacteria in the bloodstream.   The investigators predict that treatment with antibodies to host cytokines will inhibit the growth of bacteria in blood during acute infection in a dose-dependent manner in vitro and in silico. The investigators also predict that growth of these organisms will be accelerated ex vivo by use of antibodies that block complement regulation.  Finally, the investigators plan to explore the contribution of host-induced biofilms to resistance of Gram-negative pathogens in the blood.
Gram-negative bacteria infect more than 3 million patients per year, resulting in nearly 50,000 deaths.  Pneumonia is the most common Gram-negative infection and the most common cause of Gram-negative sepsis.  Although the frequency of Gram-negative sepsis has decreased over the past several decades, the mortality rate has remained between 22-30% overall. Abstract:
Treatment with albendazole for visceral leishmaniasis in Ethiopia: randomised, open, comparative, trial

Abstract:
Introduction. To determine the efficacy and tolerability of albendazole treatment compared with standard pentavalent antimoniate treatment for the cure of visceral leishmaniasis (VL). Methods. Patients infected with Leishmania donovani in Jimma University, Ethiopia were randomized into two groups. Group 1 (n=65) received 200 mg albendazole daily and group 2 (n=67) received 10 mg/kg/day of sodium stibogluconate as their first‐line anti‐Leishmania treatment. After treatment failure, 11 from group 2 switched to pentamidine treatment. To compare the efficacy and tolerability of albendazole and sodium stibogluconate, recurrences were observed over a followup of five years. A χ2 test was used to compare the results. Results. There were no significant differences in treatment efficacy, relapse rate, or survival rate. A significantly higher proportion of patients in group 1 (16 [24.6%]) compared with group 2 had a higher severity of VL (7944‐group 1 versus 5597‐group 2), and 45 (group 1) developed hyperbilirubinaemia (9.2%) during their treatment compared with 16 (group 2, 8.0%), but the difference was not statistically significant. Conclusion. Although a higher proportion of patients in group 1 (albendazole treatment) developed severe VL, there was no difference in the efficacy and relapse rates of treatment. We believe that albendazole treatment could be used among patients with severe VL.

Abstract:
The effect of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) on the management of patients with mild Covid‐19 infection is not well studied. This single‐centre, parallel‐group, randomized double‐blind controlled clinical trial is planned to assess the effect of two intravenous doses of immunoglobulin in mild/moderate COVID‐19 pneumonia on hospitalization and viral clearance at 4weeks post‐sampling. Patients with confirmed Covid‐19 infection within 48h and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air were included. All study protocols have been complied with ethical standards and the relevant regulations. Out‐patient patients, in‐patients with a viral load >or= 108 copies/mL, and those in need of supplemental oxygen by nasal prongs were included. Exclusion criteria included: patients with severe disease, cardiac failure > New York Heart Association (NYHA) Class III heart failure, haemoglobin < 7g/dl, neutrophil count < 1500/mm^3 and platelet count < 50,000/mm^3. All patients were randomized to either the standard care group (group A) or the IVIG (5% immunoglobulin at 0.4g/kg body weight) twice, with a 14‐day interval (group B). The primary objective was to assess the time to viral clearance in the two groups. Secondary objectives were viral load at three weeks, time to viral clearance, oxygen requirement and hospitalization.

Abstract:
This clinical study aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of Xuefu Huayu Pill in patients with acute ischemic stroke (AIS). From January 2015 to January 2016, 60 cases of AIS were selected and randomly divided into control group (conventional treatment) and observation group (Xuefu Huayu Pill 20g). The neurological function was improved and the modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score was reduced. Serum levels of glutamate oxaloacetate transferase (SGOT), creatine kinase (CK) and lactic acid (LAC) were decreased, the fibrinogen (FBG) level was decreased and the red blood cell (RBC), white blood cell (WBC) and platelet (PLT) counts were increased. The total effective rate of the observation group was higher than that of the control group (both P<0.05), and the differences in SGOT, CK, LAC, FBG and RBC, WBC and PLT levels between the two groups were significant (all P<0.05). No obvious toxic and side reactions occurred in each group during the treatment, and the safety of the drug was good. Compared with conventional treatment, Xuefu Huayu Pill showed better therapeutic effects and safety in treating patients with AIS.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Several studies have demonstrated the positive association of psychosocial interventions with health outcomes and improvements in HIV self-efficacy, treatment adherence, social network support, and other psychosocial parameters among chronic disease patients and those living with HIV; however, no such study has been carried out among PLHIV in Nigeria. Hence, we aim to investigate the effect of a social support intervention on adherence to medication and psychosocial factors associated with adherence among adults (aged 18 years or older) living with chronic illnesses and in attendance at the CTC of the Jos University teaching Hospital (JUTH), Nigeria. The objectives of the study is to assess the effects of social support groups on the adherence to medication and the psychosocial factors amongst PLHIV in attendance at the CTC of JUTH.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This was a randomized clinical trial (RCT) conducted in the CTC of JUTH, Nigeria. The unit was randomly allocated into two groups (A and B). The control group A was not exposed to the social support intervention (face-to-face or video-based) and were not allowed to interact, while the intervention group B received support via a 12-week social support intervention. Each group had a total of 20 participants. Each group was assessed at the baseline and post-intervention periods, with a minimum of 3 months interval between sessions. Demographic and clinical characteristics were collected using the socio-demographic questionnaire and the medical history form. The outcomes measured were treatment adherence, depressive symptoms, anxiety, HIV self-efficacy, social support, disease stigma, and quality of life.

Official Title
-----------------
The Effects of Social Support Groups on Medication Adherence and Psychosocial Factors Among People Living With HIV/AIDS (PLHIV): An Interventional Study

Abstract:
AIM: This study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a combination of an oral proton pump inhibitor (lansoprazole) and a topical corticosteroid (clobetasol propionate) for the treatment of chronic hand dermatitis (atopic hand eczema).METHODS: In this randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, cross‐over trial, patients with a current diagnosis of chronic hand dermatitis were randomly allocated at a ratio of 1:1 to receive a combination of topical clobetasol propionate (0.05%) and oral lansoprazole (30 mg) or their respective placebos in a randomized, double‐blinded fashion. Patients were treated for 16 consecutive weeks. Then each product was evaluated separately as a monotherapy for an additional 16 weeks according to a fixed crossover scheme. The primary endpoint was a reduction in hand eczema score, which was based on a 5‐point grading scale in relation to hand eczema severity by clinical examination, whereas the secondary endpoints included evaluation of quality of life and patient satisfaction.RESULTS: After 16 weeks, there was a significantly (P=0.011) higher reduction in hand eczema score on the combination therapy compared to the placebos. However, the primary endpoint was not statistically significant as patients received combination therapy and then a monotherapy. The combination therapy was also significantly better than the topical corticosteroid used alone in terms of reduction in hand eczema score (P=0.007) and quality of life when compared to placebo (P=0.049) after 32 weeks. Additionally, patients satisfaction was significantly higher with the combination treatment at the end of the study compared to that achieved with either therapy alone or placebo.CONCLUSION: The combination therapy consisting of clobetasol propionate and lansoprazole might be an effective treatment option for chronic idiopathic hand dermatitis. The reduction in the total hand eczema score and the improved quality of life, patient satisfaction, and high adherence rate observed in the current study support the efficacy of this combination therapy.

BACKGROUND:
Patients with hypertensive stage I chronic renal insufficiency (mild renal insufficiency) are at risk for a fall in residual renal function and renal failure due to the administration of iodinated contrast for computed tomography angiography, an imaging technique used in the assessment of patients with peripheral arterial disease. We sought to determine whether the administration of oral contrast before computed tomography angiography was a suitable alternative to avoid contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) while preserving the diagnostic image quality in patients with early-stage renal insufficiency.MATERIAL AND METHODS: We performed an interventional prospective crossover study of 44 patients with mild unilateral renal insufficiency undergoing computed tomography angiography for peripheral arterial disease. The study patients had a serum creatinine level of up to 1.6 mg/dl and underwent angiography of the abdominal aorta and their legs. The patients received oral contrast in the first study and intravenous contrast in the crossover study. Serum creatinine was measured before and up to 2 days after each computed tomography angiogram. An independent blinded observer assessed the image quality.RESULTS: Contrast-induced nephropathy occurred in 10.5% in the noncontrast group compared with 15.5% in the intravenous-contrast group (p < 0.05). However, compared with oral contrast, a higher rate of inadequate image quality for the leg arteries was noted with intravenous contrast (p < 0.05).CONCLUSION: Oral contrast may be an alternative to intravenous contrast when patients with advanced but mild unilateral renal insufficiency require computed tomography angiography for the evaluation of peripheral arterial disease.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Vitreoretinal surgery is the gold standard for the management of complex retinal diseases such as endophthalmitis, retinal detachment, and macular hole. With vitrectomy, the vitreous is removed from the eye, and the disease is treated. However, there is a significant risk of post-operative inflammation, which can lead to vision loss and the need for additional surgery. One approach to preventing post-operative inflammation is the use of intraocular agents that directly target the immune system. Systemically administered dexamethasone has shown to be effective in reducing inflammation, but it is associated with a high risk of side effects. Intraocular implants of dexamethasone have been developed to achieve local delivery of the medication and reduce the risk of systemic side effects. The aim of this study is to compare the effectiveness of intraocular dexamethasone implant to systemic dexamethasone in preventing post-operative inflammation after vitreoretinal surgery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Vitreoretinal surgery is a common surgical procedure that involves the removal of the gel-like vitreous fluid from the center of the eye. The surgical procedure treats many conditions, including retinal detachment, macular hole, and epiretinal membrane. Despite the surgical success, there is a risk of post-operative inflammation and swelling, which can lead to a loss of vision. Systemic anti-inflammatory therapies such as non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications or prednisolone are prescribed to help reduce the risk of post-operative inflammation. However, many patients fail to respond to these drugs, and there is a need for more effective interventions. Preclinical studies have shown that intraocular administration of dexamethasone implants can be effective in reducing inflammation and achieving rapid resolution of post-operative inflammation, while minimizing systemic exposure to the drug. Effects of Different Treatment Methods of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This experimental study is to analyze the clinical characteristics of patients with carpal tunnel syndrome, especially the effect of different treatment strategies on pain relief and wrist function recovery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This experimental study is to analyze the clinical characteristics of patients with carpal tunnel syndrome, especially the effect of different treatment strategies on pain relief and wrist function recovery. The effect of different treatment strategies, including non-surgical and surgical treatment of carpal tunnel syndrome, will be compared. There are 140 patients in this study, with 70 patients in each group. The non-surgical treatment group will receive physical therapy, corticosteroid injection or NSAIDs. The surgical treatment group will undergo elective carpal tunnel release through the wrist flexor incision or carpal tunnel incision. Abstract:
Glycemic control (GC) impairments in patients with cancer are associated with a high risk of morbidity and mortality, but the specific cause‐and‐effect relationship between HbA1c and clinical outcome in individual patients remains uncertain. Our aim was to determine the influence of HbA1c on the prognosis of colorectal cancer (CRC) patients. We evaluated 1,998 CRC patients who received chemotherapy with or without surgery and/or radiotherapy. Patients were allocated to poor (≥ 7%) or normal (< 7%) blood glucose based on the most recent HbA1c data and were stratified into 3 groups based on blood glucose level: both good (< 7%), poor (≥7%), or in‐between (6%‐6.9%) glycemic control. Logistic regression analysis was done using the Hosmer‐Lemeshow test to verify the accuracy of the classification. Time‐to‐event analysis was conducted using the Kaplan‐Meier method. Univariate and multivariable analyses were performed to determine the relationship between HbA1c levels after 72 hours from admission and prognosis of surgery‐treated CRC patients. A total of 267 CRC patients with surgery‐specific HbA1c levels 50 days before and after treatment initiation participated. Poor blood glucose (AIC: 6.5%‐6.9%) was not a significant predictor of recurrence, whereas good blood glucose (< 6%) was significantly related to recurrence. In patients with stage III CRC who received adjuvant 5‐FU‐based chemotherapy, high HbA1c (BGL50: 5.8%‐6%) was associated with a shorter recurrence‐free survival. In conclusion, poor glycemic control in colorectal cancer patients is a strong predictor of shortened recurrence‐free survival, particularly in patients who have received aggressive adjuvant chemotherapy.

Abstract:
Introduction: This study is designed to reduce distress, hopelessness, and promote subjective health among older Chinese adults. Specific aims are to: (a) compare distress and subjective health between Hong Kong and Canada; (b) compare hope and hopelessness among two Chinese subgroups, Hong Kong Chinese and Canadian Chinese; and (c) examine the influence of hope on the relationship between stress and subjective health among the two groups. Results: Participants were older Chinese adults (N= 269, Mage = 77.02, SD age= 6.50, 63% female, 27% Hong Kong Chinese and 73% Canadian Chinese). There were no significant differences between Hong Kong Chinese and Canadian Chinese for distress, hopelessness, or subjective health. Older Hong Kong Chinese had higher hope than Canadian Chinese. Hong Kong Chinese had lower stress that affected subjective health. Hopefulness was not a unique predictor of subjective health among Hong Kong Chinese, but a unique predictor of subjective health among Canadian Chinese even after controlling for stress. Discussion/Conclusion: The stress‐health model may not be generalizable to Asian cultures, and Chinese samples may be more optimistic. Future research should examine why hope has a unique impact on stress‐health relationship among Canadian Chinese samples.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This Phase 1/2, open label, dose-escalation and expansion study is designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, immunogenicity, pharmacodynamics, and preliminary efficacy of SNS-101 as monotherapy or in combination with cemiplimab in patients with advanced solid tumors.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Part A/B will consist of dose-escalation and a crossover component in patients for whom SNS-101 has been discontinued. Part C will consist of 12 dose cohorts exploring the PK/PD relationship in non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Patients will be enrolled to the study on a rolling, multicenter/multinational basis. During Parts A, B, and C, SNS-101 will be administered alone or in combination with cemiplimab. The first drug cohort treated in Part A will be a monotherapy dose escalation cohort. If that cohort is determined to have reached the safety and tolerability (ST) endpoint in Part A, the study will expand to Part B. Part B will consist of a crossover cohort of patients who, for any reason, have discontinued from Part A. In Part C, up to 12 dose cohorts will be opened concurrently and the investigators will explore the PK/PD relationship in NSCLC. At this time, enrollment will continue until the predetermined number of patients per dose cohort is met, or enrollment at a specific dose level is closed early based on safety reasons.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is an 18-month study of the use of inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) and high-intensity inhaled bronchodilator (HIB) therapy in older adults with severe asthma. Eligible participants will be randomised to receive treatment with ICS-HIB as a single therapy or as combination therapy with a different bronchodilator.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The overall objective is to evaluate the relative effectiveness of low-dose ICS-HIB compared to standard-dose ICS-HIB in terms of its ability to achieve an acceptable number and severity of exacerbations among adults aged greater than or equal to (≥) 60 years with severe asthma. The study will be an 18-month randomized controlled trial with a 36-month follow-up period. The trial duration will be 18 months. The study will enroll adults aged ≥ 60 years with uncontrolled severe asthma. The study will include a 4-week screening period followed by a 12-week run-in (baseline) period. Participants will then be randomized to receive either low-dose ICS-HIB or standard-dose ICS-HIB for 12 weeks. After the 12-week treatment period, all participants will enter a 12-week maintenance phase in which they will continue to receive their assigned treatment. At the end of the maintenance phase, participants will be followed for an additional 36 months. The primary outcome of the study is the rate of exacerbations as measured by the number of asthma exacerbations per year. Secondary outcomes include quality of life (assessed using the Asthma Quality of Life Questionnaire), healthcare utilization (as assessed by the EuroQol-5 Dimensions Questionnaire), and lung function (as assessed by spirometry).

Official Title
-----------------
Pragmatic Randomized Clinical Trial of Low-Dose Inh

Scientific abstract
=================
Asthma is a common respiratory disease that affects many people. Severe asthma is a type of asthma that is more difficult to control, and it can cause significant symptoms and can be life-threatening. As a result, there is an increasing interest in understanding the epidemiology of severe asthma in different populations. In this study, we aim to conduct a nationwide, cross-sectional, multi-center survey to gain a better understanding of the prevalence and characteristics of severe asthma patients in Egypt. The study will involve collecting data on the disease severity, treatment history, comorbidities, and patient experiences using surveys and interviews. This study is expected to provide valuable information for health professionals and policymakers to improve the management and treatment of severe asthma patients in Egypt and other similar settings.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a single-arm, open-label Phase III extension study designed to evaluate the long-term safety and tolerability of Itepekimab given as subcutaneous injections every two weeks (Q2W) or every four weeks (Q4W) in approximately 210 to 270 participants with COPD who have previously completed participation in EFC16750 or EFC16819. The study enrollment is stratified based on the baseline severity of airway inflammation as determined by blood white blood cell expression of interleukin (IL)-5Ra as a surrogate measure. The two groups will be enrolled at approximately 11 to 15 sites per treatment country/region.

While the incidence of ovarian cancer increases with aging, the number of elderly patients with ovarian cancer that are treated with curative intent is declining, particularly in the United States. Currently, the standard treatment for elderly patients with ovarian cancer is surgery followed by chemotherapy with platinum-based drugs. However, the use of this standard treatment is associated with a high level of toxicity in elderly patients, and the response rate to this treatment is significantly lower compared to younger patients.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The effects of an educational program (EP) on depression in patients with early breast cancer were evaluated.METHODOLOGY: This randomized controlled trial (RCT) randomly allocated patients with newly diagnosed breast cancer to two groups. In intervention group, the patients were educated by their physician and nurse about breast cancer and its treatments; whereas, in the control group, patients were treated by their physicians only. Depression symptoms were evaluated with Beck depression inventory‐25 at baseline, at the time of initiation of treatment, and during follow ups at 3 and 6 months.RESULTS: Eighty six patients participated in the study. Demographic and disease characteristics were similar between the two groups. The mean depression scale score was 10.81 ± 6.97 in intervention group and 10.94 ± 5.70 in control group. Depression score significantly decreased, from baseline to 3 and 6 months, in both groups. There was no difference in depression scale at each time between the two groups.CONCLUSION: The addition of a nurse‐led educational program does not confer any additional benefit in decreasing the depression score at 3 and 6 months. However, it does not have any detrimental effects on patients with newly diagnosed breast cancer as well.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The majority of older adults with lung cancer or lung cancer related symptoms experience significant anxiety and depression symptoms, which contribute to healthcare use and costs and may affect adherence to treatment and long‐term outcomes.OBJECTIVE: This pilot study aimed to investigate the efficacy of brief behavioral activation (BA) on anxiety and depressive symptoms, healthcare use/costs, and to identify factors associated with baseline levels of preoperative symptoms.DESIGN: This was a 2 x 2 factorial (BA vs usual care, anxiety vs depression) randomized controlled trial (RCT) nested in a randomized controlled trial of lung cancer screening participation. Setting, Participants, and Interventions: Eligible English‐speaking older adults with lung cancer (n = 69) were recruited from Mayo Clinic Rochester, MN between August 2018‐January 2020. Eligible participants were randomized in a 2 x 2 factorial (BA vs usual care, anxiety vs depression) design to receive a four‐session BA intervention delivered by study staff or usual care. The intervention targeted management of anxiety and/or depressive symptoms based on clinical need from the baseline questionnaire and continued for four‐weeks. Main Measures: Primary outcome measures included changes from baseline in anxiety and depression symptoms. Secondary outcome measures included changes in healthcare use and cost at 12‐weeks from baseline.RESULTS: Compared to the usual care comparator at 12‐weeks from baseline, the BA group experienced significantly greater reductions in anxiety and depression scores. For all participants, symptoms decreased significantly after receiving the BA intervention (Cohen's d for anxiety ‐1.22, p=0.001; Cohen's d for depression ‐0.82, p<0.01). There were no significant differences by baseline symptoms severity. For healthcare use and costs, the groups did not differ at 12‐weeks from baseline (p = 0.23).CONCLUSIONS: Results provide preliminary evidence of the efficacy of brief behavioral activation on anxiety and depressive symptoms.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Research is being done with a special dye that may help identify the changes that occur in the blood vessel walls in a condition called kidney disease. This includes conditions such as diabetes and high blood pressure. As a result of these diseases, individuals with kidney disease may be at risk of developing kidney failure. Your body may also make less of an enzyme call ACE-2. This can cause your blood vessels to harden and narrow, which may increase your risk for cardiovascular disease. This study is being done to see if low ACE-2 levels are linked to increased risk of developing kidney disease and kidney failure. The researchers also want to learn more about the ability of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to see how low ACE-2 levels may impact the structure or shape of your kidney's blood vessels. MRI is a painless procedure that uses a magnetic field and radio waves to create images of internal organs. The researchers want to know if there is a connection between low levels of ACE-2 and MRI-detected signs of kidney artery disease.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a single-center, proof-of-concept human observational study nested within the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA). MESA has collected medical history, physical measurements, blood and urine samples, and images of the heart and arteries from more than 6,800 men and women aged 45 to 84 years, who are free of clinical cardiovascular disease at the initiation of the study. MESA participants are classified into four racial/ethnic groups: Non-Hispanic White, Non-Hispanic Black, Hispanic, or Chinese. Each participant in this study will have an MRI scan. The researchers will use the MRI scans to record measurements of the structure and volume of the kidneys and kidney arteries. The researchers will use the MESA sample from 20002-2006 when ACE-2 testing was not available

Abstract: Introduction: To evaluate the effectiveness of the combined anterior suprascapular nerve block and superficial cervical plexus block in pain management and anesthetic recovery time for patients undergoing shoulder arthroplasty under general anesthesia. Method: This study was a prospective, randomized, controlled, double‐blind study. Sixty patients undergoing shoulder arthroplasty were randomly assigned into two groups: Group A (n = 30) received combined anterior suprascapular nerve block and superficial cervical plexus block, and Group B (n = 30) received general anesthesia alone. The pain level was assessed using the visual analog scale (VAS) and the number of rescue analgesic doses required in the post‐anesthetic care unit (PACU) and during the 24 hours following surgery. The duration of blockade onset, the duration of postoperative analgesia, the time to first analgesic request, the time to first oral intake, and the time to ambulation were also recorded.
Results: The combined block group had a lower postoperative VAS score than the control group, with a statistically significant difference (P<0.05). Patients in the combined block group received fewer rescue analgesic doses than those in the control group (P<0.05). The time to first analgesic request and the time to first oral intake were significantly shorter in the combined block group than in the control group, and there was no significant difference in the time to ambulation between the two groups (P<0.05).
Conclusion: The combination of anterior suprascapular nerve block and superficial cervical plexus block is effective in relieving postoperative pain and reducing the need for rescue analgesic in patients undergoing shoulder arthroplasty under general anesthesia.

Absolutely! The Pittsburgh sleep quality index (PSQI) is a self-reported questionnaire that assesses sleep quality and disturbances over the past month. The total score ranges from 0 to 21, with higher scores indicating worse sleep quality. The PSQI can be used as a screening tool for sleep disorders and as an outcome measure to evaluate changes in sleep quality over time. The self-rating depression scale (SRDS) is a widely used questionnaire that measures the severity of depressive symptoms. It consists of 20 items and has a total score ranging from 0 to 60, with higher scores indicating higher levels of depression. The SRDS can be used as an outcome measure to evaluate changes in depressive symptoms over time. The Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) is a brief cognitive screening tool that assesses various cognitive domains, including attention, executive function, memory, language, visuoconstruction, and conceptual thinking. The MoCA scores range from 0 to 30, with higher scores indicating better cognitive performance. The MoCA can be used as an outcome measure to evaluate changes in cognitive functioning over time. We can design outcome measures as follows: PSQI total score, SRDS total score, and MoCA total score. The scores at baseline and each follow-up visit will be compared to assess changes over time. These outcome measures will help us understand the impact of perioperative neurocognitive dysfunction on sleep quality, depressive symptoms, and cognitive functioning in elderly non-neurosurgical patients.

Conclusions PPDS was not associated with gallbladder morcellation methods in patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Abstract:
Background: A new mutational and epigenetic signature developed to predict early occurrence of distant metastases (DM) in patients with stage III‐IV non‐squamous non‐small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) has been recently validated. The current study sought to investigate whether the signature may serve as a reliable predictor for DM in patients with NSCLC, regardless of histology and stage. Patients and Methods: A total of 378 patients with NSCLC were randomly assigned into derivation (n = 189) and validation (n = 189) groups. A 13‐gene signature was used to stratify individual patients in terms of their risk of DM. The recurrence‐free survival (RFS) of patients in both cohorts was calculated. Results: Median RFS was 29 months and the 3‐, 5‐ and 10‐year RFS rates in the high‐risk group were 52.2%, 45.5% and 45.5%, respectively. The corresponding survival rates in the low‐risk group were 91.2%, 74.8% and 66.8%, respectively. In addition, the 3‐, 5‐ and 10‐year RFS rates in the validation group were 75.0%, 67.5% and 60.1%, respectively. The results indicate that the predictive power of the signature remained stable at 1, 3, 5 and 10 years. The RFS rates in the subgroups of patients with different characteristics were further compared. Conclusion: Our findings suggest that the signature may serve as a clinically valid biomarker in NSCLC patients to identify those with a higher risk of developing distant metastasis. Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to assess the effectiveness of a 40 minute supervised, moderate‐intensity exercise intervention in obese postmenopausal women with osteoporosis and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). A sample of 39 female subjects diagnosed with OSA were randomized into two groups. The first group participated in twice weekly group exercises for a total of 12 weeks, while the control group participants did not receive any exercise intervention. Participants with complete data who were adherent to this 40 minutes exercise intervention over a 12‐week time period and who started the study treatment were included in the primary effectiveness analysis. This study found a significant improvement in the exercise group with improved respiratory function, quality of life, and BMI, as compared with their counterparts in the control group. Additionally, the exercise group's improvements in respiratory function and quality of life were highly correlated, while their BMI and respiratory function data were significantly correlated.

Intervention Description:: The intervention in this study is the development and application of a prognostic epigenetic signature for predicting the risk of early relapse in oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (OPSCC) patients. The signature is derived from methylation changes in the DNA of tumor samples before treatment. 
The study design is as follows: 
1. Recruitment of patients with newly diagnosed OPSCC: eligible patients will be identified during their routine clinical care at the hospital, and those who meet the inclusion criteria will be enrolled in the study.
2. Collection of patient samples: blood samples and tumor samples will be collected from each eligible patient before treatment.
3. Development of the epigenetic signature: DNA methylation profiling of tumor samples will be performed using appropriate laboratory techniques to identify differentially methylated regions (DMRs) between patient tumor samples with and without early relapse. The DMRs will be used to develop an epigenetic signature predicting early relapse.
4. Application of the epigenetic signature: the epigenetic signature will be used to stratify patients into high-risk and low-risk groups based on their tumor sample DNA methylation data. The treatment modality will be adjusted based on the identified high-risk and low-risk groups.
5. Follow-up: patients will be followed up every 3 months after treatment to monitor their treatment response, clinical outcomes, and patient-reported outcomes. 


Study Objectives
=================
The primary objective is to evaluate the effectiveness of the epigenetic signature in predicting the risk of early relapse in OPSCC patients, as compared to traditional prognostic indicators. 
The secondary objective is to examine the utility of the epigenetic signature in predicting overall survival in OPSCC patients. 
The tertiary objective is to evaluate the patient-reported outcomes, including quality of life, pain, and adverse events, in OPSCC patients with different risk groups.

Study design
=================
Premise
=================
Robotic-assisted segmentectomy for lung cancer has become increasingly popular due to its minimally invasive nature and potential for improved outcomes.16 However, there is a need for randomized controlled trials (RCTs) to clarify the impact of robotic-assisted segmentectomy on patient outcomes.
Previous RCTs have been conducted on robotic-assisted lobectomy for lung cancer.17 However, these studies lack sufficient sample sizes to assess the safety and effectiveness of the procedure. In addition, the sample sizes are limited to small subgroups, such as those with centrally located tumors or those with a high risk of postoperative complications.
Furthermore, RCTs are typically powered to detect differences in overall cancer-specific survival.18, 19 However, the survival curves do not necessarily indicate the relative safety or effectiveness of robotic laparoscopic surgery versus a traditional laparotomy or thoracotomy. Therefore, conducting a clinical trial with a large enough sample size to allow for subgroup analyses is crucial to assess the impact of robotic-assisted segmentectomy on patient outcomes in various subgroups.20
The objective of the proposed trial is to assess the impact of robotic-assisted segmentectomy on major pulmonary complications as well as long-term survival outcomes. The following are the secondary hypotheses:
1) Robotic-assisted segmentectomy will be associated with fewer postoperative complications than traditional open lung surgery.
2) Robotic-assisted segmentectomy will be associated with improved survival outcomes compared to traditional open lung surgery.

Scientific premise
=================

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
In this study, the investigators aim to develop and investigate the effect of the K-Geroflex treatment on sleep disturbance among breast cancer survivors by measuring the change in the level of a circadian parameter, core body temperature, in the sleep environment. Core body temperature will be measured using a wristband-type core body temperature sensor.

Detailed Description
-----------------
With the expansion of life expectancy as a result of recent advances in medical science, various diseases that accompany aging such as cancer are increasing. Furthermore, early detection and active treatment of cancer are making a major contribution to extending life expectancy in cancer patients. However, cancer treatment may cause various complications, and side effects such as secondary damage or reduced quality of life are increasing interest in the field of rehabilitation for cancer patients. Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy, especially breast cancer patients, often suffer from a variety of side effects, including sleep disturbance, nausea and vomiting, diarrhea, insomnia, and decreased physical and mental performance. Therefore, this study aims to reduce these side effects and improve the therapeutic effect of cancer treatment by supplementing K-Geroflex treatment along with conventional physical therapy and rehabilitation.

It evaluates grasping, releasing, and manipulation abilities and includes items such as picking up small objects, turning pages, and using utensils. The assessment can be administered at baseline and during follow-up to identify any improvements. 

Secondly, we can use the Assisting Hand Assessment (AHA) to measure the quality of the helper hand function of the participants. It evaluates the help provided by one hand while the other performs a selected manual task. This measure can also be administered at baseline and during follow-up to identify any improvements. 

Thirdly, we can use the Spasticity Assessment Tool (SAT) to evaluate the level of muscle spasticity in the participants. It assesses the resistance of specific muscle groups to passive movement and is scored on a 0 to 4 scale. This measure can be administered at baseline, during the intervention, and during follow-up to monitor changes in muscle spasticity. 

Finally, we can use the Modified Ashworth Scale (MAS) to assess the muscle tone of the participants. It evaluates the resistance of specific muscle groups to passive movement and is scored on a 0 to 4 scale. This measure can also be administered at baseline, during the intervention, and during follow-up to monitor changes in muscle tone. 

By using these outcome measures, we will be able to comprehensively examine the effectiveness of the therapy on functional improvement, hand skills, and muscle spasticity and tone.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to assess the effect of a combination of a short term use of caffeine (one week) and acupuncture (a single session) combined on cardiovascular system (the autonomic nervous system)and hormonal blood level after surgery. Patients will have at least a lumbar disc surgery. The patients will be administered with a nasal spray with a dose of caffeine or placebo. The acupuncture session is added only to the group of patients in a caffeine. The patients will be tested before and immediately after the use of caffeine and at the end of the day. The group that will be given nasal spray with caffeine and receive an acupuncture stimulus will be called Ac+Caffe. The group who will be given nasal spray with placebo and receive an acupuncture stimulus will be called Ac+Placebo. The group who will be given nasal spray with caffeine and will not receive acupuncture stimulus will be called C+CAFFE. The group who will be given nasal spray with placebo and will not receive acupuncture stimulus will be called C+Placebo. The aim of the study is to verify which intervention (caffeine with placebo compared to caffeine with acupuncture) reduces best the autonomic imbalance that occurs after laminectomy and to explore a positive effect of using caffeine in reducing opioid use and anxiety postoperatively.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a randomized controlled study, double blind crossover. Each patient will be included in the study and will undergo all of the visits. The patients will be scheduled for a spine surgery. The patients will be randomized in one of the four groups: Ac+CAFFE, Ac+Placebo, C+CAFFE, C+Placebo. It is not possible to administer a treatment in each patient. Group Ac+Caffe: patients will receive nasal spray with caffeine and receive the acupuncture. Group Ac+ Placebo: patients will receive nasal spray with placebo and receive the acupuncture. Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The current study aimed to evaluate effectiveness, complications, and patients' feedback about the subfascial IOL for the prevention of postoperative corneal edema.MATERIAL(S) AND(S) METHOD(S): After applying the Institutional Review Board (IRB)/Ethics Committee approval, 88 eyes of 88 patients aged 50–60 years who were available for at least 6 months clinical follow‐up were included. The eyes were divided into 2 study groups: 50 eyes of 50 patients had had the conventional technique with the implantation of the IOL inside the capsular bag (group 1); 50 eyes of 50 patients had had the same IOL implanted below the conjunctiva (group 2). The data was gathered using a predesigned questionnaire.RESULTS: The results revealed no significant differences between the 2 study groups according to the baseline variables. At the end of the follow‐up period, the mean spherical equivalent of refractive power significantly (p = .028) differed between 2 groups; at follow‐up period, the median astigmatism was significantly better in group 1 subjects compared to group 2 eyes (0.4 ± 0.9 diopters versus 0.7 diopters ± 0.9 diopters; p > .05). However, the number of patients with best‐corrected visual acuity (≥0.80 on the logarithm of the minimum‐angle‐of‐resolution) was not different between the 2 study groups at the end of the follow‐up period (97% versus 98%).CONCLUSION(S): Overall, both techniques can induce an effective and safe visual rehabilitation. However, subconjunctival implantation can provide better postoperative biomechanical stability and astigmatism reduction.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this research study is to determine if starting injections of oxytocin in the early stages of labor decrease the time from admission to delivery in women who have a gestational age of 37 or more weeks and are in the active phase of labor.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study uses a double-blind, placebo-controlled design. The primary outcome is the timing of delivery (total time from randomization to delivery). The secondary outcomes will be: the frequency of cesarean delivery, the time from randomization to cesarean delivery, the incidence of maternal intrapartum adverse events, the incidence of neonatal intrapartum adverse events, the use of epidural anesthesia during labor, the proportion of participants in each of the study groups who receive additional pharmacological augmentation (either oxytocin or misoprostol), and the satisfaction of the participant with respect to her labor.

Official Title
-----------------
Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Trial to Assess the Efficacy of Intravenous Infusion of Oxytocin in Early Labor in Decreasing Delivery Time

Conditions
-----------------
Pregnancy and Childbirth

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Drug: Normal saline, oxytocin

Study Design
=================
Study Type:: Interventional Study
Eligibility Criteria
=================
Inclusion Criteria: Women with a history of hypertension with or without pregnancy-induced hypertension will be eligible for the study. Subjects will be between the ages of 18-45. Subjects must have singleton, viable fetuses, and must have consented to participating in the study. Exclusion Criteria: Women will be excluded if they have previously been diagnosed with preeclampsia, eclampsia, placenta previa, placental abruption, fetal growth restriction, multi-fetal gestation, intrauterine fetal demise, or any other medical condition that may lead to increased maternal or neonatal morbidity and mortality. Women will also be excluded if they have a history of preterm labor, rupture of membranes, fetal distress, birth asphyxia, or any other condition that may affect the outcome of the study.

Primary Outcome
=================
The primary outcome measure for this study will be the incidence of the composite neonatal outcome, which will be determined by measuring the incidence of the following outcomes among newborn infants: Apgar score <7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respiratory distress requiring admission to the newborn intensive care unit, and/or admission to the newborn intensive care unit for at least 24 hours.

Of course! The Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS) is a self-report measure that assesses the impact of fatigue on daily activities, including physical, mental, and social aspects. The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) is a self-report measure that evaluates sleep quality and disturbances over a one-month period. The MOS Pain Effects Scale (PES) is a self-report measure that assesses the impact of pain on daily activities, including physical, social, and emotional aspects. The General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES) is a self-report measure that assesses an individual's confidence in their ability to cope with challenging situations. The University of Washington Self-Efficacy Scale is a self-report measure that assesses MS-specific self-efficacy. The University of Washington Resilience Scale is a self-report measure that assesses an individual's ability to bounce back from adversity. The COPE inventory is a self-report measure that assesses different coping strategies used in response to stressful situations. The Benefit Finding in Multiple Sclerosis (BFIMS) is a self-report measure that assesses the meaning an individual derives from their experience with MS. The Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS) is a self-report measure that assesses overall satisfaction with one's life. The Flourishing Scale (FS) is a self-report measure that assesses different aspects of well-being, including emotional, mental, social, and environmental well-being. The Ryff Psychological Well-being Scales (RYFFPWB) is a self-report measure that assesses different aspects of well-being, such as autonomy, personal growth, environmental mastery, purpose in life, and self-acceptance.

The secondary outcome measures include the Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS) - Change in Fatigue, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) - Change in Sleep, MOS Pain Effects Scale (PES) - Change in Pain, General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES) - Change in Self-efficacy, University of Washington Self-Efficacy Scale - Change in MS specific self-efficacy, University of Washington Resilience Scale - Change in Resilience, COPE inventory - Change in Coping, Benefit Finding in Multiple Sclerosis (BFIMS) - Change in Benefit-finding, Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS) - Changes in Quality of Life, Flourishing Scale (FS) - Change in Quality of Life, and Ryff Psychological Well-being Scales (RYFFPWB) - Changes in well-being.

Of course! The Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS) measures the level of fatigue in individuals with MS. The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) assesses the quality of sleep. The MOS Pain Effects Scale (PES) measures the level of pain experienced. The General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES) assesses self-efficacy, while the University of Washington Self-Efficacy Scale focuses specifically on MS-specific self-efficacy. The University of Washington Resilience Scale measures resilience. The COPE inventory assesses coping strategies. The Benefit Finding in Multiple Sclerosis (BFIMS) measures positive coping. The Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS) measures quality of life and satisfaction. The Flourishing Scale (FS) also measures quality of life. Lastly, the Ryff Psychological Well-being Scales (RYFFPWB) assess psychological well-being.

The assessments for the secondary outcome measures will also be conducted at baseline, 12 weeks, and 24 weeks. This allows for an evaluation of changes over time and the effectiveness of the Unified Protocol intervention on various aspects of well-being in individuals with MS.
